description:
My husband and I ate here before seeing the symphony. We arrived at 5:20 on a Saturday evening (they open at 5) and we were told it was already a 45 minute wait. We put our name in and they texted us 30 minutes later that a table was ready. So definitely be there when it opens especially on a weekend evening! 
The service was great. Our waiter explained the menu and was able to answer our questions about all the different menu items and different types of pastas. 
The house red wine was pretty good. The Brussels sprout, prosciutto and ricotta appetizer was delicious. I ordered The cavatelli with white beans and chicken sausage and it was SO SO good. Super fresh with beautiful flavor. My husband had the bucatini all' amatriciana which was also good but it does have a Smokey flavor from the pancetta which I am not a huge fan of. But if you love pancetta you would probably love this dish. 
The only thing  I didn't love - the tables are very close together - like two inches apart. 
Definitely would recommend!
author: Lauren Z.

description:
I had been dying to try a Mano so I was super happy to snag a table here without a wait for a late lunch! 

We each ordered house wine - they were tiny little pours that took over twenty minutes to arrive. I ordered the pasta with pesto and pine nuts after our waiter raved about how popular this dish was. I loved that the pasta tasted like it was freshly homemade. But other than that, it was super disappointing! It really lacked flavor, seemed under-salted, and was watery rather than creamy as it was described. The portions were really small and the waiter didn't tell us this when we ordered. We found ourselves at the restaurant next door ordering more food right after we left. 

It's quite sad the food and drinks were a miss for me because I love the outdoor seating, the bar, the location, and just about everything else about a Mano.
author: Sarah B.

description:
What a delightful pizza and pasta spot!

Located in the heart of Hayes Valley, you've got tons of seating indoors and heated outdoor seating. The menu is straightforward and their recommendation is one atipasti, a pizza, and a pasta to split between two. The sizing is right for just one person, so don't expect to get carboloaded out here. 

The pricing reflects the quality of ingredients and cooking, which is pretty affordable considering it's in SF. The tagliatelle with chanterelle mushrooms and onions were great, but the highlight of the night was definitely the Monterey Squid with beans! I've never seen bean incorporated into a dish so perfectly before. It provided all the right textures and flavors to balance out the meal. 

This place gets busy, so be sure to come early. There are also daily specials for dinner and drinks.
author: Patty B.

description:
Top five things you'll care to know:
1) No parking. It's Hayes Valley - what were you expecting. 
2) Don't dare come later and expect no wait...it's gonna be a wait. 
3) Holy cauliflower, Batman! The food is crazy good. 
4) The seating is super uncomfortable...very modern of them. Or postmodern...? Tables, like most SF restaurants, are placed very close together. *Wait, who am I talking to again?...my wife...or these nice people next to me....oops*
5) Dunno why but the bathroom line is 100 years long.
author: Adrian M.

description:
4.5 stars. 

This restaurant is one of my favorites in Hayes valley, by the same restauranteur who started Berreta in the mission. Between the two restaurants, I like this place better. Not as loud, better menu, and better lighting. Our waitress was smart, attentive, and friendly

The vegetable dishes are amazing and pasta dishes are always solid. Also fantastic value for the quality of the food. 

MUST GET:
Cauliflower - the texture was tender and crisp at the same time. With a bit of chili and bagna cauda. Very flavorful. 

Monterey octopus with nerello peppers - another fantastic appetizer. Tender octupus and sweet nerello pepper is one of my favorite peppers - great to find them here. 

SOLID:
Agnotti with braised pork, chard, and sage butter - really liked the ingredients and flavor in this dish except that the pasta is undercooked. 

Chocolate budino - this version of chocolate pudding is exquisite with coco nibs, a bit of olive oil, and light cream on top, just the right texture and consistency. We finished every bit of this dish.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
SUCH FRESH PASTA! I'm not a pasta expert, but the pasta dishes we had were so full of flavor and fresh ingredients! We had the bucatini with the tomato and pancetta and the tagliatelle with the pesto sauce and some potato things. I loved both dishes! They were both savory but the flavors were so different. 

I am a little bit biased for the tagliatelle just because pesto and it was sooo savory (umami, too) but the potatoes were a bit too salty. The bucatini was very delicious with a spicy kick! Needless to say, both pasta dishes were very addicting. Initially, I thought that the portions were on the smaller side but this actually was a decent amount for two average stomached girls.

Friendly service. Clean and pretty interior. Great and relaxing atmosphere. Parking is crazy here, though, so I'd either take public transportation or do ride shares... or cross my fingers and toes for a parking spot.
author: Sara T.

description:
This place is good, but not my ultimate favorite homemade pasta place in SF (I like ideale and roma antica the best).

I've tried a few pasta and the pizza, and they are delicious. I've tried almost all, and they change during the season. The wine carafe prices aren't bad either.

They have cute indoor and outdoor seating too, and good cocktails. I will definitely come back here again.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Love this place but think it is a little overrated. 

The mushroom/short rib creamier pastas are wayyyyy better than their marinara pastas.

I'm giving them a 5 because the ambiance is really nice and service was good.

It is difficult to get a table though unless you come early because they don't take reservations, but there is a cute little park across the street you can walk to while you wait. I *think* they may text you when your table is ready.
author: Nadia H.

description:
Delicious fresh pasta for affordable prices in the heart of Hayes Valley! We came around noon on a Sunday and were seated immediately on the patio. We decided to order family-style so we could try a few things and everything was so good - I'd definitely order it all again. For four people (2 guys and 2 girls) four entrees was enough - we could have done 5 to be completely stuffed. 

- Tagliatelle al pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, pine nuts ($16): Very light-tasting and unique; the pine nuts, green beans, and thinly-sliced fingerling potatoes added a delicious crunch and texture. 

- Margherita, tomato, fior di latte, basil pizza ($12): Delicious! Super thin crust and perfect amount of sauce. A margherita pizza done right is absolute perfection and they do it well here! 

- Rigatoni pork sugo ($14) with fried egg ($2): My favorite dish we ordered. Very rich and decadent sauce that balanced well with the rigatoni noodles. 

- Fried chicken with polenta and fried egg: Not sure if this was a weekend special, but the fried chicken was perfectly cooked and crispy. 

Overall, worth trying this place if you're in Hayes! Would love to go back and try more of their menu.
author: Josephine M.

description: Took my cousin here for her birthday since we both have had it on our radar for some time. She ordered the rigatoni with with ragu, which was a little underwhelming in my opinion. I did, however, love my dish- tagliatelle with mushrooms! It was full of flavorful for all you mushroom lovers. The flavors remind me of pasta davinci if any of you have tried that dish from Cheesecake Factory, but with high quality, homemade noodles. I just wish it had even more of that delicious sauce! I would die if they added a hint of truffle.
author: Lexi R.

description:
My friends and I came here for dinner, and the wait can get a bit long, though it was quite a bit shorter than the time we were quoted. For a table of 3/4 we wait about an hour, though we were quoted an hour fifteen to an hour and a half.

We ended up getting a free wild arugula salad as someone misordered or something happened, but the salad ended up just tasting okay, nothing really special that I couldn't find in a salad that was boxed up at Trader Joe's or something.

My friend and I shared the duck pate mousse and it was a bit of a disappointment. The bread tasted like sliced bread from Boudin and the pate wasn't really all that special, it could have been made much more fluffy with a better tasting jam on top.

The biggest disappointment of the night though was the tagliatelle with pesto. We'll start off with the good parts of the dish: the pasta tasted freshly made and had a great texture. By itself it was a high quality pasta  that was well made.

Unfortunately, that wasn't enough to carry the blandness of the whole dish. The whole thing lacked flavor and depth and needed quite a bit more seasoning in general. It was such a boring dish, as if I had just grabbed a jar of pesto and mixed it with plain pasta and nothing else (there were other items in the dish but they didn't add anything flavorwise). 

The big redeemer of the night though was the cocktail! I had the Sirena and it was very well made, with a nice grapefruit flavor, and a small kick in it to make the drink very pleasant while not being too boring.

Probably won't be back with the line, though I might give it another shot if there is a short wait some time.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Third time's a charm- took us 3 times to finally get to eat here (there are no reservations); we managed to get a table after putting our name down at 8pm and getting the table at 9pm.  

Venue / Service: quite packed inside and a bit dark.  However it doesn't feel too claustrophobic, probably because of the high ceilings and windows to let some light in (when there is sunlight).  Given how busy it was, the service was quite good- they were very good at bringing out the food quickly without feeling too rushed and filling up our water glasses.  Our waiter made some excellent recommendations, especially with the pastas (their specialty).  

Food:
-- Cauliflower, lemon, chili, bagna cauda ($8) - I'm not a big cauliflower fan, but these were roasted pretty well and the flavor was great.  Chili was very slight so it doesn't burn your tongue, and the lemon added a great acidity to the dish.

-- Margherita Pizza (tomato, fior di latte, basil)($12) - one of the few times I've seen margherita pizza done quite well!  Also one of few times I ate the entire pizza, crust and all.  The crust is very thin but not to the point where it gets soggy from the sauce and cheese, and overall not super heavy / greasy.  Very clean to the palette.  Great for sharing between 2 people (assuming you are ordering pasta also).  

-- Tagliatelle al pesto (haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, pine nuts)($16) - the waiter recommended this one.  While I usually don't go with pesto pasta period, this one was quite delicious!  The haricot verts and pine nuts gave more crunch to the dish, and the sauce was wonderful since it didn't sit too heavily in your stomach and tasted fresh.  The pasta was cooked a tad over al-dente, but didn't mind it since it had the nuts and haricot verts.

-- Bucatini all' amatriciana (tomato, pancetta, pecorino)($15) - this one is a much heartier pasta dish, especially with the pancetta and pecorino.  Think I would have preferred a little less pecorino since it came out slightly salty, though the tomatoes were able to cut that saltiness a bit.  The bucatini was cooked al-dente and you could tell it was homemade by the chewiness of the noodle.  

Overall I'd say it was worth the wait (maybe because we were starving by then).  It may take a while to be able to nab a table here, but it's a great place to get quick Italian comfort food, especially pasta, in Hayes Valley.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Great lunch place.  I had the Tagliatelle alla bolognese with the meat sauce.  Perfect pasta texture and the sauce was delicious.  Perfect serving size for one person.

I wouldn't mind coming back to try a pizza.  They looked good and big enough to share.
author: Karen L.

description:
My bf and I visited Italy this past spring and ever since then, we have been craving some handmade pasta! I found A Mano a while ago and always wanted to try it, but never wanted to brave the wait for dinner. Luckily, we both work nearby and were able to visit for a Friday lunch, when the restaurant was barely full.

I ordered the tagliatelle with pesto and pine nuts, and he ordered the rigatoni with pork. When the pesto came out, I was so excited because the color was super vibrant, and that's when you know pesto is good!! I had the best pesto of my life in Italy, and this one came close. The pasta also had that perfect bite to it and the pine nuts added a nice crunch. The bf's pork rigatoni was a little watery but flavorful. I want to say the portion sizes were on the smaller size because we both finished our dishes... but honestly, I just think America is used to bigger portion sizes (LOL). We were very content after and can't wait to come back!
author: Tara A.

description:
I came to A Mano for my third time last week. I've been impressed each time! I would probably rate it a 4.5 as it's not the absolute best pasta I've had, but rounded up as I've always had a pleasant experience.

There's typically a wait but this time we arrived early enough (around 5:30pm) and our party of 4 was seated right away. Both inside and outside were available, but we opted for outside as it's a nice setting, and has space heaters. If you do have to wait, you can give them your cell number so you're able to walk around the neighborhood while you wait for your table.

We started with the Margherita pizza which was a great appetizer for the four of us (6 slices total). 

For entrees, we each got a pasta dish. I got the funghi campanelle, one friend got the rigatoni, and the other two each got the bucatini. We each really enjoyed our dishes. The funghi in particular was very unique - I really loved the creamy texture. While the portion sizes weren't huge they were plentiful enough to fill everyone up.

We finished off with the boudino chocolate dessert which was like a chocolate mousse. It was very rich so although it was small, it was perfect for sharing between the four of us.

Our waiter was also very knowledgeable about the menu and wine selection which helped us make decisions about what to get. 

I would absolutely recommend A Mano for a great, reasonably priced weeknight or weekend dinner spot.
author: Jessie K.

description:
Wow, I definitely recommend a Mano / will absolutely come back soon. 

Delicious handmade pasta and pizzas at very reasonable prices in a modern, open dining room. 

No reservations, but they do a waitlist with text notification so you're free to roam Hayes while you're waiting. ~45min wait on a Thursday night.

Dinner for two came out to just a little over $100 including tips for a glass of wine each, the little gem salad, the Fontina Arancini antipasti, and two pasta entrees. 

Didn't try the nightly specials, so will return or that, but both the Funghi Campanelle and Bucatini were 5/5.

I'm saying goodbye to my low-carb diet for you, a Mano~
author: Ashley S.

description:
I've had this place bookmarked for a while, so I decided to check it out for lunch one day when my Mom was craving Italian. First off, the day was very nice so we decided to sit outside. I briefly looked inside and it was large and spacious but i always prefer dining al fresco if I can, and it's great people watching here if you choose to dine here try and eat outside!

This is more of a 3.5/5 review rounded to 3 stars. Our server was not friendly or attentive, and didn't try to be helpful when we had questions - even the party next to us kept asking if she would ever come out again. We ordered the fontina arancini to start, which are basically fried risotto balls, and they were SO good!! I would highly recommend ordering those, and for our entrees I got the tagliatelle (w/ pesto + pine nuts). The food took quite a while to come out, and the pasta was presented beautifully, however, the taste unfortunately fell flat. My pasta felt kind of bland and there wasn't much flavor there. 

My mom ordered the mafaldine which had a nice light lemon-y flavor which she really enjoyed and i tried a little and I actually quite liked that pasta over the one I had ordered. Overall this is a nice spot so if you're in the area and craving fresh pasta this is a good option, but there are also a lot of other options in the area too.
author: Noor H.

description:
Yum, this place is delicious. I went around 1:30pm with my other coworkers. We saw that this place didn't do reservation but thankfully we came when the lunch rush was already over. 

When we came in, we were given the option to sit outside or inside. Both option seemed to be great choices. Eventually the waitress came around to take our order. When we asked for recommendations, she was really rude about it and said "well...they're all great. what are you looking for?" We then asked if she had a favorite and her response was "what have I not already explained to you? they're all great." Wow! You really don't have ONE favorite that stood out? It was honestly off putting, subtract -1 star for that. 

Okay.. back to the food. The appetizers and entrees were delicious. They have different menus for lunch and dinner. The appetizers we ordered arancini, tuscan duck liver mousse, and chicken polpettine. There were 5 of us so they were kind enough to have 5 of each for most of the appetizers for us. The arancini was delicious - everyone must try that. The duck liver was something I could pass - it had a sour taste to it. The chicken polpettine was amazing!!! Was so savory and you got to dip it in tomato sauce. 

Moving on to the main dish, I got the tagliatelle. It was savory, noodle was slurpy, and had the right amount of cheese on top. I honestly haven't had good pasta in a while!! 

At the end, we brought a cake, had it brought out, and they sliced it for us, which was kind of them. I wondered why they were able to do all of that but they charge $2.50 per person to slice. I just thought that was interesting - we could've just gave a better tip? So just heads up if you celebrate your birthday here. 

Overall had a good time here even with some interesting encounters. I would come here again.
author: Sherluna V.

description:
How to eat at A Mano: No reservations accepted

1. Go when they open at 5 pm.
2. If this is not an option, leave your name and number at the door. 
3. Go to Anina or Brass Tacks next door to have a pre-dinner cocktail. If you're absolutely starving, go to Dobb's Ferry Restaurant and have a light snack but show restraint and don't ruin your appetite
4. You'll get a text when your table is ready, you have 5 minutes to text back. I've usually waited 45-60 minutes for 3-4 people
5. Order food and wine! Definitely order the focaccia, arancini and cauliflower to start. Arugula and fig salad was refreshing and vinegary. All the pastas and pizzas are seasonal, home made and amazing.
6. Nap off the food coma
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I don't usually eat pasta too often so when I do, it better be a damn good one. Fresh pasta is the basic standard for SF these days. For me, it's not worth ordering if the pastas are not freshly made. 

We started with a couple of appetizers. The chicken meatballs and the squid dish. They were both really delicious and well made. I don't see a lot of chicken meatballs in the menu in restaurants so it's cool to see it; the meatballs were light and it came with a fresh sweet and tangy marinara sauce. The squid was tender and very flavorful with the sweet corn and shishito peppers that came with the dish. 

Okay so far so good, but we were there for the pasta, so what's the verdict? They were pretty damn good! We tried the bucatini and the paccheri, and I really loved them both. The texture of the pasta was perfect.... al dente of course. The paccheri came with pomodoro sauce, eggplant and capers. Simple ingredients but yet very bright and bold flavors. The bucatini was awesome too; you got the sweetness from the tomato sauce and saltiness from the pancetta.

The ambiance was very vibrant and service was excellent. I will be back to try more dishes.
author: Sam M.

description:
We work nearby and coming to Hayes Valleys is a treat because a Mano is here! The wait time for dinner on a weekday is around15 minutes. They have a texting feature which is convenient. Just make sure you respond within a few minutes, otherwise they will be moving on to the next guest on the list.

We ordered 3 kinds of pasta between the 2 of us.  

1. Spaghettini, fruti di mare, garlic, chili, lemon, bottarga 18.
A light and savory dish (variety of different seafood) that is one of my favorites here! 

2. A seasonal pesto pizza, which does taste good, but lacks meat. You kinda eat with while wondering what else this pasta is missing. Not the best feeling.

3. Rigatoni with pork sausage 14.
This is probably my favorite pasta with good portions sizes and reasonable pricing.

Next time, I think I may try a pizza, but with a good pasta selection, and with Paxti's next door, I am somewhat hesitant. Were I to come here more regularly, I might try the nightly special they have (see below)

nightly special
5 pm - close
monday: market fish
tuesday: short ribs
wednesday: fried chicken
thursday: steak
friday: market fish
saturday: porchetta
sunday: ossobuco

Overall, this is a 4-star restaurant that serves excellent pasta (home-made) with a seasonal rotation of pasta. Yum!
author: Andrew Z.

description:
My experience here had its ups and downs, though I decided to knock it up a star since some of the things aren't reeeally within their control (or it admittedly makes better business sense to have things a certain way):

Pros:
- OMG the food. There's a reason why this place is always so busy. My bf and I shared the arancini (love this! hard to go wrong), focaccia (not as expected since the olive tapenade came on the side rather than the bread having olives within it), Sat special (porchetta, omg so good and salty and crispy, with veggies on the side), and bucatini amatriciana (this was good but nothing special). For dessert was the crostata (which again was good but not amazing). 
- Service. The server we had (unfortunately don't remember his name) was mostly around when needed, considering how busy it was. 

Cons (ish):
- The line. It's a mark of a busy place, but just know that (depending on the time of day) you'll likely need to wait in line. Luckily, you can put your name down and they'll text you when the table is ready, so you don't need to stand outside the door.
- The bathroom situation. There are only two (gender-neutral) for like 100+ customers. There was always a line here. 
- $$ cha-ching. Kinda pricey, but also kinda not, because of the city and neighbourhood that it's in.
- Noise. Since it's a busy restaurant with a lot of people, there are a lot of loud voices as people try to talk over each other.

Overall, the food was superb and I had great experience, so I'm sure I'll be returning soon... maybe I'll try to plan it for off-hours next time though ;)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Always looking for a good place before seeing an SHN show, I find Hayes Valley always has lots of choices and is usually only a 6-8 block walk to the show (albeit through the most depressing/homeless parts of "Twitterverse") to get there.

I had bookmarked this place since it opened and a lot of the reviews said that unless you go there bang on open time, you had to wait...well we got there 30 mins after open and the place was only about 1/6 full.

We sat by the window - I got the view of the kitchen  - and sure enough the executive chef Freedom Rains (Incanto, Flour + Water, Belga, etc) was right there working the line with everyone else, paying special attention to the salads - great to see, that he is still very involved.

Our waiter was Harry (loved his recent wedding btw, I though Meghan looked gorgeous!). He was very friendly and gave us a full breakdown of the menu and specials.  He said we needed to order 3+ things, but 2 was really plenty (even though we ordered 3!)

--Specialty cocktail - A gin martini with pickled tomatoes - Served in a pretty pretty glass!
--Arancini - these were perfected fried, my only complaint of the night would be that the cheese inside was not melted like the photos.
--We split the corn cappetelli - YUM
--And a pizza with shaved zucchini, red onion, zucchini blossoms and some AMAZING kind of melty, buratta-like cheese, we added sausage for $3 and they did NOT skimp. We also specified to make it extra crispy and that was done to perfection.

People are always asking me for recommendations and this place is going on the list, I want to try more of the pastas, and there is a Nuttela sundae for dessert that sounds great!
author: Amy W.

description:
Besides not serving quite enough food, and the 1 hour walk-in wait, a mano served quite a pleasant experience. Their space is huge and accommodates outdoor seating with personal heaters (unsure if it was effective), and there is a text-reservation system implemented so you don't have to wait outside for an hour doing nothing. If bored, a mano is a short walk to the park, loving cup, and bars. 

I got to try the funghi campanelle, fontina arancini, rigatoni, pork sugo, bucatini all' amatriciana. Huge fan of the campanelle, rigatoni with pork sugo was slightly dull flavored/bitter for my taste, and the bucatini could have used more sauce although it came al dente which was pretty nice. Pasta was definitely delicious with a good texture and chewiness. Like I said, wish they served more--I finished my plate way too fast!

Service was friendly and I hope to try their pizza someday.
author: Lydia Z.

description: Loved this place! Low key and relaxed vibe but in a really nice open setting. Really great food, nice sized portions yet very reasonable prices. I started off with a spritz cocktail. We shared 2 pizzas and 2 pastas and you know the meal was great if I forgot to take photos of all of it. LOL! We got the margherita and bianca pies. My fav was the margherita. All bubbly and gooey! The pastas are all home made and cooked perfectly al dente! We got the paccheri with eggplant and the bucatini with pancetta. They lived up to all the good things I've heard about them!!!!
author: Karen R.

description:
Great for the price! On the smaller end but hard to find good pasta under $20 especially handmade ones! 

-Spaghettini is a must! Also it's seasonal so go sooner

-Tagliatelle with pesto was a little harder than I had liked but the pesto sauce was great.

-Funghi campanelle was a bit bland for what I had expected, so I wouldn't get that next time.

-Duck liver is a must as well! They give you so much it's a steal, plus unlimited crostinis!

-Arancini was yummy too, but I didn't expect the sauce to be tomatoey even though it looked like cheese, 


Would definitely come back! I came after 10pm so there was no wait, but it was crowded still.
author: Tina P.

description:
Man, I liked a Mano. 

Everything we got here was amazing and the price was right! (For San Francisco). All the pizza and pasta dishes were priced in the $16 range and considering everything is made fresh, that price point is hard to believe in a city where fast-casual salads places stick you for $20+ per salad. 

We tried 3 different pastas and a pizza and everything was full of flavor. Despite being busy, the service was very attentive. The best part--they gave us LARGE wine pours. 

The great food and service coupled with the location (the best Hayes Valley people watching) a Mano should be on your San Francisco restaurant checklist.
author: Liz S.

description:
I came here for my friends bday and it didn't disappoint! We sat outside and the heat lamps made it super comfortable, plus Hayes st. is so fun to be on. I wish I brought my pug with me, there were so many cute dogs in the outdoor area. 

We had the olives and wine to start, both delicious! I ordered the funghi campanelle with porcini, morels, and fava beans, it was so tasty! Not sure the last time I had a pasta dish this good. 

The waitress was so sweet and helpful, she even surprised the birthday girl with a dessert! I will definitely  be back, highly recommend!
author: Kelly F.

description:
Came in a little after opening on a Friday and we were able to be get seated in no time for our party of 4. Definitely recommend planning to arrive early or plan to wait because I've seen their lines go long!

As first timers, we went in on some cocktails and got the following:
- Bucatini (2 Orders)
- Strawberries, Pickled Shallots, Wild arugula, Pistachio, Ricotta Salata 
- Shishito Peppers & Squid
- Margherita Pizza

Overall, a solid meal, with everything feeling rustic, fresh and tasty. I like the fact that they really let the ingredients shine in the dishes. But if I were to identify a star, it would be the BUCATINI (5 Star dish). We only ordered two orders for the table to share, but I could have easily finished one order all by myself. I'm such the noodle lover and I appreciated the perfect al dente texture and there's something about this dish that epitomized comfort food, where you just feel that love...in your stomach :-). I definitely will come back, as this has been my identified bucatini spot. Thanks!
author: Vincent L.

description:
What is there not to like about A Mano:  beautiful space (+large), great cocktails/ Italian wine list, and wonderful pasta dishes. Came here (for the second time) tonight for a girlfriend dinner and it checked all the boxes (trendy, large enough menu to please all types, easy to do a walk in during the week). If you are looking for good mid range Italian in Hayes Valley look no further. 

Apps and starters are in the $10-14 range, while pastas (which I feel are the most stand out/ inventive portion of the menu) average about $16. I would say portions are a bit small, so definitely order an entree per person as well as some apps and salads to share.
author: Adele T.

description: Next time you're in the San Francisco area, be sure to visit a Mano. This Italian spot in the heart of Hayes Valley serves up some delicious food & drinks. Be sure to get there early - they don't take reservations. I enjoyed the Fontina Arancini, Bucatini all'amitriciana and Cauliflower.
author: Alexa B.

description:
This review is for their bar only, but will definitely need to come back again for the food.

The space has a rustic feel with an open layout with high ceilings, which I like. The bar space only seats about 8, so come early! I had two rounds of their Manhattanero ($13), which is made up of Rye, Cynar, and Italian Vermouth. If you like dark and you like strong, this is perfect. I was definitely on a good buzz by the end of the night.

The bartenders were great about checking up on us along with pouring us some waters too. I'm impressed by the bartenders' effort to provide service without even asking.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
I really really love a Mano - maybe more than I should. I love their pastas - well to be fair, I'm really talking about the bucatini. I've tried other pastas, the pizzas, and salads and they're all good, but they're not memorable so I usually order the same thing.

Few other reasons I like a Mano:
- very affordable for the freshness and the ambiance
- about the ambiance... it's perfect for most groups/occasions. I've come on a couple one-on-one girl dates or in a group of 5-6 girls
- the area is perfect. you have Anina right next door so put your name down at a Mano, pop in at Anina for a drink or two, and wait for your table to be ready (a Mano will text you)
- service has always been friendly. I've accidentally thrown my ring across the restaurant for some weird reason and a server went and picked it up without looking at me like I was THAT weird
author: Sophia L.

description:
You know, even though I've never gotten a seat inside and have always had to wait at least 2 hours for a table, I still for some reason have put myself through this madness, twice already. This review is mainly on food. 

If you come here around 730 like I did yesterday, be prepared to be seated (likely outside) at 930ish. There's no waiting list you can add yourself on through Yelp and they don't take reservations so it's really up to you if you want to wait 2 hours. 

The food is pretty good and if it was closer to home and not a 2 hour freezing cold wait every time I came here, I'd probably frequent it more often. 

Not worth the 2 hour wait but I'd probably say worth a 1 hour wait. 

Onto the good stuff- their menu changes often, if you look to find pictures of their food you won't see pictures of half the pasta dishes. 

Good apps to start-

Fried anchovies
Focaccia 
Monterey Squid 

Pizza- 
Margherita is my go to 

Pasta-
I've tried the funghi Campanella -YUM (mushroom based) and also their tagliatelle pesto. Also YUM. Portion is enough for one person so if you want to share pastas would order a few :) 

Overall, solid pasta place but for a 2 hour wait in the cold it's hard to justify. Better off coming at around 930-10 where you'll get seated (still outside) but right away. 

Oh yea and the people who sit inside seem to never move so Goodluck if you want an indoor seat.
author: Shelly W.

description: Had a Sunday lunch with my boyfriend. There was no wait. We ordered chicken meatball appetizer and two pastas. The meat ball was tender with delightful sauce. The pastas were handmade and very chewy. The sauce tasted light but made the texture of pasta stand out.
author: Tracy F.

description: A great place to have family meal with your friends and loved one. Outdoor and indoor seating are both lovely options for the weekend. The waiters are always super helpful. The pizzas are surprisingly delicious and I recommend getting an order of that along with your pasta orders. I also recommend their focaccia tapenade combo for appetizers. Will be coming back again!
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
Food: 3/5
Service: 2/5
Ambiance: 3/5
Overall: ok food but wasn't too impressed.

The extended review...

Food:

Rigatoni with pork sugo - definitely cooked well but the portion size was small and the pork could have been more plentiful.

Torchetti with sausage - again cooked well but the portion size was small.  Sausage was quite tasty and I preferred the taste of this dish to the rigatoni.

Salsiccia Pizza - a small pizzette. Not bad but definitely nothing to write home about.  Toppings were pretty minimal.

Service: well here you have to wait as the line tends to be long.  My main gripe was that the hostess refused to check us in until the whole party was there.  I'm not talking about seating...check in...  

Ambiance: not a bad setting but it was slightly cramped.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I am extremely picky with Italian food, but this place hit the spot. Keep in mind that they don't take reservations, so the wait can be up to 2 hours at peak dinner time and on the weekends. BUT IT IS WORTH IT. 

Arguably best pasta I have had in SF; me and my friends shared the focaccia, the arancini, and these starters are amazing. The funghi white pizza was thin, flavorful, with a nice touch of a crispy crust. 

Finally, I loved the pesto tagliatelle! The pasta is soft, neither too undercooked nor overcooked, and the pesto is creamy but light at the same time. Melts in the mouth!
author: Marina C.

description:
Came here for my friends Birthday Party, fun place for a small restaurant but with a lively Friday nite crowd.
Great wait staff friendly and tentative.

We shared several dishes Cauliflower, Chicken Meatballs, Margarita Pizza, and Rigatoni. All the dishes were very good. Great flavors, chicken meatballs tender and not dry, cauliflower dish not overly cooked, pizza dough was excellent, great thin crust, marinara sauce was light and not overpowering, the pasta in the Rigatoni was cooked perfectly (to the teeth) but the sauce was slightly salty. 
And of course we ordered dessert 
Chocolate Budino with espresso and sea salt... excellent. 
Panna Cotta with persimmons was nice and creamy. Persimmon gave it a nice crunch contrast. 
Apple tort dessert (forgot the name) but well done nice outer crust with soft but slight firm apples.
These were not overly sweet dessert ... good stuff.

All n all good funny place to have dinner or just hook up with friends. Little pricey but a well had place... check them out !!!
author: M I.

description: If this place was in our city we would eat here once a week. We just came back from three weeks in Sicily where food is a sacrament. Close your eyes and A Mano will take you to Italy. We went very early for lunch and it was easy and pleasant. Service was outstanding--just the right mix of smart and friendly. The Negroni was superb. But come here for the pasta which is fresh and bright. Grated cheese falls like snowflakes over your dish. We devoured the focaccia, the squid, radicchio salad, paccheri, bucatini pasta dishes. Prices reflect the no frills atmosphere, fair and within reach of a normal person. Of course I wish they would start taking reservations, but hey it's San Francisco.
author: Chris V.

description:
a Mano occupies a prime stretch of Hayes overlooking the dog park and, on many occasions, I've walked past to see gigantic lines stretching all the way down the sidewalk. I lucked out by getting in what was already a building line about 5 minutes before opening time on a recent weekend and scored seats without reservations.

For such a popular, well-located venue with solid fare, prices are quite reasonable. I just had to get the fontina arancini ($11) as a starter and it was every bit as savory and creamily saucy as I'd hoped. A paccheri dish (that is, a type of pasta somewhat similiar to, but wider than, rigatoni) was nicely portioned at $15, but not overly so is as so often the case at Italian-oriented restaurants. A mixture of sauce and shredded cheese provided a  perfect, not-overwhelming backdrop to all this.

I couldn't resist dessert, and the chocolate budino with crema and espresso sea salt was a fitting finish to an absolutely satisfying meal. Service managed to be prompt and efficient enough, given that this place filled up fast.

It's certainly good enough for 4 stars now, and I'm motivated to come back and try more to see if it's worth bumping up to 5 stars.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Nice brunch spot, and if you go at opening, no wait! The drinks and starters were total hits, but the entrees were a bit of a miss. Still, I'd come back to try dinner or even brunch again.

THE WAIT: We got there Saturday around 11:20am (they open at 11:30am). There were 5-10 other people waiting. We were all seated when they opened. There are plenty of tables, and A Mano seemed busy the whole time we were there (about an hour), but I don't think there was ever a wait.

THE COST: $67.70 before tips for brunch for two. On the steep side but it was fairly worth it.

DRINKS
* Custom mocktail ($4) - 4 stars
I asked for a mocktail, described the flavors I like (herb-y, refreshing) and got this lovely drink. 

* Il Palio ($12) - 4 stars
Tasty! I tried a couple sips and this was refreshing and nicely balanced. Not too girly - my boyfriend ordered this and liked it too.

ANTIPASTI
* Arancini ($11) - 4.5 stars
Best dish of the meal. Perfectly crisped, lovely gooey filling.

SPECIALS
* Fried Chicken, Polenta, Fried Eggs ($17) - 3.5 stars
The chicken was a little dry, but I liked the thick crispy breading. I really enjoyed the rich, creamy polenta, but my boyfriend found it flavorless and was unimpressed. 

PASTA
* Rigatoni + egg ($14 + $2) - 2.5 stars
For house-made pasta, this was a let-down. The rigatoni didn't taste fresh, and the sauce was watery.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This and Tsubasa are my 2 favorite neighborhood restaurants in Hayes Valley. Amazing food, great atmosphere, and very affordable price point

My friends and I come here probably at least once a week. The menu changes seasonally and everything is always delicious. Very fresh ingredients and love that their pasta is handmade. It makes a world of a difference! This is my favorite pasta spot in the city. I like it more than homemade Italian and SPQR

The wait is long for dinner, but just plan ahead and put your name down early. And yes, 1.5 hr wait sounds crazy but honestly I usually get a table in less time than they quote me. There's plenty of places to get a drink or walk around nearby to kill time. If you don't want to wait, I've found that the wait is much shorter/nonexistent for lunch usually 

One thing to note.. They're always insanely busy for dinner so service isn't always the fastest or most attentive, but the food is so good so I don't mind. You just have to reset your expectations and understand that they're crazy busy. Plus, it's a casual spot anyway so I wouldn't be expecting fine dining service

PS my photos are from various points in the past 6 months so it may not match what's currently on their menu since it changes often
author: M K.

description: Super fresh pasta & pizzas. Definitely try to share a couple things. It's all good.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Definitely get the buccatini and a pizza. The buccatini lives up to all the other yelp reviews, it is really that good. Good bite and nice balance of flavors. The pizza is great in terms of the dough, and baked to nice bite. 

Definitely a line, so be prepared to wait or show up right when it opens. Note that the lunch/brunch menu is different from the dinner menu.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Bottom line: go here for fresh pasta

What to get: the hand-made pastas. The rigatoni was the best, I'd order this again. The bucatini was good, but a bit spicy (hot) despite ordering it with no spice (heat). The paccheri was also good, but the sauce was too heavy and smokey, maybe due to the eggplant flavor.

When to go: casual dinner. This place always seems to have a wait so get there early to get on the list, they don't take reservations. It's very noisy, so more of a casual or group vibe, not a romantic or date night.
author: K R.

description: This is in Hayes Valley. We had pizzas. I had the Salsiccia and friend had Salsiccia minus olives with chilies. It was average, but the interior is nice, lively, and the service was really good. I had a housemade citrus soda. Waitress was nice. It's a good experience out for dinner in Hayes Valley. Pizza, pasta, etc.
author: Denise C.

description: Given that the line is always nuts, I was expecting more from this place, but was left a bit underwhelmed.  Came close to 11pm on a Sat night, so luckily there was no wait! (Would not have been happy to wait more than 30 min.) We got the squid, the chicken polpettine, bucatini, and malfadine. Everything was just OK. The squid dish was actually quite weird to me- an odd cornucopia of peppers, corn, and orange sauce. Actually the orange sauce made it look like I was eating candy corn and kind of grossed me out. Just didn't think the mixture of flavors was that great. The chicken meatballs were quite dense- not very juicy as I was hoping.  The bucatini pasta was solid- no complaints, al dente. And the malfadine was just OK as well. The panna cotta was pretty decent! Good firm texture, although persimmons could have been a bit more ripe. Service was just alright as well. Over all, the pasta was cooked well, but didn't quite wow me as I was hoping. Might return if I went with a party- but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Vivian D.

description:
In the Hayes Valley Foodie Court, this is a gem. They don't take reservations so we headed to the city early and met our off the dole kids for a birthday dinner. They also require your party to be there before seated, so make sure they've called their Ubers.
Good vibe, great space, fills quickly but they are ON IT, taking orders and bringing food to turn the tables. Not rudely, professionally.
Specials each night...I want to go back on a Saturday for porchetta, we passed on the fried chicken but it looked good.

The cauliflower was incredibly good, the aracini was good, the focaccia was good but I wouldn't order again, there were other things I think would be great too.
Favorite pasta was the spaghettini with clams and seaweed (sounds weird but it truly works!) Pizza looked great but we didn't try it.
Next time.
author: Susan K.

description:
Can it be? I think I found one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco!  For me, a Mano embodies all the qualities a great restaurant should have: delicious food and excellent service!

My friend, Henry P. always mention a Mano and I have been intrigued especially since he is very serious about his food lol. 

We started with the Fontina Aracini which was bomb. I would describe it as a fried risotto ball. It had the right amount of crispiness and the inside was just filled with the right amount of cheese. I wish it came with more than 4 balls though.

The star of the show is definitely the Bucatini all' Amatriciana . If you are deciding what to get, don't think, just get the Bucatini all' Amatriciana ! Their handmade pastas are not only fresh, but has a distinct chewiness. It was so refreshing to have delicious pasta. The pancetta and tomato sauce complimented the noodles well. The only downside is that their portions are kinda small. I was full by the end, but perhaps they give you a small portion so you are left wanting more? 

The servers were very attentive and cleared plates and forks after appetizers and made sure to check in on my table even though they were quite busy.

Overall, I'm really impressed by a Mano and I can't wait to come back many more times.
author: Eva L.

description:
I took my parents here for lunch on a Saturday and it was great! I had their house sparkling grapefruit and rosemary soda which was perfectly refreshing. For appetizers, we shared the olive tapenade with focaccia and chicken meatballs. The appetizers were tasty and I especially enjoyed the tapenade because it was so tart and vinegar-y. I ordered the bucatini which was served with a spicy red sauce and pancetta. The bucatini tasted beautiful and the pasta was very fresh. My dad's pesto and peas spaghetti was beautiful and tasted delicious. 

Overall, highly recommend this place! Prices were fair for lunch and I imagine this place would be a great dinner spot.
author: Megan K.

description:
Come here EARLY - even on a weeknight. This place is poppin'! 
The restaurant has a very clean and chic vibe - high ceilings, open kitchen, and huge glass-paned windows facing Hayes St. There is plenty of both outdoor and indoor seating. 

I came here with a gal around a little bit before 6pm and we were immediately seated. At around 7:15pm or so when we left, there was a wait.

The meal:
* Rossini cocktail ($10) - Bubbles, strawberry, and elderflower mix. You had me at elderflower. Honestly, not even sure what elderflower IS, but it just sounds so.... fragrant. I was feeling girly that night. I enjoyed it.

* Squid appetizer ($13) - Squid, beans, with some amazing orange sauce. The squid was tender yet juicy. And they didn't skimp on the portions. Pairing it with the beans with the sauce complemented the otherwise bland squid. 

* Orecchiette pasta ($16) - This was served with clams, some white-wine sauce, bread crumbs, and some kind of slightly sour veggies. Clearly, the description is not giving the pasta justice, but trust - the pairings of all the flavors were so good. The sour veggies paired really well with the clams and the light white wine sauce. Also, who doesn't like an extra crunch in their pasta?

* Bucatini pasta ($15) - TBH, after having a bite of my friend's Bucatini, I wish I opted for this. It's clearly the highlight pasta of the place!! At first, I was skeptical. What could possibly make a pancetta + spaghetti + tomato-based sauce be soooo good? But alas.... The spaghetti was so darn good. I loved the chewiness. The pancetta bits harmonized so well with it all.

Overall, a solid choice in Hayes Valley. I'd come back for the ambiance, and most likely, the arancini. Fried rice balls ftw.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Came again last weekend and it was just as great as the first time!

Fiancee and I were in the Hayes Valley area with our dog and couldn't resist the relatively short wait for an outdoor table on a nice Saturday evening. The outdoor seating is great for dogs - our pup seemed to have a great time sitting on the sidewalk, waiting for people to walk by and pet him. 

Although we really liked the cauliflower and the duck liver mousse we had last time, we wanted to give the other items on their menu a try. We ordered the focaccia, arancini, the salcissia pizza, and a portobello pasta. All were fantastic! Our pizza did not arrive for a while because of a machine malfunction and we were surprised to learn that it had been taken off the bill when the check arrived. 

Order anything and everything. You can't go wrong here!
author: Olivia V.

description:
In a word, delicious! This is the best meal I've had in SF in a very long time! The prices were reasonable, the service very attentive and the food was so so good!

Appetizer = chanterelle mushroom and ricotta with toasted bread
Main = chestnut Campanella with Brussels sprouts. Roasted chestnuts and celery root crema

The house wine was also quite good.

Even though they don't take reservations, the space is quite big so I wouldn't think the wait would be that long.

All in all, it was a fantastic meal. I will be back!
author: Tera K.

description:
The restaurant feels spacious with all the natural light but a bit cramped inside. The sidewalk seating is nice but the heat lamps are absolutely useless, they really lack strength and are tilted away so whatever heat is there doesn't make it down.

The service was very slow and inattentive although our waitress was very friendly. 

We ordered the duck liver mouse which was very light, the cherry topping could have been more sour it was a bit bland. It was served with Crostini, but not enough of them and we had to ask for two refills and seemed to take 15 minutes to get more.

The pasta with pesto was over cooked and dry because it just soaked up the sauce, a few shavings of zucchini didn't do much for the flavor. 

I hope the other fishes are better.
author: Inga W.

description:
As one of many Italian restaurants in the area, a Mano has gained a pretty decent reputation for it's food. Since I had heard so much about it, I decided to go try it for myself. 

Located in downtown SF on Hayes St., the restaurant gets pretty busy during peak lunch and dinner hours. I would definitely recommend going early since they do not take reservations. For parking, they do have a couple stalls right in front of the restaurant, if not, you must find street parking in the nearby area. 

The restaurant itself was pretty spacious and had a nice, relaxing atmosphere. We were seated almost immediately since we had gone on a weekday for a late lunch. Having checked out the menu beforehand, we already knew what we wanted. We ordered the Fontina Arancini ($11), the Margherita Pizza ($12), and the Bucatini all' amatriciana ($15). 

The Fontina Arancini was good, crispy on the outside and warm and gooey on the inside. It reminded me of a scaled up version of fried mozzarella ball with some better cheese and the addition of some rice. 

The Margherita Pizza was brought to our table fresh and hot. Although the texture was good, the amount of toppings was pretty lacking. There were probably 3 or 4 small basil leaves in the middle of the pizza, and a limited amount of mozzarella and tomato sauce. Overall it was average only because of the lack of toppings.

The Bucatini all' amatriciana was delicious, their popular homemade pasta definitely lived up to expectations. The sauce was also delicious , and had a very nice consistency and depth to it. My only issue was the extremely small portion size, other than that I would recommend ordering.

Overall, a Mano definitely lived up to its expectations taste wise. But, the portion sizes could be a lot better for the price.
author: Ben T.

description:
I found this restaurant to be unwelcoming and self righteous with very little to show for it. Knowing that they did not take reservations, I got there early to put my name down and was quoted a 30 minute to 1 hour wait which was totally fine. After about 30 minutes I went back in to confirm that I had requested an outside table and was met with an attitude about how she had quoted me 30 minutes to 1 hour so she didn't understand why I was back (which is not what I had come in to ask about). The. I got a text about 45 minutes in saying my table was ready. I checked in with the hostess and she apologized saying the table was not actually ready. 20 minutes later, they lead us to a table meant for 2 people which clearly would not hold all of the dishes needed for three people. When we pointed that out, it took another 10 minutes for them to figure out another seating arrangement for us. It was frustrating that we had to wait 30 minutes after receiving a text saying the table was ready. 
Once we were seated, the waitress came over but she seemed unprepared to tell us what the restaurant was out of. She mentioned that there was just one more serving of the tagliateli left, which we tried to order, but after checking again she said it wasn't available anymore. Then we placed our order and our waitress came out 10 minutes later to say they were out of the appetizer we ordered. I understand this happens but it would have been nice if she could have gotten a better handle on what was actually available so we wouldn't keep being disappointed. For the main course, we had three of the pastas. The only one that was worthwhile was the bucatini. The spaghettini tastes overwhelmingly fishy and the rigatoni was very bland. Our waitress finally checked in on us when we were almost done with the meal. Then left us with the dessert menu for a solid 15 minutes. We had planned to order but because we didn't want to wait further for the actually dessert, we passed and just went somewhere else for dessert.
author: Gloria N.

description:
Came here with friends' recommendation and it did not disappoint! 

They don't take reservations so we were initially nervous to come to a long line on a Sunday. Luckily we got seated pretty quickly and service was great. We ordered appetizers (cauliflower was really good!) and 5 main dishes to share between 6 people (squash pizza and all their pasta were really delicious, as you can tell they are handmade. The fried chicken special that day was also yummy and juicy). 

Will totally come back again!!
author: Nancy H.

description:
Came here for lunch with a craving for fresh pasta and this definitely hit the spot. 

It was my first time trying bucatini pasta and I think it may now be my favorite all time pasta shape! The pesto was also very fresh and aromatic. 

The star of the show will probably be the cauliflower though. It was DELICIOUS. Not sure how they do it, but the roasted cauliflower has the perfect crispy crust and texture. It also has a lot of flavor. My boyfriend, who does not like cauliflower, said that if I am able to make cauliflower like this at home, he'll grow to like it more
author: Christine L.

description: Great vibe, friendly server with terrific recommendations.  The pasta was incredible! The wait is quite long, so go next door to Brass Tacks for drinks after putting your name in.
author: Jessy E.

description:
As if the city didn't need anymore Italian restaurants a Mano comes to Hayes Valley and kills it! 

Walking in the neighborhood one night we noticed a huge crowd congregating on the street - OOOoOOO whats going on?! - Its the wait list waiting to get into a Mano! Not wanting to wait we showed up for lunch the next weekend and were blown away. The food is amazing!! We got a dish from each category and were impressed with everything. The quality of the ingredients is apparent in each dish. Homemade pasta - bucatini was fresh & delicious. Pizza - thin, crispy & seasoned perfectly. It can get busy but the staff is very attentive and courteous. It made for an excellent meal! Will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Caye Q.

description:
Came for the handmade pasta and was not disappointed. The bucatini was delicious. I particularly liked the chewiness level. 

The cocktail was pretty good. Stronger than I expected.

We came right at the opening time because there's usually a long line. I was glad we made this choice when we had no wait.
author: Sophia L.

description: I don't get what the hype is about for this place. Margherita pizza was tasty but doesn't taste especially delicious. Had the pasta and with clams and it was also not especially delicious.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Ate the orecchiette, clams, broccoli di cicco, garlic, chili, pangrattato. It was more on the sour side. Added salt and a bunch of Parmesan to it. 

Loved the duck liver appetizer. More than the prosciutto- asparagus. 

Long wait time. Our party of 5 got seated in 45 minutes and our seats were towards the rest rooms where the air conditioner was blowing harder then anywhere else. Had to ask for the 5th chair to be swapped out from a simple mini bar stool to an actual  chair with a back. 

Not impressed. Decor is cool. House red was good. Bathrooms are clean.
author: Zita M.

description:
I loved my experience at a Mano!

As a pasta lover, I had been wanting to try a Mano for a long time, but the long lines (and frankly other great pastas in the city) kept me away. Now that I've finally tried it, I can confirm: a Mano makes insanely affordable and delicious pastas.

I came with a group of 4 just before 6:00 on a Friday, and we managed to snag the last table (phew!). We ended up sharing the cauliflower and fontina arancini appetizers and a margherita pizza to start, and then we each ordered our own pastas. I chose the tagliatelle in bolognese, and the handmade noodles and sauce were both perfect. It was just the right amount of food for the four of us, and everything was delicious. It's a cute, buzzing spot in a great location--I'll definitely be back!
author: Kelly R.

description:
I like this place a lot and have been here a fair number of times. I'm in love with the focaccia, I could eat it for days. The pizza is a nice, solid Italian-style pie and seems very gently worked. I think their pasta and pizza doughs could use a touch more salt, and that the pasta could be cooked around 30-60 seconds less (the two times I've tried it, it hasn't been al-dente... it could also be that it needs some more dry time). There's a huge focus on fresh, high-quality ingredients here and they're in the habit of showcasing a number of things that look and taste positively beautifully in-season. This is a really great go-to, but sometimes it's missing a bit of seasoning and balance (e.g., the pesto pasta needed some lemon juice and maybe something else); that said, even when the food isn't amazing it's always made better by the intense flavors of their high-quality ingredients.

In short: good food, reasonable price point. Great little restaurant in an easily-walkable area for dates or dinner with friends or coworkers. Try the focaccia, the pizza, and specials like the fried chicken (which looked phenomenal and several of the people I was with described it as the best chicken they'd ever had). It's important to note that they do not take reservations, you have to physically go there and put your name down. I can understand not taking reservations, especially given the neighborhood and how packed they typically are, but they also won't do takeout.
author: Aly P.

description:
Finally made it to a Mano! I've walked past this place so many times and there's always been a wait.
This review is dedicated to the vegetarian options we tried:
Squash salad: excellent. It was simple, fresh, and delicious. 
Funghi pizza: pretty good. Caramelized onions added a pop, but there was also a Smokey flavor which made the pizza pretty unique. 
Buckwheat pasta: really good. Interesting flavor. Simple ingredients. You could really tell the pasta was homemade. 

The service was excellent. The vibe and ambience lends itself to a nice chill place to meet up with friends and share wonderful food with.
author: Soundarya C.

description:
Worth the wait! The pasta is perfectly cooked and the sauces are classic and mouthwatering. I actually went Friday with my husband and then came back Saturday with my parents, because YOLO.  But hey! At least I can give them an A+ for consistency.

The pizza is great too, but the pasta is fantastic. When in doubt..... pasta.
author: Vee S.

description:
Quick take: Waited a long time for our order


This place has a good vibe. Waiters are friendly. They are good with giving recommendations. We went on a Saturday afternoon for lunch. The place was busy but we did not have to wait for a table. 

Our order took a really long time to come out of the kitchen. Tables that were seated after we ordered got their food before us. We flagged down our waiter and he said our food is coming. Not sure what happened.

Our appetizer and two pasta dishes were very good.
author: Nancy H.

description:
If you plan on going here, try to get to the restaurant as soon as they open because this place gets packed, fast. My friend and I arrived at the restaurant around 5 and all the lower communal tables were occupied. 

The two of us shared the marinated olives, margherita pizza and the Wednesday fried chicken special. All of which were very good but the fried chicken stole the show. It was crunchy on the outside and juicy on the inside. Quite possibly the best fried chicken I've ever had.
author: Sara J.

description:
I live in North Beach which is the mecca of carbs, carbs, and more carbs. So when I visited Hayes Valley, I decided I'm a glutton for punishment and fed my inner fat girl without regret. Maybe it was the red wine that convinced me to indulge. 

My boss raved about a Mano. She said it's her favorite and I must pay a visit to anything that's anyone's favorite so I can judge for myself. 

Came here right when they opened for dinner time on a Saturday. They were already so packed but luckily there was one table outside available.

I ordered the  bucatini, arancini, and the salad that had sardines in it that emulated a caesar but less rich of a dressing.

Let me caveat and say that I'm giving this establishment 4 stars due to the fact that they do not skimp on the cheese! Forget the sprinkling or a dash of shaved parm, this place gives you heaping hurricanes of cheese atop your pasta and salad. It was so glorious!

The bucatini noodles were a bit harder than al dente. The sauce was kind of salty for my liking. The arancini balls (fried cheese balls) in a cheese sauce were cold, and the salad was my favorite (next to the wine). The salad was tart but meshed well with the mounds of parm. 

I really like a Mano for its lack of a hoity toity attitude. Hip hip horray! Kudos for serving up affordable homemade eats in boujee Haye's.
author: Connie M.

description:
One weekend night a friend and I happened to stumble upon a Mano after hanging out in the town and then found ourselves starving. We did have to wait 15 minutes for a table but then the server promptly came and took our drink order. The restaurant is a nice size and the ambiance was chill despite it being busy. They have indoor and outdoor seating but it was a chilly night so we wanted a table indoors. Not sure if they have heating outside.

We ended up ordering the focaccia with olive tapenade and shared the margherita pizza, both were really good and I remember specifically loving the crust (for me all good pizzas need a good crust). I wanted to try the pasta but that would have been way too much food. I definitely want to go back to try cocktails and have the pasta. It was overall a great meal and good experience.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I'm so, so in love with a Mano. Except for the wait. I've tried to come here for dinner on several occasions, only to be told that there would be a 2 hour wait. The trick is to come here early - between 5-5:45 PM, there is virtually zero wait, and you even get a choice of sitting inside or out! I'd recommend sitting outside if it's not too windy, as it's so nice to people watch, and they have pretty strong heat lamps that keep you nice and cozy.

There's a few menu staples along with seasonal dishes, so I'm excited to continue coming back when the menu changes! 1-2 appetizers + 1 entree is usually enough for 2 people. I love the cauliflower and fried asparagus, which was a seasonal dish. The cauliflower is zesty and a little spicy, and the asparagus is very lightly battered, so you don't feel greased up before your meal starts. The arancini balls were quite good and should be tried at least once, but a bit heavy especially given the carb-heavy remainder of the meal.

I've only ever tried the pastas, because I didn't think the pizza selections were anything unique that you couldn't find at Delfina, Del Popolo, etc. Definitely try the new buckwheat rigatoni with cremini mushrooms and garlic. It was hearty and as nutritious as pasta can probably get. I came here twice over the span of three days, which is a testament to how delicious the place is!
author: Denise L.

description:
I've been here for dinner and weekend brunch and I'm a huge fan of a Mano. Venue is spacious with lots of natural lighting giving the restaurant a very airy feel. Plus excellent for food photos. 

I'm a huge fan of everything I've had here. Make sure you don't skip out on their hand-made pastas, my favorite is the mafaldine in kale pesto (and it's vegetarian!). If you want something on the lighter side the gem lettuce or Monterey squid (omg so tender) are excellent starters.
author: Cindy A.

description:
They don't take reservations. Stopped in on a Friday evening at around 630 pm. Put down a name/number on the list and got drinks in the neighborhood while we waited for a text. Wait took about an hour.

We sat outside, under the heaters. The restaurant is new and spacious for San Francisco. It's clean, dimly lit, very loud.

We had an appetizer, a funghi pizza, the squid ink pasta, and another daily special pasta. Everything was fine, but nothing was outstanding. The pizza was bland and the crust wasn't crispy, the squid ink pasta was dry, the other pasta and appetizer I can't even remember. Honestly, if I had known that this restaurant is by the same people who run Beretta and Delarosa, I probably would have not even come in. I do think this is better than Beretta and Delarosa, though. Would I come again? Yeah, I like the ambiance, our waiters were nice, and it's relatively affordable for the location/quality. Does the city offer better pizza and pasta? Definitely.
author: Nelya T.

description:
Lunch review 

Ordered the tagliatelle with fried egg on top (yummy but pork was not very flavorful). Also shared the bucatini which was packed with flavor
author: Laura D.

description:
I really enjoyed our lunch here at a Mano! My friends and I were really pleased with the quality of the food (you can taste how fresh the pasta is!) for its price! Such a cute Italian spot and I would recommend to everyone to try if you're in Hayes Valley. 

What we ordered: 
:: fontina arancini . This was a lighter appetizer to start with. I think I enjoyed the pumpkin sauce more than the rice/cheese balls itself but I liked how it wasn't heavy for something that's fried. (4/5)

::pizza- funghi and salsiccia . I think I enjoyed the salsiccia pizza better than the funghi one even though I love anything with mushrooms in it. I wasn't too crazy about the pizza compared to the other entrées. I think it's because I like my pizza packed with toppings and I was kind of disappointed at how little meat there were on the salsiccia. I do love the thin crust though! (3.5/5)

::pasta mafaldine and bucatini. I loved both of these pasta dishes and they're so different from the each other. The mafaldine ( I believe this is a seasonal dish) was so light and fresh from the pesto and the butternut squash. My friends and I loved the pesto so much (we tried to ask the waiter to ask the chef for the recipe but he never got back to us , so sad). The bucatini on the other hand is more savory compared to the mafaldine but I like how light the dish was even though it was supposed to be the heavier one of the two.  (4.5/5)

::special of the day : fried chicken - my true love.  I believe the chicken is only served on Wednesday and we were lucky ! The thighs were boneless so it made splitting the dish easy and the flavoring was spot on. I wasn't a fan of the kale though.  (4/5)

Overall, we had a great experience in terms of ambiance and service! The bill ended being only $26 each for 5 people for 5 entrees and an appetizer + coffee for all. I think that's a great deal for the quality of the food in San Francisco!
author: Tram N.

description: Good Italian comfort food in a cozy, casual setting.  Hard to get a table due to no reservation but the bar is always available for a short wait.  The Monterey Squid casserole dish is quite flavorful and the Tagliatelle pasta may be too al dente for some but I think it complemented well the tender soft chunks of beef in the ragu sauce -- I loved it!   Also, the Tagliatelle is served very hot.  If you leave it sit for a few minutes and not eat immediately, it will continue to cook and become less al dente.
author: Truman W.

description:
We came on a Friday night and the restaurant was pretty busy by around 6pm. They do not take reservations, but you can put your name on the waitlist beforehand via Yelp. We waited around twenty minutes for a seat at the counter, which wasn't too bad, 

This place isn't your typical, Italian restaurant; it is much more modern and somewhat Americanized. I was expecting bread and olive oil for the table like most Italian restaurants, but they didn't offer it, which was disappointing since that is definitely part of the Italian dinner experience. We decided to order the chicken meatballs, the filled gnocchi dish, and the braised duck pasta. The chicken meatballs were good, but I have never been a big fan of meatballs so I didn't really care for them. The pasta, however, was very good but the portions were extremely small. The braised duck had so much flavor and the curly pasta was a little out of the ordinary. The filled pastas were somewhat sweet from the squash, and the pasta was super sauce. 

Overall, I would come again to this place if I was really craving good pasta. However, be aware that the portions are pretty small, so expect to get an appetizer or pizza also.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Another new Italian establishment opened in the city and I was beyond excited. (Why oh why don't I live in the city?) After seeing all the beautiful photos of delicious pastas and pizzas, I was convinced this was going to be a good match. Is it Julie + a Mano forever?? If they keep up with this level of cooking and flavor, it may just be destiny. 

a Mano is located on Hayes Street in the Hayes Valley area of San Francisco. I don't frequent this area, but I think I should now. The space is on a street full of cute shops and other restaurants. It's just two shops down from the newly-opened Salt & Straw which is super convenient for those who want some good après dinner artisanal ice cream. There's plenty of street parking all around the area. 

a Mano is offering some delicious homemade pastas, pizzas, and small plates from their colorful hipster-ish space. Their menu is simple and they also have an additional "Specials of the Day" menu which hangs on their interior wall. I love that their prices don't break the bank so that many other people can go enjoy their dishes. Having delicious well-made food and making it affordable is something more chefs and restauranteurs should think about. Our server was very helpful and attentive. He came by often to check on us and to ask how our food was. He was knowledgeable about each dish on the menu also. 

The only con I can think of is that they don't take reservations. Why? It's especially uncomfortable when it's a really windy day in the city and you're trying your hardest not to get sick while waiting in line to get in. We lined up outside the door before they opened at 5pm.....with about 15 people ahead of us. Thank God the restaurant is big and can fit about 80 people. So just remember that it's first come first serve. 

Tagliatelle : I really wanted to try their Tagliatelle with Pesto and pine nuts which they used to have just the month before, but I guess they ran out of Pesto? This was good just as well. It was creamy and the pasta was perfectly al dente also. I would definitely order this again! 

Porchetta : This is their Special of the Day. (Saturday) I've never had it as an entrée, only in a sandwich, so of course I had to order it. I was blown away by how thick a slab of Porchetta it was! That piece of pig was HUGE. I feel that it could've feed 4 people. Even the man and woman next to us was pleasantly shocked and they in turn ordered this Special right away. For an exceptional dish like this to have a price tag of just $20 is unheard of in the city. We couldn't finish it at all so we boxed the rest up to make Porchetta sandwiches the next day. The only negative thing I can think of is that it was a bit dry after a couple of bites. I wished there was more salsa verde on the dish.
author: Julie W.

description: My friend took me here for a belated birthday and I had a wonderful dining experience.  She lives around the corner so put our name on the list before I arrived, it was pretty busy around a 45 minute wait.  After we got seated we got our waters right away and our drink orders.  I ordered the monterey squid for us to share.  It was absolutely delicious!! I could've ate like 5 of those little servings!  For the main course I had the spaghetti w/fruti de mare (shrimp and mussels), the pasta was al dente and just light and delicious.  My friend had the funghi campanelle which was rich and creamy.  Price was very reasonable and food came quickly considering I was super hangry and it was so busy there.  I highly recommend coming here.
author: Honey S.

description: I usually don't crave Italian food, but it was strange that this day I wanted some. As me and my friend were walking down the blocks of Hayes Valley, we stumbled upon people outside eating pasta and pizzas, at that moment we knew what we wanted to eat. We went inside to get a table, but sadly they had a wait up to 40 mins, but we went ahead and waited anyways because we didn't know what else to eat. After thirty mins, we got called that our table was ready and got seated inside. The interior is super cute and open, so it doesn't feel tight in there. Me and my friend ordered three items all to share. We got the aracini appetizer, margherita pizza, and lastly the bucatini pasta. The aracini was something I've never had before, it was a fried stuffed risotto and cheese ball served on a mini cast iron skillet. The pizza was alright, it was a little dry and it would've been better if it had more cheese. The good part was that the crust was crispy and non oily. Lastly the pasta, I was expecting more from the pasta portion wise because it literally probably had two long strands of spaghetti only and the dish was gone. However, I thought it was a little too much cheese flavor which overpowered the flavors of the pancetta and the sauce. a Mano is something you have to try if you like pasta/pizzas, but this wouldn't be a favorite spot for me.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I came here for dinner last night with a friend. We ordered a couple cocktails (the mango one is summery and delish but a tad too sweet). We got the arancini for appetizer - really good, soft and cheesey on the inside, perfectly fried on the outside. For food we ordered a pasta and a pizza to split. The Fusili Verdi - which is fusili with peas, snap peas, basil, in a green pea sauce - was very heavy on the pea flavor if you like that (we did!) but I was missing some spice, even just more black pepper.
We also ordered the margherita pizza - which was standard fare and tasty. The crust was perfectly crispy.

All of their pasta is made in-house and you can definitely tell by how fresh it tastes! I missed having spice in the food but that could have been just the items we ordered. But I'll def be back to try some of the more interesting toppings!
author: Farrah N.

description: Was quite a wait for a Thursday night but was definitely worth it. Had amazing steak and pasta to complement sorbet and panna cotta with desert wines on the house! Will definitely be coming back!
author: Max R.

description:
Visiting from out of town and craving Italian food. It was between something "nicer" or a budget restaurant. Decided to splurge a little.

Came around 7:30 / 8 pm and it was like a 1.5 hour wait. Good thing we found some seats at the bar. 

Ambiance is what you would expect. A bit boujee. Minimal.

I really can't remember which pasta I got... It was good but the portion was small for $15-16. My friend's pasta dish was even smaller than mine! I get it's a more "upscale" place, but I was disappointed by the size. 

I think handmade pasta is awesome, but don't think this place is worth a 2 hour wait.
author: Mel N.

description:
This is my new fav go to for a meal, snack anything really in SF! Everything is so fresh and taste so amazing! And for SF it's reasonably priced!

They now do lunch which is exciting! I recommend 2-3 plates per person and you will not be disappointed! Try to make reservations for dinner or be prepared to wait
author: Veronica R.

description:
Finally getting around to writing this review! Came here last month with my husband and cousins and it's a cute little spot. There was a massive wait though and I believe they don't take reservations.

We put our names down, walked around for an hour or so and then came back and waited another 20 minutes before we were seated. 

The service was great. The most memorable thing about this restaurant for me is probably the price. There were 5 of us; we ordered drinks, appetizers and entrees and the bill was $150 before tip. 

The food was decent. I think my favorite was the bucatini and I also enjoyed their focaccia and olive spread. So good! Everything else was pretty average... not bad but pretty forgettable.

Overall, I'd recommend if you're looking for a decent restaurant that won't break the bank. Maybe a first or second date where you're not entirely sure about the person yet and dont want to spend a fortune!
author: Lam M.

description:
We came here right before the Saturday brunch rush after an outdoor  yoga class right across the street and had plenty of seats to choose from. It is very cute bright and airy space (huge windows, it was a sunny morning).
