Our server was very attentive and true professional (I believe his name was Kyle, tall and handsome too :)). Food came out fast and everything was delicious! 

One improvement suggestion: have dairy alternatives. I ordered a mocha and they only had whole milk option. How about some almond/coconut/walnut/pea milks too? It's 2018 and we're in SF!
author: Kat S.

description:
Though there's currently about one million Hayes Valley restaurant options the appeal of a Mano will be obvious to all but the blind:  Hello al fresco dining.  Thanks to climate change, San Francisco can actually be an appealing outdoor destination and it's difficult to walk by a Mano without succumbing to that temptation.  

The outdoor seating at a Mano is arranged in a smart way, maximizing the space and ensuring that passers-by see not just the diners but also, in many cases, the food and drink they're enjoying.  It pretty much dares you to just walk on by, for who doesn't like good Italian fare?  

With a "no reservation" policy, a Mano can be an equal opportunity offender but on the evening I dined there, outdoors naturally, a table was snagged almost immediately.  Service took a bit longer and was actually my only beef with the a Mano experience.  Throughout my meal it was difficult to get or sustain the attention of my server; we weren't asking a lot but did have some questions, some needs for our table, and the requirement that we be on time for a nearby show at SFJazz.  

So, some small beefs about service but zero beefs about the food: this would adequately sum up my a Mano experience.  

Theres nothing ground breaking going on here but the prices - by SF standards - are reasonable and the food is good.  Shared Arugula Salad, Bucatini, Margarita Pizza, and Chicken Meatballs (which I'd have preferred not to share; they're quite good) made for a quality and filling meal with each plate coming in anywhere from about $13 - $18.  The food reminded me of that at Delfina, and that is said as a compliment.  

In this immediate area there's a lot of places I like, all vying for my dining dollars.  A Mano  didn't do anything to cause me to recommend them over some other very good options nor did they dissuade me.  If you're in the area without restaurant reservations it'd be worth your time to see if they could take you.  At worst you're guaranteed a satisfying, reasonably priced meal and there's little not to like about that.
author: Tracey A.

description:
Very tasty pasta dishes at prices most would deem fair for SF. We got 3/4 of the pasta dishes as well as the foccacia, and they were all very enjoyable to eat.

a Mano is a casual-yet-trendy place to see and be seen, and the good food merits another visit sometime when San Francisco. Gets pretty busy, so I'd come in either early or late to avoid the long lines. Al fresco dining would be great here on a nice day!
author: Jocelyn C.

description: I love this place. I recommend it to all my friends as the perfect / cozy date night with very reasonable pricing and amazing Italian options. Definitely family style so you can try different things. So good!
author: Jaclyn B.

description:
Came here in a group of 4 people. Wow the pasta is amazing.

We ate outside in the evening, which I would not recommend due to SF's breeze + chilly nighttime air, because the place was so packed.

Service is super knowledgeable and friendly.
author: Michelle B.

description: LOVED all the pastas here. They don't take reservations, and the line was short if you get here at opening on a weekday. Will definitely be back soon!
author: Jess C.

description:
Now I know why the masses of people are having dinner here! The restaurant is beautiful, but slightly cramped. The large windows facing Hayes bring in tons of light and energy. No reservations, so plan to wait anywhere from 40mins-1 hour, esp during Friday dinner service. They've got any efficient notification process; give your number and you'll get a text once your table is ready. 

The FOOD! They've got some excellent variety of dishes here. We started off with the grilled squid appetizer. It was mediocre. Though nicely grilled, the butter beans and tomato sauce did little to add more flavor. For my main I had, I believe a seasonal dish, chicken and pork ravioli which was just nice. I was expecting more flavor, but overall there was solid flavor. My friend had the tagliatelle al ragu, and that was bomb! Full of tomato sauce flavor, the beef soft and juicy and it was perfect. I paired my meal with a Rossini cocktail, which tasted light with champagne, elderflower and strawberry. It's a creeper drink; you think there's no alcohol and then bam it kicks in. Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Visited last night for a nice Italian meal. We had a carafe of the house red, the cauliflower appetiser and two pastas (one seafood, one meat) for mains followed by the nutella sundae. We got a serviceable portion of pasta for our money (~ $40 each) but every bite was delicious! 

The wait was about 30 minutes at 6:45pm on a Sunday evening, but there are a number of pleasant shops around in Hayes Valley, so it's not a bad place to have to wander around. We stopped into the Warby Parker shop, tried on some sunglasses and then headed back to find our table ready. 

The restaurant is bustling with people (most of whom were on dates, I guess), which is fun but can be a little exhausting if you're looking for a quiet, more relaxed atmosphere.
author: Sunil S.

description:
We've been seeing this place on a few news articles and lists. And every time we walk by, there's a line, especially on the weekends and for dinner. Came about 5:30 on a weekday. And still had to wait about 10 minutes for a table, which I consider not bad. It was outside on the sidewalk though. Luckily it wasn't too cold and they do also have heaters. Service was pretty slow. Sure they were busy. And it probably had something to do with us sitting outside too. But yeah it took a while to get our order (food and drinks separately) taken. Food was brought out quickly (though this is due to the kitchen and another bus boy/expediter/waiter). But then to try and get our check took another 15 min or so after we were done. Also I ordered a house made soda that had passion fruit in it. Now I love passion fruit everything so I had to get it. It came out red from another bus boy/expediter/waiter and I was slightly confused. But sipped it anyways - it was fine, but I didn't taste any passion fruiot. Waiter strolls by 5 minutes later and was like oh did you notice it's a cranberry soda now. They just ran out of the passion fruit one. "I hope that's ok" I remember a rushed apology. But what the heck? You could've told me before you brought out the substitute that you didn't have what I originally ordered. I don't think I wouldn't gotten it if it wasn't passion fruit. But since I already had taken a few sips, I just kept it. Ugh, that's slightly sneaky of them. 
As for the food, I got the torchetti with lamb and broccoli and the agnolotti with chicken and pork. There's a lot of options and it all looked really good and I wanted to try everything. But I think we were happy with what we got. I liked my dish. Torchetti is like a rolled pasta, lamb was tender and not enough broccoli for me, but it was fine. The agnolotti a stuffed pasta, similar to ravioli. It was a chicken and pork mixture inside that was fine. Both dishes could've used more sauce. But the pasta is on point. The waiter made a point of stating that a mano mean by hand so all their pasta is home made. And you can taste it. Portions are really small and the waiter did tell us that when we ordered - it's small plates and meant to be shared and you should get a few dishes to try. But it's also pretty pricy, almost $20 a dish. So we really didn't want to get any more dishes. (And we just ended up getting ice cream down the street for dessert). 
I would try this place again but maybe try to sit on the inside and be up front with my choices. Pasta is good but service brought the rating down.
author: Alison W.

description:
a Mano made the SF Chronicle's top 100 restaurants for 2018.  Good thing I already came a couple of weeks ago with 4 friends for lunch.  We arrived around 11:10am.  Decided to take a seat & wait in front at one of their outdoor tables.  At 11:30am opening hour, the hostess came out and directed us indoors to a very nice table.

We did family style.  Portion sizes are small but when ordered enough, it's satisfying.  

Shout outs:
* the deep fried rice balls (fontina arancini).  We added an additional rice ball as it comes in four to an order.
* the asparagus with pancetta pizza
* the bucatini pasta

Much of what's served is seasonal, i.e. the asparagus and beets.

All the pastas are housemade.  You can visually see the pasta making process through the kitchen window.  When the pasta was brought to the table, one of my friends & I both thought the same thing - I could eat this plate of pasta by myself!!! But I've got to share it with 4 other people.

Our plates and flatware were changed after our starters and salad.  Great attentive service.

They've got daily specials posted available at dinner time only. I'm going to need to come back and try the fried chicken served on Wednesday nights.

We skipped dessert as the restaurant is located in the heart of Hayes Valley, and we wanted to go to another yummy place where we could talk and hang out longer.

Overall great food and great service.
author: Shirley N.

description: I came here on a busy Sunday night with my niece. Has a great bustling atmosphere and a crowd waiting to get seated.  Very good bartenders here who see you waiting and acknowledge you. Pasta was excellent and service very fast and efficient. Will try again perhaps on a Monday or Tuesday night.
author: Paul S.

description:
Relatively newcomer to Hayes valley we decided to give this italian eatery a try.

Parking in Hayes valley on a Saturday can be challenging so plan accordingly. We did end up finding a spot right outside the restaurant but the meter at $5.75/hour was steep!

They have outdoor seating (dog friendly) although the seating is a bit tight between neighbors so a big dog may not Work that well.

Dishes:
Little gem salad: fresh anchovies, a bit on the salty side
Clam rigatoni: clams were food and pasta was el dented but the sauce was very bland 
Margherita pizza with added salsiccia: crust was a bit over cooked and definitely not enough cheese, basil, or sauce. 

Overall we thought the meal was fine but if you want italian food in the city there are many other restaurants in sf that offer a much pizza/pasta.
author: Betty C.

description:
Interesting how on my way to a Mano, I was just listening to a chapter in Bourdain's memoir, Medium Raw, in which he went into great details why sometimes people just want a dinning experience that is simply enjoyable and fun, instead of one that is over the top, takes 5 minutes for the waiter to explain each dish and 5 hours to finish the meal.  

a Mano, if you don't have to wait an hour for a table, is exactly the place to have that enjoyable, fun meal.  It is not fine dinning.  It does not take reservations.  The price is more than reasonable for SF standards.  The space is crammed but twice we had pleasant exchanges with the diners next to us, in a neighborly way.  The decor is very hip but the wait staff was friendly and professional (my cocktail came from behind me in a stealthy maneuver while I was deep in conversation with my sister across the table, that I didn't even notice there was a new drink on the table for me).  

And the food!  We shared 3 apps and 3 pasta dishes, all were excellent.  The funghi campanelle loaded with mushrooms was unanimously our favorite, and the bucatini all' amatriciana was a hair thin close second.  Accompanied by well crafted cocktails, the dinner was, as I kept saying, so enjoyable, so satisfying, and so fun.
author: Jiajia C.

description: OMG! Talk about delicioso! Me and my partner stumbled across this quaint A mano Italian restaurant and it totally surprised us. We ordered bucatini rigatoni Margarita Pizza and something else I'm not sure how to pronounce but it was so good. And just think this restaurant is just steps away from my apartment and a beautiful Hayes Valley it was a lovely day we got to sit outside and I had a little heating lamp so if you got a little cold or chilly they turn it on for you the drinks were amazing. I definitely will be coming back again and again and again did I mention the plates were big enough to share between two people. Awesome A Mano
author: Lorellie S.

description:
I absolutely LOVED this place. The fresh pasta was so damn delicious and perfectly portioned. The flavors were absolutely fantastic.

The service was great, the staff was friendly, and I loved the open vibe of the restaurant. It was pretty neat to see the chefs making the pasta and dough. 

My only regret about coming here is not ordering the pizza! This is definitely on my list for next time.
author: Samantha J.

description:
Yet another great place in Hayes
The restaurant is perfectly decorated and there is enough space around the tables to move around (rate these days)
We had several things off their menu like pizza, salad, most of their appetizers and they are all great ! 
Friendly staff too !
author: Jad A.

description:
A Mano translates to "by hand" in Italian and what A Mano is trying emphasize is their focus on hand crafted food from their kitchen.  They definitely succeed as the quality and attention to detail do shine through!

For starters we had the cauliflower and the squid. The cauliflower was delicious and so was the squid.  However, i felt the squid had too much Ceci Beans.  Found ourselves struggling to finish the abundance of chickpeas.

For pasta we got the tagliatelle alla bolognese and the squid Ink spaghettini.  Again both were delicious, especially the bolognese! The pastas were perfectly cooked.

We also got 2 pizzas, the funghi and salsiccia.  The pizzas stand out because of the thin, crisp, yet chewy crusts!   Put any toppings on it, I'll eat!  

I recommend red wine with everything here!
author: Veasna H.

description: This place is one of the best Italian restaurants in town. Our server Alyssa was charming & attentive without hovering or bugging us, & the food was sublime. It's pricey for lunch, but worth it. The arugula salad with apriums (plum-apricot hybrid), pistachios & pickled shallots was really good. All the pasta is home-made & perfectly al dente. I especially like the paccheri with early girl & sweet 100 tomatoes, with capers. The sauce is sweet bit the capers balance it. I definitely recommend A Mano.
author: Scott F.

description: Definitely a great place to hit up late at night after you've had a few glasses of wine at a nearby bar. We were seated right away but the place was still pretty busy for 10 pm on a Tuesday night. We had the bucatini (amazing texture and just spot on pasta) and the pizza packed with hen of the wood mushrooms. I give them five stars for being so heavy handed with the mushrooms (don't you hate when you order something with mushrooms and there's just a sprinkle?) but in terms of taste, there just wasn't much flavor so the pizza was more 3-4 stars in the end.
author: Joanna L.

description:
4.5 stars. As always, it had been awhile since I got to catch up with Nina Y. but whenever we get together, our restaurant selection is on point. We chose a Mano for this rendezvous, and when you're dining in Hayes Valley, you can hardly go wrong. We made reservations, which I would recommend, because it was quite packed for an early Sunday evening. 

Service was decent, and the interior of the restaurant is beautiful. I wasn't a fan of sitting RIGHT next to a giant pillar (what's up with that?) but I guess that keeps my focus on Nina and our conversation. We ordered a bunch of items that were quite tasty. Nina liked the duck liver mousse, and I was more a fan of the squid starter. The squid has corn, romanesco, and shishito peppers. Beautiful and flavorful dish!

I loved my entree even more. I had campenelle with spinach, kalamata olives, and parmesan.
I'm sure there was more in the dish, but it was amazing. If you don't like salty flavors, this isn't for you, especially when it's covered in kalamata olives. But I was in heaven. Nina ordered the buccatini with a tomato sauce and cheese. Simple looking spaghetti that was also delicious.

We didn't opt to try any of the cocktails or dessert here and instead headed somewhere else for a night cap. Specifically for that squid and campanelle, I would love to come here again. The experience leaves something to be desired, but I had a fantastic time, and this is a great neighborhood for the vibe that a Mano inherently has.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Visited it twice.

Food ------------------------ 4.5
Service --------------------- 4.5
Portion --------------------- descent
                                       not for the starving 

In the age of better pasta ... but also shrinking portion portions
Some places charges $17+ for spaghetti marinara with portion for
     figure conscious super model ... come on ...
Portion is more than some places ...
It is some very well made pasta and well executed dish
Rotating different pasta shapes and style ...
So far ... different offerings to make it interesting.
author: S.K. Y.

description: If you are looking for a place that serves close to authentic Italian, this would be a great option. I liked the vibe if the place, it's spacious and serves good food. I liked the pasta I ordered over the pizza.
author: Rutika D.

description: We had the tomato bucatini and pesto tagliatelle to share. Loved alternating the tangy/sour bite from the bucatini with the salty/pesto-ey bite from the tagliatelle. The bucatini was al dente and on the firmer side, which I loved. I will definitely be returning to try their other handmade pastas!
author: P C.

description: Have dined here twice now and it never disappoints the menu is seasonal and everything on that menu is a must HAVE! So glad we were introduced to this restaurant bc it has become a favorite of ours!
author: Tracy C.

description:
Tried to go to a Mano a couple of times but the wait was always too long. Stopped by for an early dinner, around 5:45pm and were seated immediately. They don't take reservations and the wait can range from 45-90 minutes on busy nights, but that is pretty common for drop ins in Hayes Valley. 

Great homemade pastas. The entrees are reasonably priced and approachable. However, the portion sizes are on the smaller size. I would recommend 2-3 entrees and an appetizer for two people. Full bar with amazing cocktails! They have a large outside seating area out front, which is a good option on nice evenings.
author: Bao D.

description: From refreshing cocktails and beers to delicious food (Pasta dishes are fantastic).  This place is happening, so reservations are recommend or be prepared to wait a bit.
author: Raul R.

description:
Delicious pasta and appetizers! My favorite pasta is the rigatoni with pork sugo. I also love love their cauliflower appetizer.

The line for dinner has gotten crazy lately (I guess it's the new popular spot), so I'm not sure when I'll come back. I wish they start accepting reservations..
author: Novalina N.

description:
This restaurant is amazing!  Staff are friendly, service is prompt. I've read a few negative reviews on here because there are no reservations but it's easy to see why they don't need to shell out for that service. 

Pastas are unbelievable and handmade, pizzas look amazing and our appetizers and salad were fresh and delicious. 

The restaurant is immaculate and everyone works together. Servers were knowledgeable and they've got a great selection of the bar. 

We'll definitely be back!
author: David G.

description:
No way am I going to wait 2-3 hrs for ANYthing so when husband and I were in the area and hungry for an early dinner, I thought it may be the perfect time to try this place since they do not take reservations. I've been wanting to try this place, but haven't done so because of the anticipated waittime.
We arrived right at 5:30pm (Saturday Aug 5, 2017) and had a choice of 2 seats at the communal table or a table outside. We chose to eat inside. A short wait started growing at around 6pm and the place was poppin' with a long wait by 7pm.
 
FOOD & DRINKS
-Monterey squid- Served with summer corn, roman-esco, and shishito peppers on top. Squid smelled amazing and had good texture, not over-cooked. Corn was very sweet, in a good way since corn is in season.
-Pizza- With summer squash, zucchini blossoms, stracciatella, Vidalia onion, lemon. Tasted light, fresh, and the crust was very good. Chili flakes given were spicy, which I liked.
-Spaghettini- With clams, chili, lemon, pangratatto. Served steaming hot! I was told that pasta should not be served steaming hot, but this turned out fine because the pasta was still al dente when we ate it. Clams were flavorful and the sauce/broth was tasty.
-Wallbanger- Cocktail made with vodka, mango, pineapple, mint, Galliano. Dangerously tasty, taste like juice but I was red-faced and tipsy shortly.
-Negroni- Made with Gin, Campari, Carpano Antica. Solid.
 
SERVICE
Good as waitress was friendly and other staff who helped with the food/water were timely. Our order was taken correctly and food came out at a good leisurely pace. Since we sat at the communal table, the waitress took care of all patrons at the table. The group of four older guests next to us received the most attention while we received adequate "normal" amount of attention. The couple who got seated on our other side received an introduction/explanation of the restaurant/menu when they sat down- "all pastas are house-made, as well as our sausage". We did not get that introduction even though we were also asked if it was our first time dining there and we answered "yes". NOT an issue for me, but just something I noticed.
 
AMBIENCE/DÉCOR
Bright and lively. Noise level can be a bit loud inside. Tables inside and outside. Table top of communal table inside is lime green color, which worked very well in photos! Nice wall shelf of alcohol at the bar with several bartenders and multiple seatings available outside which is a good option for summer evenings.
 
Yes, I would come back again because food is solid, drinks are great, and I want to try other items on the menu. To avoid a long wait, I would come for early dinner or come when I'm not hungry so to be prepared for a wait. If that doesn't matter to you, then come anytime!
author: Iris H.

description: Came here in a Friday night around 5:45 PM. It was busy, but we only had to wait 20 minutes. We were able to get drinks while we were waiting and chill outside, so that was nice. Both the cocktails my friend and I got were delicious. It's a nicely lit restaurant and wasn't too loud, but definitely wasn't quiet and intimate. We ordered the duck liver with cherries to start. The combination seemed unusual, but it was an exquisite pairing - the crispy toast with a smooth spread and jam like cherries tasted light and summery. They even gave us more toast when we ran out! My friend ordered a pasta with a red sauce, pancetta I think and other ingredients, I tried it and it was delicious! I ordered a pesto pasta that had little potato slices, fresh pine nuts and grated cheese, and arugula I think. The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, and the sauce seemed like it was super fresh, but it was definitely too salty. Was a little disappointed about that because everything else was so good, but I'm assuming it was just a fluke. I definitely want to come back to try other things, and hope to be more impressed in the future.
author: Carlie C.

description:
Came here on Friday evening, put our names down at 7pm and walked around the neighborhood for drinks and got seated by 815pm.  

The menu had so many great choices it was hard to figure out what to order. 

Our server Domingo was awesome and really helped us pick out the winning dishes. 

We started with the cauliflower and the green lettuce.  Both were really wonderful.  The cauliflower was done just right and the salad was basically like a fresh Caesar. 

For pastas we literally almost ordered the entire menu!  We got every dish except the tagliatelle and the campanelle. 

My favorite was the rigatoni and the gemelli.  What can I say, I love meat! 

I didn't try the pizza margarita but it also got great reviews. 

Overall, lovely meal!  With 2 bottles of wine, how can you go wrong?
author: Kimberly L.

description:
This place is fantastic! I came here for a date night and initially had to put our names down and wait about 30-40 minutes. This isn't a huge deal since they will text you when your table is ready and there's plenty of other things to do in Hayes Valley close by.

We were seated outside on the patio which was a great area to people watch as we ate dinner.

For drinks we ordered the Russini's and we ordered the focaccia bread, beets salad, bolognese and amarciana.

The drinks came quick and were tasty! Next up was the focaccia bread and beets salad. The focaccia bread came with a super tasty olive dip and the beets salad was great too!

Our main courses arrived and perfectly complimented each other. Both pasta dishes were good portions but were extremely tasty!

While they did take a long time to bring us our second round of drinks, the overall experience was great and I will definitely return!
author: James D.

description:
Wow - 4 of us had 4 different dishes and all were amazing

Kyle was the man described everything to perfection and helped us with the order

Can't go wrong!!!
author: Tom R.

description:
This place opened up recently in Hayes Valley in May, and I've walked by it a couple of times but haven't had a chance to try it out until today. When my friend and I showed up at 7pm on a Sunday, I was surprised at how packed it was! Despite the fact that there's tons of seating, both inside and outside, there was a 45 minute wait for a table of 2. We ended up snagging two seats at the bar (where you can order drinks and the full menu) without waiting. 

Started off the night with the sirena (grapefruit, vodka, aperol, calabrian chili) which was delicious - $12. Highly recommend if you like spicy drinks. We ordered an heirloom salad with avocado, cucumbers, and pistachios which was delicious and fresh. We've rarely eaten a tomato salad without any cheese, but it was a great combination. Although I typically go with margherita pizza, my friend convinced me to try something different and we ordered a pizza with summer squash, zucchini blossoms, stracciatella, vidalia onion, lemon - $16. This was unexpectedly delicious. The crust was crispy all around and the cheese was fresh and paired well with the rest of the vegetables. Loved it. We also ordered the tagliatelle with pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, and pinenuts - $15. This was also a winner.

Overall, would definitely come back! Affordable pasta, delicious drinks, and a great ambiance. Sure to become my new go-to pasta place.
author: Sally C.

description: Really young, fun vibe. Good drinks and tasty food. Recommend for anyone in their twenties or thirties with friends visiting from out of town.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
The low review is because of 2 reasons. 
1- service was mediocre, and who serves luke warm tap water! They had the water pitchers sitting at the server area without lids on them the entire time we were there. When people would be seated they would take a warm pitcher water and serve it to the guests, nasty! I'm sure they do this so you can order their spirits. 

2- food was not worth what we paid. I ordered agnolotti dal plin, roasted chicken & pork,
chard, parmigiano-reggiano $16. I basically paid $16 for a cup of raviolis, it was soupy and definitely won't be eating there again. 
I will say that the atmosphere was nice, and seating was okay.
author: Yesus B.

description:
Lovely space, big windows, great neighborhood spot. Probably not a destination but if you're in the area and there's no wait, what a great option. The place has a lot of seating which is awesome because it doesn't take reservations. But the giant space does get noisy and the tables are only two inches apart from each other. It was very hard to drown out the other tables conversation once the place got full. 
The food was definitely good but nothing spectacular and the prices reflected that. It made me wonder why it was so reasonably priced and then after eating there I was like oh yeah that's why. It's fast casual in a cute but loud environment.
author: Veronica L.

description: No wait during lunch time on the weekend! Was seated fairly promptly, and ordered three dishes (one pizza, one appetizer, one pasta) based on the server's recommendation. The arancini was my favorite -- beautifully crusted, warm rice and cheesy filling with a delicious yellow tomato-y sauce. The pizza with white sauce was alright, nothing too special besides the small roasted tomatoes that burst with flavor! The pasta was great and the noodle was cooked perfectly, but the eggplant was surprisingly bitter? Left a funny taste in my mouth, but the sauce was excellent.
author: Joyce T.

description:
I really wanted to like a Mano but the food really fell short in my opinion. Having grown up outside NYC and being half raised on Italian food, I admit I do have expectations of handmade pasta so when a Mano said that was their focus, I expected something great.

Arrived Saturday 10 minutes before they opened and ended up being second in line; by the time 5pm rolled around, there was a line long enough to fill about half the restaurant when let in. 

FOOD:
tuscan duck liver mousse, strawberry mostarda (5/5): This was actually really yummy! The liver mousse had just the right amount of funkiness as expected and the sweetness of the strawberry really balanced it out to created a light and refreshing appetizer. I would definitely get this again!

tagliatelle (2/5): Seems like a lot of reviews spoke highly of this dish but I found this one extremely underwhelming. The pasta actually had very little bite and crumbled quickly with each bite. The pesto was also quite underseasoned which resulted in a relatively bland dish and pasta that really doesn't meet expectations for a pasta that is handmade.

agnolotti dal plin (3/5): Very small portion size but what came was decently tasty. The agnolotti had some good bite and the filling was flavorful. The sauce it came with contained a little bit of chard but did a decent job of pulling the dish together. Overall tasty but nothing great.

bucatini all' amatriciana (3.5/5): Probably the best pasta out of the 3 we tasted. This one actually tasted up to par for something that was handmade pasta with good bite and chew. Unlike the tagliatelle, this dish was actually really salty and the bit of spice only served to accentuate the saltiness more. If this one was seasoned less, it'd stand out more as a decent dish.

Service was good but that's nothing surprising for a hot and new restaurant. I know San Francisco doesn't have as rich a history in pasta and Italian food as NYC but I was pretty disappointed to find how big the gap actually was despite some of the rave reviews.
author: Jason W.

description:
Everything we had was pretty much good. I say pretty much because there were dishes I would have not gotten but two of the people in my group wanted them so, I took one for the team! Hehe. The two dishes I could have gone without were the squid and the summer salad. But, I have to say those two dishes were not so bad.

The standout dishes for me were:

- chicken meatballs looking dish
- pork belly special

The meatballs have this kick and I love it! Plus, the sauce is yummy! If you plan on getting the pork belly, be prepared because it is huge! There were four of us and we still had leftovers. But, there were other dishes that I think my friends may have preferred over the pork. The pork is juicy and flavorful! 

I would definitely would come back here and I would recommend them!
author: Loreto D.

description:
A solid four.

Some options are like "man, I could've made this at home," but other options really knock it out of the park! Hence, this is one of those places I would highly suggest asking the wait staff what is most popular. There are some items on the menu that are staple items, and others are seasonal. I don't remember whether my squid ink pasta was seasonal or a staple, but it was in the "I could've made this at home" category. Another time I've ordered pizza as well as another red sauced pasta that was super delicious though, but somehow I can't remember their names.

Even though there seems to always be a wait any day of the week, what's nice is that there are shops to browse in the area while you wait. My friend and I even got Smitten ice cream before our dinner here once (:
author: Jennifer L.

description:
***Hayes Valley is a lively neighborhood with great shops and the open décor and delicious Italian food of a Mano makes it the perfect lunch spot in this area***

Sometimes, you enter a restaurant and feel like you have been completely teleported to some other place.  Baume in Palo Alto feels that way.  The surrounding area is full of concrete fast casual places and small stores you go to if you need stationary or need to ship something.  But once you enter Baume, you are in an incredibly modern fine dining establishment that sets the tone for the exquisite food that follows.

That is not the case with a Mano.  It feels like it would have to be in Hayes Valley.  Floor to ceiling windows that let out a lot of light (and can even let in nature) allow the bustling and open restaurant to match perfectly with the energetic streets where residents and visitors alike check out the variety of unique boutique stores in this neighborhood.

a Mano serves Italian food.  Their housemade pastas are a real draw.  Not just because the pasta is fresh and bouncy, which it is, but due to their showcase of seasonal ingredients.  These seasonal ingredients allow the chefs to create unique preparations as well as feature delicious ingredients and flavors at peak quality.

I had their chestnut campanelle pasta, which was nicely thick.  They garnished the pasta with roasted chestnuts, which provided a nutty flavor but with a softer and chewier center than the typical crunch you would get from a nut.  There was also celery root crema, which provided some creaminess without being too rich as well as Brussels sprouts leaves, which were lightly bitter and helped the dish avoid being heavy.

For dessert, I had the buttermilk panna cotta with persimmons.  Like the chestnuts, persimmons are only around for certain times of year, and I loved the sweet flavor and juiciness, which was a nice contrast to the sour buttermilk flavor.  The panna cotta was well prepared as it had the perfect amount of wobbliness.

Service was friendly and quick.

Prices are not cheap, but given the quality, I think it is well worth the few extra dollars per dish you might pay at a Mano over other lower quality Italian restaurants in the Bay Area.

a Mano is a very good Italian restaurant.  Their seasonal menu excites me because it makes it the kind of restaurant you can go back to again and again knowing that you are going to have a different experience while also knowing the chefs behind the kitchen will maintain high standards for preparation, presentation and quality of ingredients.

I am not sure what the parking situation is around a Mano.  I would imagine parking options are limited.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Food 3/5. Service 3/5. Ambiance 4/5. Bang for your buck 4/5.

The wait for this place on a Saturday night for a party of six was a three hour wait. That's right a three hour wait. I already planned my birthday dinner here so we decided to get some snacks around Hayes Valley to wait for the ridiculous wait time. 

As one of the restaurants under the Beretta group, I had high expectations for flavorful Italian dishes made with care. The dishes were mixed with some dishes really good while others not as great. The atmosphere was absolutely great with lightly dim lights, and tables inside and out with communal tables just like Beretta. 

Recommendations:

Roasted cauliflower : This dish was delicious with crispy roasted cauliflower with hints of lemon and chili. 

Fried summer beans: This dish was perfectly fried with a breading that wasn't too oily. The beans still had a nice crunch to them and the aioli kept the dish interesting. 

tagliatelle, pesto, english peas, fava pinenuts: This dish was as delicious as it looked with the pesto being fresh and herby. The pasta was thin and perfectly al dente. The roasted pine nuts gave the dish a warm and nutty flavor. 

campanelle, brocolli di ciccio, garlic, chili, nicoise olives: This was probably my second favorite pasta dish with the overall conscious of the dish being light and fresh, but more herbaceous than the pesto. I was worried that the dish was going to lack flavor but it was far from it. 

Could be better: 

fontina arancini: The rice balls were bland and not all of them were equally filled with cheese inside. The sauce on the bottom was stone cold and tasted like store bought vodka sauce. 

bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, pancetta, pecorino: This dish felt watered down, with a lacking of flavor and richness. The pork was a great addition but didn't meld well with the pasta. 

Tortellini: This dish was a little sweet for my taste with the cheese and corn. The broth didn't really add any flavors. 

Buttermilk panna cotta: It tasted like vanilla noosa yogurt with strawberries. I wasn't too impressed with this. 

Biscotti and Nutella sundae: It was meh, with the Nutella and ice cream being just mediocre and the one dimensional biscotti gave no depth to the dish. 

In addition, the service could have been better. Some of the staff members were excellent and gave great attention to details like folding the napkin on the table when a person left. On the other hand, our waiter felt distant and didn't really give us too much attention. In addition the hostess was cold and it felt like she didn't think we were good enough to eat here.

I think that a Mona still needs time to refine their dishes but overall it's still a good restaurant to go too. I just wouldn't want to wait three hours for it. I'll probably come back to try a Mona in a couple of months to see if it's better. 

Tips - Come early to get your name of the list and walk around Hayes Valley to wait. Anina the cocktail bar is right next to it and it's a great palace to wait. They also currently don't take reservations.
author: Brian N.

description:
We wanted to avoid the 45 minute wait so we chose to sit at the bar instead. The place was packed but seating was comfortable. I loved the bright, clean look of the interior. 


[ tagliatelle al ragu ] The pasta texture was firm but chewy. I loved the shredded beef and cheese. The sauce was creamy and extremely savory. Definitely one of my favorite pasta places.
author: Annie Z.

description:
I love this place but I hate that they don't take reservations. The food is really good and prices are reasonable. I also love that they close later than most restaurants (11p weekdays, 12a weekends).

Came on a Saturday night around 10pm and the place was still pretty busy. There was a line just to check in but luckily they were able to seat us right away. We were a party of two.

We were greeted right away and got water. Our server Juliette made some great recommendations and we were set. I told her I don't drink and she was really accommodating and told me what cocktails they could make virgin. I had the Wallbanger and it was great. The cocktail is $12 but the virgin is only $5. I appreciate the fair pricing. Some places would only knock off a buck or two when you ask for no alcohol in a cocktail. 

We had the squid, agnolotti, tagliatelle, porchetta and ended with the panna cotta. Everything was great especially the squid and agnolotti.

Street parking wasn't bad when we went at 10p but during the day would be much harder. 

Overall a great joint for fresh made pasta. I don't often find value in restaurants in the city but I found it here. Our bill came out to about $100 before tax, fee (4%) and tip.

Will be back very soon.
author: Andy W.

description:
With most of San Francisco toiling away at their desk jobs, two other unemployeds and I stopped by a Mano this afternoon for a late, leisurely lunch. We sat outside, watching city life unfold in front of us. There were cars, dogs, delivery boys, men and women of all ages and children of all stripes sharing the sun-kissed street on this radiant spring day. As such, we were in good spirits and a sharing mood. 

We split the asparagus, pancetta, green garlic and pecorino pizza with arugula. This was only our second choice, after the closed-minded chef curiously wouldn't allow us to add pancetta to the margherita. Still, it was dangerously good and disappeared from our plates in the blink of an eye. We also shared two pastas: the trochetti, kale pesto, young carrots and pine nuts, as well as the tagliatelle alla bolognese with an olive oil fried egg. Both were exceptionally plated, though slightly less noteworthy in taste. The kale pesto added some bitterness that, in my view, was uncalled for. As a final note, I got a homemade "soda" of various fruits that was tranquil and refreshing. Overall, a solid (if not exceptional) lunch.
author: Oliver S.

description:
Located in lovely little Hayes Valley is a Mano. My colleague and I hadn't yet had our team holiday lunch, and a Mano was his suggestion. I originally imagined it to be a dimly lit, classically Italian-in-every-way restaurant, but to my surprise, it was bright and airy with an open floor concept. The menu is simple, but there are so many good things to choose from. We ordered (with ratings on a 5 star scale):

- 5/5 Salad: gem lettuce, fennel, radish, anchovy, ricotta salata, capers - The mix of flavors complemented each other perfectly. I love anchovy. If you aren't a big fan of it, you can still get this, because the anchovy is not mixed in. 

- 5/5 Salad: wild arugula, beets, gorgonzola, hazelnut, pickled shallot

- 4/5 Pasta: orecchiette, clams, broccoli, garlic, chili, pangrattato -
The pasta was so well made, there was a certain chewiness to it that you can't replicate through store bought pasta shells. I'm also a huge fan of putting chili on pasta, and the spice in this dish was PERFECT. My only thing is that I'm big on creamy pastas. The orecchiette had more of a soupy base, but nonetheless was super yummy!

- 10/5 Dessert: Chocolate budino - 
Yes, you heard that right. The chocolate budino got a 10 out of 5 stars. So what. It was THAT GOOD. I never have the stomach for desserts after a meal, but the servings here weren't super huge so I had room. The chocolate budino was a rich, dark chocolate pot de creme with mascarpone cheese and a sprinkle of salt on top. Washed down with a Mano's cappuccino, you are in for a TREAT. I would go back here just for this!

- 5/5 Dessert: Apple pie -
My colleague got an apple pie with mascarpone cheese on top. I'm not a huge fan of pie, but from what I tried, this was on point too.

Yelpers beware - they do not take reservations (walk-ins only) and the tables are very close together. I felt at one point we were all listening in on each others' (interesting) conversations. This place is not good for groups. (Which is why I took off one star) Otherwise, the food is solid! Thank you for such a wonderful dining experience, a Mano!
author: Monica M.

description:
Been reading a ton of mixed reviews on this spot. FYI, they're owned by the same ppl as Beretta (and I personally love that spot). Despite the naysayers of long, long lines and spotty service, my friend and I (she's also pescetarian!) decided to give this spot a try. 

First things first, we were seriously prepared to wait. ALL the reviews screamed LONG LINES. BE WARNED. We came here right after work, around 5:50pm(?), and it was about 3/4 empty. What the what??? Did we go to the wrong place? No. Are ppl still out of town from the July 4th wkend? Maybe. Is it better to go before 6pm? Hell, yes. Within 20mins of our arrival, the entire spot was jam packed! 

We both ordered the gin grapefruit bitters situation and it came out straight up. Whoa, it's a Wednesday and I wasn't prepared for that, but it was tasty af. And not too strong (def a creeper). We started with the squid app (perfectly grilled, but nothing EXTRAordinary about it). For the main dishes, we got the clam spaghetti and the pesto tagliatelle. The clam spaghetti came out right away, and it was a good thing we were sharing bc the messed up our order and gave us a second meat pasta dish. We looked confused. They looked confused. Four other tables around us got that correct dish we were waiting on before us...even though we were there well before they were. Fine, you're a new spot getting your bearings, but no apologies or explanation so idk if it was the waiter, server or what, who made the mistake. 

Anywho, a Mano means by hand. They've got guys churning out hand made pasta from their open kitchen, which is great. The pasta was al dente (when it finally arrived), and the "sauces" (not really a sauce, nor should it be) was perfectly light and complimentary to the hand made pastas. Just like when I was in Italy! Extra points for that. 

All in all, good food and good drinks. Service could be a bit better, but I'd def come back. 4 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
We have walked by this place a couple of times and always wonder what is this place that the line is 2-3 hours long. So we sent a friend there to test the water for us first  

He came back with a good feed back & come good instagramable photos so that got us to come and try this place out.  

We hate the ridiculously long waiting line of San Francisco so we skipped lunch & came in for dinner at 5:30 (yes, rolling senior style) to avoid the line but still have to sit at the bar by the window. Not complaining since I love sitting by the window for people watching anyway and have a better & closer conversation with my bf. (Hint: good for making your first move on a date *wink*) 

A Mano is reasonably priced, I am so glad  I thought it would be one of those hyped, overly priced in Hayes Valley but it definitely wasn't. 

We were kind of disappointed when they switched the menu somehow because my test drive friend of ours got the liver duck pate that got us so excited but they took that item out of the menu :( 
So we got the pole beans tempura - It was the best deep fried veggies that I ever had ! It all comes from that amazing aoili that they use to dip those veggies ... damn!! It was Delish! 

As always, I normally go for "Clams spaghetti" - A Mano has not disappointed me. TASTE OF HEAVEN. Right amount of olive oil, touch of salt, the freshness of clams & the perfect  spread for garlic. Nommmmmm 

Paired with a glass of Rose  & topped it off with strawberry panna cotta: oooooh yeaaaah! 

Tiny comment about panna cotta though: it was just okay. Meh.!! 

You tell me to wait 3 hours for this place? I would say no, your time is more valuable than that. There are 5000 restaurants in the city. But for Italian food, you'll have a great time with delicious food.
author: Thao P.

description:
The drinks are great and the appetizers are pretty good as well. 
There also is a nice ambiance.

The main dishes are overpriced and honestly did not taste very good.
I had the Bucatini and my girlfriend had the seafood pasta (the name is escaping me at the moment). Both were incredibly salty. The seafood pasta was particularly fishy which wasn't to my taste (but I guess that might be what you would expect when buying a seafood pasta dish?). Regardless - salt overload. The price of each pasta dish was between $15 and $18 and we really felt like we didn't get anything special for that premium price.

We both agree that we will never return here for dinner, but may appear for happy hour as we did truly enjoy the cocktails and appetizers.

I should also note that there is potential to get great seats here with cool ambiance within the main dining area or next to a window. We got the the dumpster seats smooshed at the far wall by the blinding orifice that lead out into the kitchen (why isn't there a door?). I was essentially brushing elbows with the couple seated at the next table over. That was pretty disappointing.

Honestly I could see this place becoming a four star experience pretty easily if they just lowered their main course dish prices or refined their questionable recipes.
author: Tyler C.

description:
They have the BEST pasta and sauce in SF. I might be bias because I'm in love with one dish, "BUCATINI ALL' AMATRICIANA"!! Honestly my favorite pasta dish ever. It's $14 and made with tomato, pancetta and pecorino. I came here 3 times in 2 weeks and I don't even live in the area. And I got the same pasta all 3 times. My only complaint is the portion size for this pasta dish is smaller than the others. Everything on the menu was also delicious. My breakdown is below.  

Drinks: 
*Rossini - Bubbles, Elderflower, Strawberry.....10 (my favorite) Wine mixed cocktail. It's dangerously delicious! 
*Wallbanger - Vodka, Mango, Mint, Galliano.....12 - Little too sweet for my taste but still
refreshing. 

Pasta: 
Bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, pancetta, pecorino 14 - The BEST! The pasta has the perfect chewiest. The sauce is amazing. Slightly tart and savory. The pancetta just completes the dish with a bang! 
Rigatoni with pork sugo 14 - flat tube pasta and tasty. It's the favorite said the waitress. I like it but I think the sauce is a bit on the watery side. 

Antipasti: 
*Monterey squid, summer corn, romanesco, olives 13 - hot dish, perfectly cooked squid. The sweetest of the corn makes it the perfect summer dish. Very light and tasty. 
*Fontina arancini 11 - I do like this but not my favorite. Fried with risotto on the inside. 
*Cauliflower, lemon, chili, bagna cauda 8 - Love this dish, so good. The best cauliflower I had. I'm sure it's the chili that makes this dish amazing, found a new way to cook cauliflower now. 
*Fritto misto (not on their standard everyday menu) - Fried seafood and veggies. The batter was light and wasn't overly fried. I ate more than I would normally for fried food, which is a good sign. Haha

Pizza 
*Salsiccia, chili sausage, tomato, provolone picante, olives, red onion 15 - pizza was good, thin crust and you can add all the toppings you want. 

Meat: 
*Pancetta - Served with a side small salad. The restaurant switches up the meat dish everyday. I would prefer pasta over this dish. It's good and flavorful but my friend and I think it was more on the fattier side.
author: Sandy B.

description: Be prepared to wait 1-2 hours during peak times but they use a texting system via Yelp which allows you to grab a drink/snack nearby (and there are a ton of options). You can also check your place in line if you get antsy. We came around 7pm on a Friday and waited an hour and 15 minutes for two. Small bar has about 10 seats and is first come first serve if you get lucky. Good selection of beer, cocktails and wines by the glass, carafe and bottle. We ordered 3 pastas to share, all of which were amazing (tagliatelle, seafood spagehttini, pesto and summer squash). Servers were pretty busy so service was friendly but a tiny bit slow.
author: Sarina Y.

description:
Love the space! It's actually not as big as it seems, but they've managed to make it feel open and fit many tables in there without feeling cramped. Service was great. A good amount of vino options and a few tasty sounding cocktails to choose from as well. Food was great and you have a good selection of salad, pizza, and pasta dishes. It wasn't really what I'd consider authentic Italian and thus minus one star. But portion size is decent and very reasonably priced. We tried:

Focaccia with Olive Tapenade: Fantastic Focaccia bread, super flavorful, just the right crusty on the outside and fluffy on the inside. Tapenade was great as well!

Torchetti with Braised Lamb Shoulder, Broccoli Rabe, Capers and Caprino: I loved the pasta made in house and it was cooked perfectly. But the lamb, while didn't taste gamey, was a bit overpowering. The broccoli rabe also tasted a bit bitter. My half Italian boyfriend jokes that he's never had lamb in a pasta dish because that's just not what they do.


Margherita Pizza: Because this is the only kind of pizza my purist half Italian boyfriend orders. You can definitely tell that the pizza wasn't cooked in a wood fired oven, and it wasn't, which is not a big deal. But the dough was a bit too hard and chewy for my preference, and it was actually overly crunchy on the outside. The tomato sauce wasn't as flavorful as I'd like as well. But for $12, I'd say it was a not too bad pizza for one.

Overall a great spot for a chill/low key dinner in Hayes Valley, but actually feel like you are sorta kinda having a night out without all that hassle. Love the no ressie policy so it's first come first served.
author: Nana L.

description: Great pasta dishes! The only thing is that pesto is seasonal so they don't have that dish year round. I brought my husband thinking he will order that since it's one of his favorites but was bummed to find out that they didn't have it at that time! Overall the dishes we did get were amazing. Check out the photo! Great ambiance as well.
author: Sophia K.

description: This is good pizza in San Francisco! I went with friends and sat outside in the sun, which felt great. We got some pizzas and aperol spritz's. The Bianca pizza was my favorite.
author: Sara S.

description:
What an amazing company. I was so excited to try this place for dinner and got all ready and arrived promptly at 7pm, excited for my date to arrive. 

After getting seated and waiting 40 minutes, the date texts and says he's actually not coming after all and stands me up. I'm super embarrassed and frustrated (partly cause I was starving!) and I ask for the check to pay for my drink and leave. 

The waitress was so unbelievably sweet and insisted that they'd not only comp my drink but that I should stay and have a meal on the House because that guy sucks! (Truuu) The couple sitting beside my table insisted I stay and eat with them - and we had a freaking blast!

It was an incredible evening and a true testament to what happens when we all remember that we're human. Sharing a meal with two new friends meant more than that date ever would have!

Thank you A Mano for being human with us. I so appreciate the care and 5-Star treatment you gave me. Thank you Emily for serving us and being a part of this crazy sad-but-then-awesome night.
author: Kelsey W.

description:
Five stars all around. Drinks, food, server, food, ambiance, drinks, everything, such a great experience. Our server was sooooooo entertaining and attentive, he made sure we had a fun time. Oh, A mano means by hand, they make fresh pasta (so freakin' good!). 

I spotted a Mano while driving by - the liveliness of the restaurant caught my attention. What is this place? I asked. And so I yelped, and urged my friends to come here :)  

Four of us came a little before 5 pm on a Saturday evening to skip the line. It was 4:50 pm and there were 5 parties in front of us already (we read that if we come after 5:30 pm we could find ourselves waiting 2+ hours for a table). A mano is not taking reservations yet, so I suggest for you to come early. They also only serve dinner now, brunch and lunch to come (CAN'T WAIT!) 

My crew tried these and we recommend (almost) everything below: 

Drinks:
-Rossini ($10)  if you're feeling sparkly, bubbly, and fruity 
-Wallbanger ($12)  if you're feeling tropical (mango yum), very sweet
-Aviazione ($12)if you want a slight floral gin & tonic 

Food:
-5 stars: monterey squid, summer corn, romanesco, olives $13 (please, please order this)
-cauliflower, lemon, chili, bagna cauda $8 (this one was okay, not worth the $8, but still delicious)
-Pizza: salsiccia, chili sausage, tomato, provolone picante, olives, red onion $ 15 (kind of reminds me of the pizza at Delfina, but with a softer crust). *remember to ask for red pepper flakes! 
-PASTA! The tagliatelle w/ pesto, english peas, and fava pinenuts ($15) was really good, but don't order it if you're not a fan of pesto. I personally love tagliatelle and pesto, so this was the PERFECT combo for me. I'm still burpin' pesto now :) so yummy. 
- spaghettini, clams, chili, lemon, pangratatto ($14)  this was was just okay, very light. I'm not a fan. 

We went to Boba Guys for a drink instead of getting a dessert, though everything on the dessert menu sounded amazing (next time!). 

Overall, a Mano is a great spot for: 
- DATE, bring your date here, he/she will be impressed. The restaurant has ample natural lighting w/ floor to ceiling windows, bar seats all around the windows and tables in the restaurant. 
- friends date, with lots and lots of friends. There are big family style tables perfect for a big group of friends. The more the merrier, everyone will get to try more things off the menu! 
- casual & fun time in the heart of Hayes Valley. Nearby you'll find Smitten, Ritual coffee, Warby Parker, bars, shops, boba, etc. 

a Mano, so glad you're here. Can't wait to come back with more friends so we can try more things!
author: Dana Z.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner on Tuesday, it was perfect spot for us! Great ambiance and pretty fast service! It was pretty empty around 5:30, but we ran an errand and came back at 6:30, and it was packed for dinner!

It is right in the heart of Hayes Valley so parking can be tricky. I am unsure if they take reservations, but if they do, I would make one. We decided to share 2 antipasti, a salad and a main. We went with the cauliflower, lemon, chile bagna cauda (handful of cauliflower) and the fontina arancini (came with 4). Both were very flavorful and the perfect amount to get a small taste of each. We shared the gem lettuce anchovy salad, which was their spin on a caesar. I was able to take off the anchovies which was nice. The tagliatelle alla bolognese was also a great portion to share. It wasn't too heavy which some can be. I would definitely return since there are other menu items that looked amazing when observing tables. We did not order any drinks, but they had an extensive bar and the wines and cocktails were priced between $9-$13. 

I would suggest it as a good restaurant or a girls night or date, the prices are reasonable and the ingredients are quality! My friend is from Italy and finds it to be a great combination of food, atmosphere and location! I look forward to returning and trying a new dish!
author: Paige L.

description: I love this place! The food and atmosphere are great (although somewhat loud at times) but the friendly, knowledgeable and efficient waitstaff make the experience! Try any pasta and you'll be thrilled; try the salad with a soft bed of shaved fresh parmasen and you'll float away! Enjoy!
author: Andrea R.

description:
Super high quality ingredients, can't wait to try this place again. We weren't very hungry so we ordered 3 appetizers which were all great. For the squid dish, loved the corn and shishito peppers. The aranchino was small but maintained it's cheesiness on the inside. The arugula salad came with really juicy peaches which stole the show. 

The vibe of the placed reminded me of a slightly more modern Delarosa. The wait was only 15 min and I was able to go shop while waiting thanks to their text message wait list program.
author: Young Y.

description:
Saddens me to lower my rating of this place but some of the recent reviews are right. The service when I went here was AWFUL.

They gave my food to the person seated next to me. They didn't refill my water until I was almost done eating. They also didn't give me the Parmesan cheese that I asked for till I was almost done with my pasta.

The food is good but the service that I got last time I went here was atrocious.

This was also at the bar where you'd think service would be easier to get but certainly not here. Not if you don't sit smack in the middle right where the bartender is constantly making drinks.

To top it off, the lady who sat next to me and ordered way before I was even seated got her food way later than I have due to them not placing the order properly or something.

Disappointed.
author: David K.

description:
Has the potential to be between 4. 5and 5 stars based on food.  

What we ordered :
-margherita, tomato, basil: thin and Flavorful. Could use one more basil leaf IMO.  ANCHOVIES are a must if you like them. 
-mafaldine, summer suqash: highly recommend if you want to taste  vegetables
-corn-ricotta cappelletti:  delicious but  a bit too sweet for my palate.  As you can tell it was Vibing salt that night. 

Pros : 
-delicious pasta, unique flavors, I didn't feel stuffed after
-pizza is simple, thin crust
-Cool and upbeat vibe
-come as you are or dress up for the meal
-open late

Cons :
-waitlist is long AF!  I don't think they take reservations.  Each time I called, they didn't answer
-the 3x I've been there, customer service kind of sucked.  The hostess isn't welcoming but I suppose you don't need to be with such a long wait.  I had to ask for my waiter on each visit and I'm a patient person! 
-drinkers, I believe there are only two toilets
-for you ppl who insist on driving.  parking is a biznatch!! 

Other comments :
-portions are smaller than usual but I prefer that.
-pricing is fair
author: Kae O.

description:
I love love love this place! So happy about its existence. Hayes Valley is in desperate need of a yummy Italian spot. Had dinner here during its soft opening for a first date with the hottest man I've ever seen in my life. I knew this restaurant would be a hit! My suspicions were correct as I see lines out the door here every night! Its become a total hotspot, especially with Anina next door as well. Never saw my date again but I will for sure be back for the food. 

They don't take reservations which might explain the constant line and wait times. I feel like this place is going to put ll Borgo and Delle Stelle out of business. The cocktails here are amazing and super dangerous. I left here pretty drunk despite stuffing myself silly with yummy carb loaded Italian food. I had the pizza, pasta, and asparagus appetizer. Also had some dessert but couldn't even finish it. I usually do not eat pasta but theirs was delicious. I happily ate my leftovers the next day. 

Prices are on par with all the other restaurants, make sure you add the egg to the pizza. They put the entire egg on just one slice which was kind of weird when its usually in the middle but whatever. I went there a while ago and forgot to finish writing this review so I forgot most of the details. Our waiter Brian was such a pro! Entire staff here is awesome. This place is straight up bumping. Perfect for a fun date night!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Updated review.

The first time I came here, service was good but the food was a hot mess. I left a not quite glowing review and thought I was done with the place. Supprisingly a rep reached out to me and asked for my feedback and to try the place for a second time. I finally did and this place blew me away. The restaurant actually listens! The food was so much better and had less salt. My biggest issue last time was the lack of toppings. For example my Margherita pizza was tiny and only had one basil leaf on it. It would have been topless if I had not ordered an egg on top. This time the fungi pizza was bigger and came with normal amounts of toppings.
author: Diane Z.

description:
Dinner review. 

Fontina arancini - 3/5
Duck liver mousse (kumquat mostarda) - 4/5
Cauliflower (lemon, chili, bagna cauda) - 4/5

Spaghettini (Clams, chili, lemon, pangratatto) - 4/5 
Agnolotti dal plin (roast chicken, pork, chard, parmesan) - 5/5
Rigatoni (pork sugo) - 3/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
I truly enjoyed my mid-week lunch here!

I got there early and I was seated at the bar as requested. The server behind the bar was chill and she let me take my time placing my drink and food order. I don't remember the type of beer that I ordered but it was in a can and it went down well so I ordered two throughout the meal.

The meal I ordered was the orecchiette pasta with clams and it was just what I needed; light, tender, and savory. I took my time eating it and taking it all in. The atmosphere was airy with lots of light and by the time I left, the place was packed.

The server that brought out my food was super cute and I just felt comfortable eating my meal, reading, and just chilling. My only regret was not staying there longer because the next bar I went to was such a disappointment. 

Definitely will be looking forward to my next visit here.
author: Art O.

description:
Mediocre, at best. The salad was very good, but it went downhill from there. The pizza was good. The pork sagu was flavorless and the pork was very dry. The corn-ricotta cappelletti was undercooked and served in a big puddle of water. Not much flavor and like eating raw pasta. 

We got there at 5:15pm and it was completely empty. Nevertheless, they refused to let us sit down and wait for our third. I get that policy when they're busy, but when we're literally the only ones in the entire restaurant, I'd think hospitality would prevail over blindly following rules.
author: B D.

description:
Fresh pasta! While it was super crowded the day I went (they don't take reservations), I heard it was because of an event happening in the city that night and the wait is usually 30 min - 1 hour, not the 2.5 hours that I waited. My 2nd visit, I opted for 8:30pm on a Sunday to avoid any semblance of the usual crowd; we were seated immediately. 

The menu rotates often so it's definitely worth a few repeat visits. The entrees range from $12-16 which in the heart of Hayes Valley, sounds like a steal for a sit down dinner. My ratings are for pasta only; there are other things like thin crust pizza on the menu. 

Rigatoni with pork sugo (summer 2017 visit) 3.5/5 - not my favorite, pork flavor fell a bit flat, nothing special, but I love the rigatoni texture.

Bucatini all amatriciana (Jan 2018 visit) 3/5 - a bit too tomato-y without enough pancetta. Sauce appeared to pretty much be tomato paste, not my favorite.

Agnolotti dal plin (both visits) 4/5 - white parmesan cream sauce over mini ravioli stuffed full with chicken and pork. The cream overpowers the meat flavor compared to a lot of the other dishes.  

Tagliatelle alla bolognese (Jan 2018 visit) 4.5/5 - I'm a sucker for traditional beef bolognese sauce, the tagliatelle was thin but cooked al dente so it was perfect. If you're looking for something traditional, this hits the spot, but if you're being adventurous, look towards something else.

Mafaldine (Jan 2018 visit) 4.5/5 - Really unique protein option for pasta, but did very well with the light clear sauce and chard. Super chewy squiggly pasta (like the rippled edges of lasagna noodles)

I would opt for family style sharing with maybe 1 1/2 plates per person; the portions are a bit small to feed a single person, but great for sharing. I've gotten 4 plates to feed 2 people and 4 plates and an appetizer (fontina arancini - chicken meatballs were good) to feed 3.
author: Kathy T.

description:
I arrived a bit early and hung out in front with the family. Next thing I know, people started lining up behind us. I don't know if they were planning to dine at a Mano like we were or had a case of FOMO, but that was soooo San Francisco. 

It was my birthday and I just finished watching Hamilton down the street (humble brag). I wanted to check a Mano out because the food looked really good and I loved reading about how they planned out their menu, making everything so fresh. We were seated near the open kitchen and we got to watch fresh pasta being made. 

It's tight quarters in here, but don't let that discourage you. The service was top notch and we were well attended to in such a packed and bustling place. We were so hungry that we ordered 4 appetizers, three pastas and the special osso bucco for dinner. Food came out at a good pace and we finished every last bite. My favorite appetizer was the fritto misto with shrimp and calamari, as well as the duck liver. I love that our server offered to get extra crostini when he saw I was finishing them with still a bit of liver to go. The chicken polpetti were good, as was the asparagus with prosciutto. 

I was hoping the special tonight was the porchetta, but the osso bucco was absolutely delicious. It came with polenta that was good, but a little salty. However, the pastas were the star of dinner. We had the tagliatelle, agnolotti dal plin and bucatini.  Each were cooked perfectly and the sauces were excellent, especially the pesto. I secretly wanted the bucatini all to myself, but will have to wait for another visit. 

It seems funny that I don't have a lot of go-to pasta places in the back of my pocket, but a Mano is definitely going to be one for me. I can't wait to go back and try more of their menu!
author: Maria S.

description:
Did not have a reservation and waited around 30 minutes for a table. After 30 minutes, we were seated in the communal table. 

Tuscan duck liver mousse, kumquat mostarda- I liked this very much. The kumquat gave the mousse nice balance. 

Bucatini all'amatriciana- I am very passionate about this dish and its contribution to Italian cuisine. This dish is so beautiful but this restaurant, I feel, did not do it justice. It was so disappointing yet I wanted to love it so much. 

Spaghettini with clams- the chili taste was strong and that was about it. 

The wine list is not too long but I think you can find something to pair your order. Honestly, there is Italian food in the city.
author: Mariana V.

description:
Overall I wasn't impressed with anything we tried, but maybe we got the wrong things.  I would try the restaurant again (When the buzz dies down and waits are reasonable) and get something different.   The all-in cost for 2 people was ~ $60 (dinner + drinks) which is super reasonable for the quality of the food and the area.  

Food
     - Squid with corn, roman-esco, shishito peppers:  The flavor combination of the three
       primary ingredients was inspired, but the sauce was a discordant / overwhelming. I
       think the dish would be delicious with salt + pepper and a lemon wedge.  Squid
       was cooked well - tender and not rubbery.

     - Heirloom tomato salad:  basic salad that was good but under seasoned.  I had hoped 
       to get really flavorful summer tomatoes - these weren't that (hard to blame them)

     - Pecchio pasta with tomatoes and capers. Pasta was perfectly cooked but not a
       particularly interesting or flavorful dish.  

Service
     - Friendly and efficient, but our server didn't really have opinions on the menu / thoughtful 
       recommendations  to make
     - We waited ~ 45 minutes for a table
author: Holly P.

description:
A quick catch up in Hayes Valley for two turned into an impromptu dinner for three.  My friend and I were catching up in the area and it was also the right opportunity to invite a new friend to join us.  As soon as we walked by this new establishment, which we heard good things about, we placed our name on the list for three; more people= more dishes.  

*Arancini - fried rice balls with cheese.  Enough said but the star of this dish was the sauce.  
*Bucatini - the noodles had the PERFECT texture
Agnolotti - pasta was good but filling could've been better
Pizza - the pizza had a nice crispy crust but I wasn't satisfied with the toppings.  

Our server had high reviews for the pasta noting that they hand make them in house and she was right.   

*recommended dishes
author: Linda N.

description:
a Mano was a great place for me and my friend to catch up after not seeing each other for almost five months. Crazy how that works in San Francisco, but after catching each other, I recommended coming to this part of town to try out this new Italian + Cocktail Bar place. Even on a Friday night, we only waited about 20 minutes to get a spot. Luckily I had followed up with the front because they seated us immediately after I had waited 20 minutes but did not notify me on my phone. I am wondering if they're still working out on that system, but I highly recommend coming in earlier than usual for dinner if you do not want to wait in the long liens. 

FOOD: For the antipasti, we went with the cauliflower with the bagna cauda. The cauliflower was cooked to perfection and the bagna cauda was delicious with the right amount of garlic in the sauce. For the pasta, I got the mostaccioli with the tripe and I must say, the pasta was perfectly made by hand. The right amount of al dente and the tripe was cooked to perfection, this whole pasta dish came together quite well. Their cocktail list is not super long, but definitely worth a dive in, especially ranging in the $11-$13 range, which is reasonable for SF. 

SERVICE: Pretty smooth; however, the timing was a bit off on the courses, but it happens. 

Overall, one of my favorite Italian joints in San Francisco and I can't wait to go back!
author: Albert H.

description:
The pasta is handmade.
Upside: super delicious (the pasta pictures is a little spicy) and the texture is super chewy and different from most machine made pastas.
Downside: took a bit long so I recommend order an appetizer or salad.
author: Lin Z.

description: Wow. This place is loud but they make delicious food. My wife and I split two dishes: their version of a Caesar salad and a fresh pasta dish. The salad was made with perfect leaves of butter lettuce, whole white anchovies, and crispy fried capers. Genius and so tasty. The pasta was tagliatelle with chanterelles, cipolini onions, and this marvelous oregano variety that tasted minty. Perfect. Service was excellent and friendly. Waitstaff were very tattooed. :)
author: Esther L.

description:
4.5 STARS

A: "So what have you been up to these days?
Me: "Nothing much really...just going out to eat dinner with friends and going home afterwards to watch Lifetime movies. You?"

A: Gurl, me too! Well, except the Lifetime movies part. I'm usually in bed my 9 pm!"
Me: "OMG - ME TOO!"

Ahhh, what a change from 5 years ago when we would have answered, "I don't know...I blacked out after the 10th shot and went home with David, or was it Chris?" Hi, dad! Just kidding...

These days, instead of spending $$$ at the bar and losing all my morals, I rather spend that money on a nice meal catching up with friends. Except a "nice" dinner with drinks in SF can cost $100+ and may require a McD run afterwards because the portions are made for ants. 

a Mano has changed all of that. 

From the owner of Beretta, Belga, Delarosa, and Super Duper, a Mano is a Modern Italian restaurant serving handmade pastas at very SF wallet friendly prices. My friend and ordered one app, one pizza, two pastas, one entrée, two desserts and one cocktail each, and our bill was $112 pre-tip. Ok, saying a $112 dinner tab is reasonable may sound ridiculous but this would have easily cost $160-$180 elsewhere in SF. Hello, $28 plate of [appetizer portion] pasta and $17 cocktails!

a Mano is walk-in only. To avoid a long wait, come before the dinner rush; 6 pm on the weekends. You cannot get on the waitlist until your entire party is there so unless all your friends are all punctual, it's probably not the best place for a large group dinner. 

While waiting to be seated, my friend and I grabbed drinks at their bar. I ordered the Sirena: Vodka, aperol, grapefruit, calabrian chili and she ordered the Wallbanger: Vodka, pineapple, mango, Galliano ($12): http://bit.ly/2qJu5d4. Loved the Sirena. It was well-balanced and citrusy with a mild kick. My friend's Wallbanger was on the fruitier, sweeter side. If you can't find seats at the bar, Anina and Brass Tacks are just several doors away from a Mano. 

Everything looked great on the menu so it was hard deciding on what to order. After some debate, we decided on the following:

*Tuscan Duck Liver Mousse w/ kumquat mostarda ($9): 4.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2qjNMHe
Deliciously rich and creamy, not too gamey. I wanted to lick the saucer clean. 

*Mostaccioli w/ braised tripe ($15): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/2pNLgGb
Our least favorite dish of the night. While the tubular pasta was perfectly al-dente and the honeycomb tripe was melt-in-your mouth tender, it was a very bland dish. 

*Tagliatelle w/ pesto, english peas, fava, pine nuts ($15): 5 STARS
 http://bit.ly/2pCKlwc
One of the best pasta dishes I've ever had! Super flavorful and great varying layers of texture. The ribbons of pasta had a great toothsome chew. The crown of cheese shavings added a nice pop of saltiness while the toasted pine nuts added a great crunch. 

*Asparagus, green garlic, spring onion, lemon, caciocavallo ($15): 4.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2pPmAMD
Crackly crust, stretchy cheese, oniony, and lightly citrusy. Simple yet ohh soo good. 

*Nightly Special: Porchetta w/ spigarello, red onion, salsa verde ($22): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/2ri8O6v
A carniwhore's delight, the porchetta skin was crunchy and umptuous. The herb studded loin was tasty but a tad dry. The spigarello's subtle bitterness perfectly cut through all the porky richness.  

*Dessert: http://bit.ly/2rj4apD
--Buttermilk Panna Cotta w/ strawberries, biscotti ($9): 4 STARS
--Nutella Sundae w/ fior di latte, amaretti cookie, whipped cream ($10): 4.5 STARS

We couldn't decide on one dessert so we ordered two. I'm not a chocolate person but the Nutella sundae was my favorite. The nutella and fior di latte ice cream was rich, dense, and not overly sweet which I appreciated. Simple but super satisfying. 

Our server was super friendly and cheerful but she was spread thin. It was a packed house on Saturday night so it was hard to track her down at times (not her fault). Luckily, they have a great team and other staff jumped in to take our food order. For opening week, the kitchen operated like a well-oiled machine and we were never left waiting for long between courses. Towards the end of dinner, one of the hostesses noticed us looking around for our server and jumped in to take our dessert order. Awesome teamwork! Thank you for being proactive and observant. 

Located on the ground floor of a new luxury condo building, a Mano is very sleek, trendy, and hip. While it was a full house, it wasn't deafening like most SF hot spots. It was bustling but we could easily have a conversation without shouting across the table at each other. Great casual date place! 

Parking has become a nightmare in almost every part of SF so take uber/lyft here especially on performance nights. 

a Mano is one of the best new restaurants that I've been to this year.

Hooray for top-notch quality eats that won't leave your wallet nekkid!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Because there are SO many restaurants in San Francisco, I find myself reluctant to re-visit even the really good ones.
