But upon leaving a Mano, I thought to myself, "I would happily come back here tomorrow and order the same exact items all over again." This is the sign of a truly impressive experience.

We didn't have reservations (I don't think a Mano does them), but were able to get a comfy spot at the communal table rather quickly on a Sunday evening. Despite being seated in this space, our service was prompt, thorough, and attentive the whole meal through. Our courses were PERFECTLY paced - despite the lack of effort on our own part to plan that - and we somehow ordered just the perfect amount of food.

How was the food? Every dish was delightful, but in recap:

- The lemon-chili cauliflower app: flavorful, and somehow managed feel both substantial and healthy at the same time. Just the right amount of spicy. Would highly recommend! 
- The squid app: nicely grilled, not chewy, also felt tasty/substantial over a bed of chickpeas and a nice romesco sauce
- The funghi pizza: tasty and well-done, though the least remarkable of all the dishes we tried (we ended up bringing a couple slices home)
- The chestnut pasta: OMG. I was reluctant to order this one, because ... what IS chestnut pasta? Have I ever eaten chestnuts, or is that just something you sing about at Christmas? But I'm so glad we ordered this dish, because it may well be the tastiest pasta I've ever had. It was light but creamy, cheesy, perfectly toothy ... I could have eaten two bowls to myself. 
- The squid ink pasta: Yum, yum. Garlic, lemon, olive oil and super well-made pasta, again perfectly cooked.
- Nutella sundae: This is another one I was hesitant to order, based on the (detailed) description our waitress gave, including a type of mozzarella as part of the sundae. I couldn't get my head around it, but that didn't matter when the sundae arrived. It was elegant, familiar and comforting but also had unique twists at the same time.The whole thing disappeared. 

Beyond the food, the small details (delicious wine, good recommendations, the perfect size and weight of cutlery, clean bathrooms, overall ambiance) put a Mano over the top. I don't give five stars lightly!
author: Catie F.

description:
Food: 4/5
Space: 4/5
Service: 4/5

Super popular Italian spot in Hayes Valley...and for good reason. Love their handmade pastas and pizzas. Finding good Italian food in SF can be a challenge and a Mano is definitely one of the better spots. Despite it always being packed, the restaurant is still comfortable and I'm a big fan of the ambience and decor. As long as the table next to you isn't being to loud/obnoxious you'll have a pleasant experience. Waitstaff is patient and friendly, even during busy times.
author: Derrick F.

description: A friend really likes this place and took us here.  We two did have a pleasant dining experience when we were there.  But later that night, we two had food poisoning and felt nauseous, got stomachache and had diarrhea.   We carefully examined what we ate from the day previously, and after ruling out the previous meals, we were pretty sure it's something we ate here, unfortunately.  For me, I only had salads, the night special (a pork dish), and a dessert (chocolate mousse).  We didn't know which dish caused it, and haven't had food poisoning for years although we eat out regularly.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
4.5 stars for the delicious housemade pasta.

WAIT: Came on a Saturday for dinner and note that they open at 5pm but people start lining up well before that.  We stopped by at 4:30pm with no one in line, walked into another store and came back around 4:50 and there was a huge line waiting to get in.  We were able to get in with the first "wave" with some seats still available after us but it's still crazy! If you get here by 6, you might have to wait 1 hr 1/2 for people to finish within the first wave. 

ATMOSPHERE: Reminds me of North Italia in LA with a modern Italian restaurant feel, open seating outside with heat lamps, a semi-open kitchen and a high table top area that faces both the inside and the outside.  Overall, dimly lit makes it a nice dinner with friends, family or for a date.

FOOD: They make their pasta in house and fresh and you can tell.  I would suggest that and maybe a pizza to share as their pasta dishes are smaller in size.

MALFADINE DUCK PASTA - malfadine is like the ends of lasagna with curves in long strips.  If you like duck, you'll enjoy this pasta although the duck wasn't super gamey and didn't have a very strong flavor.  The dish is light and slightly buttery/creamy but no heavy sauce.  I liked the currants which give it a sweet bite to it like you're eating raisins with your pasta.  Seems odd, but tastes good.  I loved that the pasta was fresh and chewy (al dente) and not overcooked or bland.

SQUID INK PASTA - very good squid ink pasta with a good chew to it but beware that this is spicy! I can't handle spicy and it was bad for me and my husband can handle spicy and he was still saying it was a little too spicy.  Not a huge portion but if you have appetizers you should be OK.

FUNGHI PIZZA - white pizza with pretty good flavor, the cheese was a little too mild for me though.  The crust is very bubbly and thicker but when you bite into it, it's more like a cracker/harder and not quite as chewy as I would have liked.  Thin pizza.

CAULIFLOWER - pretty good, a little more on the tangy side and fairly "saucy" but still tasty.

Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner here so if you want to give it a try come early to get in line or expect to wait 1hr +.
author: Brittany T.

description:
Why not five stars you ask? Because I didn't try the pizza; or pasta. So what type of a raging lunatic would go to an obvious pizza/pasta place and not order it? What type of a self respecting Elite Yelper are you?! 

Now that I've gotten that out of the way, I will meekly defend myself by saying that I unfortunately started my low carb week after too much feasting of late and this dinner engagement had to suffer my poor timing. 

However, my companion highly vouched for the margherita pizza, and she's an expert. That's usually the pizza she orders and she's been to many good joints around town. I had the meatballs and squid, which were both quite delightful. Staff was super friendly and coming early on a weeknight paid off as we didn't have to wait for a table (meaning at 6pm on a Wednesday).

Loved the ambience and I was definitely drooling over other people's plates of pasta (want to try the pesto one soooo badly). Will be back again to do just that.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
New modern, hip Italian restaurant in Hayes opened by restaurateur Adriano Paganini (you may know him from his other ventures: Beretta, Lolinda, Starbelly, Super Duper). The focus here is pasta, but they have other tasty antipasti and salads if you don't want the carbo load. We went during the last day of their soft opening - there are definitely some things that can be worked on but I see lots of potential for this restaurant. The service was friendly and fast for the most part, and the ambiance is nice but casual. What we ordered for 3 girls, in order from my favorite to least.

MIXED SPRING VEG SALAD, PISTACHIO, SHERRY VINAIGRETTE 5*- My friend wanted to order this, it doesn't seem impressive on the menu, just looks like a plain old salad (they def need to work on their marketing). It was hands down my favorite of the night! Super fresh snap peas, arugula, avocado, pistachio, and carrot shavings, oh my! I would highly recommend this!!

TUSCAN DUCK LIVER MOUSSE W KUMQUAT 4*- Oh baby, I love me some foie and this did not disappoint. Super fatty and creamy mousse topped with a citrus element to cut through the fat. So simple but so delicious.

TAGLIATELLE W PESTO, PEAS, FAVA, PINENUTS 3* - The pasta was cooked to perfect al dente in my opinon (my friend thought it was a tad overcooked), and sauce was tasty. Our pasta was significantly under salted, and needed a lot more salt which all 3 of us agreed on. This dish has potential to be a 4* dish.

CAULIFLOWER, LEMON, CHILI, BAGNA CAUDA 3* - Roasted cauliflower with nice flavors, it was good but not amazing. You can make it at home.

ROASTED ASPARAGUS, FONDUTA, PROSCIUTTO 2.5* - Unimpressive and unoriginal. 5 asparagus for $10, pass.

GEM LETTUCE SALAD, FENNEL, RADISH, ANCHOVY, RICOTTA, CAPERS SALAD 2.5* - This dish sounded super luxurious and tasty, but unfortunately it fell flat and was just alright. Would not order again.

Overall, I think a Mano has the potential to be a 4*. The ingredients are fresh, and it's an easy place to order family style and try a bit of everything (as the portions are not very big). They forgot our pasta and was reminded 2x and our pasta was very under salted which is a huge no no. The menu needs to be more solid as there were some very impressive dishes that we tried and thoroughly enjoyed, some that had careless mistakes and could be great, and others that fell flat and are not even comparable. I would consider coming back and giving a Mano another try once they've been up and running for a while.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I love this place, but I wish the portions were a tad bit bigger.

The bucatini is the best I've had in a while.  The noodles were cooked to perfection and the sauce was flavourful. The duck liver mouse was excellent, but 5 pieces of crostini wasn't enough.  We had to ask for extra twice and each time they only gave us 2 pieces.  

I got there at 6pm and it wasn't crowded at all.  6:45-7pm rolls around, and there's a line and people waiting outside.  Tables along the window are seated so close, you can hear the conversation next to you.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Spicy spaghetti with pork cubes is ok. I think it's not too salty but maybe because of the spices.
I wish the pork cubes were bigger, less salty, and fried more (crispy edges). Serving size is a bit small for the price. 

Their home made soda was good. Great ambience and good customer service.
author: Ariene S.

description:
Great food and not a ridiculously long wait? We must've been lucky that day! a Mano is a great place to go if you are looking for that elusive combination of great food and great cocktails.

I was fortunate to be dining with a party of four for lunch and we went family style so I was able to try a lot of things. The pasta dishes are amazing and housemade. The pizza was delicious. And the salad? Might've been one of my favorite combinations (it was so simple but well put together). Everything was so good!

Cocktails are also great! And can be quite strong. 

Service was excellent and the restaurant has a clean/modern/casual atmosphere. Would definitely come back here if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Cindy L.

description: Very good quality and taste at this newer Hayes Valley Italian Restaurant. The cocktail list is also very good.  We had the cauliflower for appetizer and it was excellent. The pizza was also very good. As good as Del Fina if not better.
author: John L.

description:
We stumbled upon this place as we were walking around Hayes. It's another masterpiece of Ariano Paganini ( Lolinda, El Techo, Belga) 
The service was fantastic from start to finish. We ordered a few anti pastis ( squid, cauliflower and asparagus) and they were all incredibly great! ( All gluten free and light) 
If I get to pick my two most favorite, I think I will pick the cauliflower and asparagus. 

As for the dessert, we shared the yummy panna cotta. 
For the price, the service and the quality of food, we will for sure return.
author: Ghazal P.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend on a Friday. We arrived a little after 5 when they opened, and most of the restaurant was still pretty empty. Given that this restaurant is pretty popular, I was afraid it would fill up quickly after opening, but fortunately that wasn't the case.

We were quickly seated and given a menu. I started with the Aviazione ($12), which was gin, maraschino, lemon, violet, and soda. I was expecting it to taste more cherry-like due to the maraschino but any cherry taste was completely overpowered by the lemon. I wasn't the biggest fan of my drink, but I tried a sip of my friend's Wallbanger (vodka, mango mint, galliano) and that was very sweet and more up my alley. I'll have to get that for myself next time I come.

For food, we started with focaccia with an olive tapenade ($5) as we wanted something lighter before pasta. I loved the focaccia itself as that was very light and airy, but I stayed far away from the olive tapenade as I'm not a fan of olives. Also the focaccia was overly salty where they sprinkled too much salt and I couldn't imagine eating it with another savory spread.

For our mains, we opted to do family style and shared two pastas: the bucatini all' amatriciana ($14) and the tagliatelle ($15). They were both really good. The bucatini came piping hot to our table in a delicious tomato sauce. The noodles were nice and thick and each bite was very satisfying. The tagliatelle came in a pesto sauce and felt much lighter than the tagiatelle. The pesto was refreshing and the tagliatelle had a slight crunch to it when chewing that I typically don't experience with pastas. I'd say I liked the pasta in the bucatini more but the pesto sauce more with the tagliatelle.

One minor note - I asked for both pastas with cheese on the side since I don't like cheese on anything other than pizzas. Weird I know, but our server was super nice and said they could accommodate my request. Therefore I was kind of annoyed when both pastas came out to see that they were both topped with their respective cheeses! I ended up having to eat around the cheesy parts on top. 

Despite being stuffed, we opted for dessert and finished the meal with a panna cotta topped with strawberries. Pretty standard but it was nice to end the meal on a sweet note. 

With tax and tip it was a little over $40 per person.
author: Dianna H.

description: If the pizza is any indication of how good the rest of the food is, then thumbs up. I ordered the salsiccia (sp?) and added arugula.
author: Kirsten F.

description: Love the ambience the service but the food husband thought was too gourmet for him and my pizza they forgot to put cheese on it. The drink pretty good and the price regular San Francisco's so for a busy weekend was okay after look around I guess I should had order their salad because looks delicious and a lot of people ordered
author: carla a.

description:
An absolute gem in Hayes Valley.

Can't go wrong with any of the pizzas or pastas, but my favorites are the salsiccia pizza and the rigatoni with pork sugo. The bucatini is also incredible.

For those that like duck liver mousse, that's also a win.

Happy to finally have a casual restaurant in Hayes Valley that delivers again and again. Looking forward to many more leisurely lunches and dinners with friends here.
author: Alex N.

description: Pasta was very fresh and al dente but almost ruined by an over-salted butter sauce.
author: Dennis W.

description: I love this restaurant. Every time we're in SFO we come here at least once. They don't take reservations and often there is a short line that forms before opening time for dinner at 5 p.m. They let us sit outside with our golden retriever pup so that's a bonus. We always get the Focaccia and we always get the cauliflower dish because both are decadent and incredible. If they have a nectarine salad on the menu don't miss it because it's also to die for. All of their pastas are fantastic and we have tried many of them. They make their pasta fresh in house. We have always had great service as well whether sitting at the bar outside or inside. I know that this place is very popular and fills up quickly.
author: Desiree G.

description:
Oh holy moly what a piece of pasta heaven.

Had the wonderful pleasure of dining here on New Years Eve and oh what food joy it was. EVERY SINGLE ITEM was delicious, full of unique flavors and modestly priced. The five stars is well deserved. It is quite difficult in my opinion for a restaurant to capture all elements of a great dining experience but this certainly did. And on New Years Eve of all nights, they did not price gauge with an outrageous prix fixe menu which was a huge bonus.

For starters, we had the cauliflower and the beet arugula salad with hazelnuts. AMAZING. I have never had such perfectly fresh beets, and the combination with the gorgonzola and hazelnuts was just perfect. The entrees were straight out of food heaven. We had the nightly special which was a duck yolk ravioli and I havenever had such an amazing piece of work of a pasta. It was the star of the night amidst every other selection which was awesome. Our other entrée was the mafladine braised duck leg and it too was so flavorful and hearty with perfectly tender duck (which I am a sucker of duck). And the dessert, was just perfect-- the chocolate budino with sea salt and the panna cotta were both perfectly light, and sweet.

I left the restaurant feeling satisfied without feeling overly stuffed . And a $100 ticket for a three course meal for 2 people on New Years Eve was even better. The fact that they didn't take reservations and we could be seated within 30 minutes on New years was the icing on the cake of a great experience. Highly recommend
author: Lahiji F.

description:
Arrived on a Thursday night around 6pm, and the place was busy. Inside was more or less full, but there were several free tables outside, so there was no wait* (unless you wanted to sit inside).

*TIP - if your whole party isn't present, they won't seat you.

Everything on the menu sounded great, but I ultimately tried the monterey squid, ceci beans, castelvetrano olives, romanesco antipasti and the tagliatelle with hen of the wood mushrooms and kale for my main dish.

The portions are a bit small, but beyond that I enjoyed our meal. With the antipasti, I initially thought the olives might overpower everything else, but it ended up being present but not overpowering, and the beans had a lot of flavor in them too.

With the tagliatelle, the pasta was al dante and the mushrooms added nice texture and had a flavor of its own. The sauce was great too, and the kale added another texture to the dish (and also made it feel a bit lighter?)

Because the place was so busy, service was a bit on the slow side (though the servers there were really nice!), but I wasn't in a rush anyway.

Overall, had a solid experience here and would recommend.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Was so happy to discover this place! It gets a little crowded on weekends so make sure to get there early, the wait is not so bad and you can sit at the bar and sip a cocktail. The food is AMAZING!! The focaccia and olive tapenade is addictive, you can't go wrong with any of the pizza's or pastas. It's all made fresh from scratch and the staff is very friendly. The bucatini is a must, I order it every time I'm there.

Definitely my go-to spot for Italian goodness!
author: Naya A.

description:
Absolutely epic meal here! I have to caveat that I was 3 days into a sugar detox when I had dinner here so I had only eaten the blandest food for that stretch prior but I still think it was epic!  My dinner mate agreed as well.

The marinated olives - strong.  The cauliflower with lemon, chili, bagna cauda - epic flavor.  The heirloom tomato salad - divine.  The chicken polpettine with spicy tomato sauce - that's a spicy meatball!  My friend's pasta with sausage (which I could try because of this sugar detox) smelled epic, too.

Great buzz, vibe, and lots of chatter in this bustling, sprawling venue.  Fun place to check out, we snuck in and grabbed seats at the bar and got great service regardless.
author: Saminda W.

description: The service was great, we had a great server and she made us feel great. The food though is like other places in sf, low quality covered up by oil and butter. Don't fall for it. It's heavy heavy on the carbs. The problem is that everyone in SF has forgotten how great things were before and that a place like a mano would not cut it, the food just is easily forgettable.
author: 73and9 7.

description:
4.5 stars. No reservations. Come before 5:30 PM with no wait. Tables are small and very close together. Food was excellent. Everything we ordered was super good. 

Got the cauliflower, pasta, mushroom pizza and every day they have a different special. Since we came on a Tuesday, it was short ribs. Super yummy! Will be back.
author: Karen H.

description: The fusili verdi is the best pasta (or food in general) I've eaten in a long time, and I'll definitely be returning! Really busy on a Saturday evening, but the staff were consistently friendly and attentive.
author: Alice Z.

description: Have been here twice now, ordered different dishes every time. Have tried pastas, pizza, meaty appetizers, veggie appetizers, desserts. Every item has been delicious. Rounded up from 4.5 stars.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Food was great.  Atmosphere was excellent.  Service wasn't great, but it seemed like our server was maybe new or not very good.
Pizza and pasta dish were perfect for splitting. Cauliflower app was superb.
author: Matt C.

description:
This was sadly disappointing, to keep it short the pairing was off the food was unbalanced and wasn't timed correctly....treat all guest even later ones like they are your
 first... bottom line....also dont display product boxes its tacky for the bar.
author: Jason M.

description:
I had been waiting so long to try this place as every time I came it was a Saturday night with a 2 hour wait but I finally got a table with my boyfriend on a lively, Thursday night! Outside there is a row of tables next to fire heaters and funky lights, definitely a good vibe while on the inside the bar is eclectic as there are neon lights behind every drink. My New York City roots always leave me looking for a trendy dinner place with good food and this was it.

We decided to go all out and started off with the fontina arancini which was fried risotto balls with fontina cheese, and sea salt focaccia with olive tapenade. The balls were not oily at all and very hot and steaming. It was super flavorful and the cheese didn't overpower. My boyfriend loved the olive tapenade with the house made bread as it was toasted and warm as well. We split the pork rigatoni and tagliatelle with mushrooms and kale. The rigatoni meat sauce was spicy and flavorful, SO GOOD. I didn't care much for the tagliatelle  as it was a butter sauce, and lacking some flavor though still a solid dish. We paired this with some Pinot Noir carafe size (in between a glass and bottle gave us each 2 glasses) so perfect to be tipsy with our food! Shout out to our waiter Kyle who was so attentive and very pleasant to have conversation with. Will definitely be back hurrr
author: Kaitna S.

description:
Had lunch here the other day (finally) with 3 colleagues.
We had:
Fried cauliflower - quite possibly the BEST cauliflower dish ever
Chicken polpettine - very good 
Margherita Pizza - just ok 
Tagliatelle bolognese - outstanding
Bucatini w spicy tomato sauce - very good
Campanelle w chestnut sauce - interesting
Rigatoni w clams and garlic broccoli sauce - outstanding

Fresh made pasta is a nice treat.  We could see one of the chefs making more pasta by hand all throughout lunch.

Service was also excellent.

Overall a very enjoyable meal.  Will definitely be back.
author: Lewis C.

description: If you come here there are probably two major decisions you'll make...Pizza, or.... Pasta.  I went with the pizza and now I live in regret everyday.  Not that the pizza was bad or anything, but just that the pasta looked so much better when everyone else got their food.  So, dont be like me, dont live in regret.
author: Vince L.

description:
Was excited to come here but left unsatisfied. 

Came here with a group of 4 on a busy Thursday night, but did not mind the wait since the reviews and the pictures on Yelp looked so good. Service was good, but I felt like the food was lacking. 

Nightly special was the hanger steak with bone marrow, I expected a flavorful medium rare steak but received a medium well steak. It was tough, chewy, underwhelming, and I could have made a better steak. The bone marrow was just bone marrow, but the side veggies were good. I didn't really care for the carrots, but the roasted potatoes were crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside, the greens were seasoned nicely and tasty.

Margherita Pizza+Salsiccia was the most flavorful thing we ordered, crisp, light cheesyness, and basil-y, but while some slices were crispy and delicious, other slices were super soggy underneath and were limp and gloopy.  

Rigatoni with Pork Sugo was okay, fresh pasta was a plus but sauce was bland and nothing special. 

Spaghettini with Clams was lemony and fresh, not much else to say.

If you're looking for a cocktail the Wallbanger is yummy.

Portions are all on the small side, we were all still hungry after finishing our meals.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Posting the 2-star review, since the opportunity to improve (at lunch, specifically) is quite real.

I'm a huge fan of sister restaurant Beretta and have enjoyed Starbelly quite a bit too.  Since a Mano opened in happening Hayes Valley, I worried that it would be a bit too much of a cash grab and not push itself to far to provide an exceptional customer experience.

DINNER in June -- my pregnant wife and I stopped by for an early dinner and a Mano significantly exceeded my expectations.  We ordered the fontina arancini and summer squash pizza and both were as great as the food at Beretta.   Decent service and drinks too.  Left feeling happy about the restaurant and could see myself returning.  4.25 stars/5

LUNCH in July -- I really wish I wrote the date down so that management could track down who was working this day -- as they definitely need to improve lunch service.  We arrived mid-week around 1:45pm with a newborn baby and our dog, so we asked to sit outside.  The host did a good job at getting us into the shade, which is a little difficult in their sunny front outdoor area.  Aside from that EVERYTHING, was too slow.  My fears of a Mano being a cash grab seemed to be real (at least for lunch).  Waiter was nice, but did not come by very often (and again, we had a 2 week old baby who didn't need to eat for another hour and a half -- we could tolerate semi-slow but not this level of slow for a mid-week lunch!).  I think most of the slow pace of the meal came from the kitchen.  We got the strawberry and arugula salad (very good, but would still be good if your D team culinary staff were working that day) and the chicken polpettine (way underseasoned! we probably would have been sent it back had we not already sensed the slow pace of food coming out to everyone else around us).  Our original order around 2pm included the Summer Squash pizza and the Margherita pizza.  Around 3pm, we still hadn't received our pizzas, our waiter came by to say that the kitchen was at last call if we wanted to order anything else (but did not acknowledge the excessive wait for the Neapolitan pizzas we had ordered an hour ago).  Having a birds eye view of the restaurant/kitchen, I did see a line cook starting to work out pizza dough a little after 3p (nearly everyone around us had ordered pasta, so I was pretty certain it was ours).  As he was working out the dough, I noted that the dough was getting a really wide circumference and then I saw the line cook actively grimace as I think he noticed a tear or the dough becoming too thin towards the middle.  Instead of chucking the dough (sunk cost of less than $1 for the flour) and restarting, he continued to make the pizza (probably since he was worried since we ordered so long ago -- but never do this -- don't make us wait and then deliver us an inferior product).  We received the Summer Squash pizza about 10 minutes after I saw him start working out the dough (which felt long for a Neapolitan pizza like this, with no one else ahead of us in the queue).  The seasoning/flavor/temperature balance of the pizza was way inferior to the one that we had ordered for dinner a few weeks prior.  The worst part, however, was that there was a large section of incredibly thin crust towards the middle, the majority of it burnt through at the bottom.  This is a fairly junior varsity mistake for a pizza maker, and again, the line cook should have tossed the dough and restarted with new dough once he saw this error.  Margherita was better but nothing special.

So, to summarize, a Mano needs to improve its lunch service if they don't want it to be considered a pure cash grab.  When they announced lunch service, I got really excited since I'm off on paternity leave and eating outside seemed easy enough to do with a newborn.  However, it clearly seemed that a Mano was using this time not to serve their lunch patrons, but instead to grab some revenue during the day as they attend to their prep work for dinner service.  Very disappointing indeed for a first lunch out with a baby -- a baby which ended up crying all the way home after a nearly 2 hour midweek lunch pushed her mealtime back a half hour (damn, this story somehow ended with a crying baby...my apologies for that one).
author: Scott F.

description:
I went here for a girls night out on a Thursday. I tried to go the previous week on a Friday night and wait was close to 2 hours so we abandoned ship. I was excited to try again and happy we were able to get seated outside which was great with the heat lamps. 

Between 4 of us, we split a few dishes including 2 pizzas and a pasta. The broccoli rabe pizza was definitely a highlight with big chunks of burrata. The margarita pizza was a solid choice. The pizza is very traditional Italian style with quality crust. 

The price was extremely reasonable too. Between the 4 of us with 3 mains, one app and a bottle of red it was $32 /person with tip. Going back asap!
author: Grace A.

description: Good food, good ambiance, great location in hayes. Also a nice place to go by oneself and do people watching by the window.
author: Gina S.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for awhile and finally did and it did not disappoint!  Be prepared you will have to wait, my friend and I went on a Wednesday night at 7pm and waited for a half hour.

This place has handmade pasta, you can see them make it in the kitchen.    It feels like real Italian when you are dining there.  We ordered the arachini, clam pasta, and the pizza with broccoli rabe.  If you love fried food, get the arachini.  Fried to perfection and the sauce was excellent with it.  The clam pasta I thought was nothing too special but the noodles were nice.  I loved the pizza, great crust and the ingredients on top were delicious.

I definitely want to come back to try a few other different pastas.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I'm worried at how much I like this place. Promise I'm not exaggerating it's absolutely amazing. My new favorite Italian in SF hands down! Located in one of my personal favorite neighborhoods its a beautiful space and has a great layout. As it's very new the lines are quite long but I don't expect them to die down any time soon bc this place will easily have everyone hooked.

It's the perfect place for a nice dinner with girlfriends, place to take family/friends visiting, and of course makes for a great date night spot!!

As others mentioned its by the brilliant minds of those from Berrata Delarosa and Lolinda so they know what they're doing.

The pasta is truly some of the best i've had in SF.
author: Hetal P.

description: Wow.  This was even mo betta than the first time.  For starters, we did the fried smelt which was so light and crisp with a nice aioli dip, the pan fried cauliflower, duck mousse with cherry mostarda, and Monterey Bay Squid and the Gem Lettuce salad.  My favorites were the cauliflower and duck mousse but all were excellent.  Then on to the Salsiccia and Bianca pizzas, Pork Sugo Rigatoni, Tagliatelle, seafood Spaghettini and egg plant paccherri and finally the salmon fish special.  Wow.. this seems like a lot for eight of us but it was just the right amount.  All plates were shared so it was like a tasting of pizza and pasta.  My favorites were the egg plant paccherri and salmon.  The egg plant and capers was incredible but paccherri was a little too al dente for my taste.  But who am I to question a Mano who makes the best pasta I've ever had.  Wine would have been nice, but a couple of Kolsch was a perfect pairing for me.  Too make the dining experience even mo betta, Emily our server was excellent.  Go with a group of friends so you can give the entire menu a go.
author: Wayne K.

description: This is a great Italian restaurant in Hayes Valley! Great and super fast service and really good food! I highly recommend the Tagliatelle al ragu and the foccacia bread with olive tapenade. Everything was cooked fresh and the portion sizes were perfect!
author: Piyali B.

description:
Second time here and it was better than the first. Have you ever been to NYC in the fall and the air is a bit cooler but people are out and about walking and shopping on a Friday night? Hayes valley and eating on the patio reminds me of that. A friend pointed that out and I have to agree! There are bars and boutique shops all around and the people give a cool chill vibe that just makes it all that much better! 

a Mano's location in the heart of HV is a great location whether you're out shopping or just getting the night started. There are no reservations but the wait isn't too long. We were lucky they had an opening. Right away and we decided to sit outside. 

Patio has great heat lamps and the tables are set further in on the sidewalk so you're not in anyone's way and it doesn't feel cramped. Service is great as well and our server knew the menu well. 

Ok on to the food...the pastas change depending on the season so your menu may be slightly different. All the pasta is handmade daily and it definitely shows. the bucatini with pancetta and agnolotti with brown butter and sage were on point. Perfectly cooked and delicious to the last bite!  We also ordered the cauliflower as an a starter and that didn't disappoint either. 

All in all you can't go wrong here. From the vibe of the area to the good food that's being made here, you'll have a good time regardless. Bars are right next door to carry the evening on or the new Salt n Straw shop down the street for the sweet tooth in you!
author: Andrew S.

description: My wife and i had supper there recently and sat outside . We had a great server but our 1 entree was cold and the portion is small for the cost. We would probably not return but the place was very busy while we were there
author: Ron C.

description:
Got there on a Sunday at 4:40pm, (they don't open doors until 5pm), so we waited because we heard good things about this place.  The dishes are hit or miss.  A great shame is with their house-made pastas and good fresh sauces, many of the dishes were over-salted, so unnecessary.

Fontina Arancini:  4 golf ball sized fried rice balls in a good Fontina cheese sauce.  The outside of the arancini were really crisp and had a strong, comforting fried taste, but this appetizer is just one dimensional in that it is just pretty much the fried taste.  

Chicken Polettine with spicy tomato sauce:  3 2 1/2 inch chicken meatballs with 3 small pieces of toasted bread.  The toasted bread was good, not too hard/burnt.  The meatballs were so light with specks of green parsley and red inside and the spicy tomato sauce was so fresh and simple and not that spicy.  But it was just too salty, I couldn't get past this.  

Focaccia:  A table next to us heard me say the meatballs were too salty and said to us, "so is the focaccia."  She wasn't kidding because I saw that they ripped the tops off of the focaccia and left them on their plates.

Bucatini all' amatriciana: (hollow spaghetti in a tomato bacon sauce):  The portion was smaller than I expected, (especially looking at my buddy's pasta plate).  O.k., I know that bacon and pancetta are salty, but they should have enough salt in them, there was no need for the kitchen to add more.

Torchetti with lamb shoulder:  The portion of this pasta dish was twice the size of mine.  I don't eat lamb but had a bite of this pasta and it was beautiful.  This dish sounds heavy but the pasta and capers made it so refreshingly light and there was a good amount of shredded lamb.  This dish was perfect, (if only I ate lamb).

Desserts were o.k., but I would pass and fill up on the antipasti instead.  I'd only come back if my dining friend wanted to come here again, (which he will because of course he had the perfect dish).
author: Johnnie N.

description:
Didn't have a wait on a Wednesday night.

Food was okay to good, one of their major selling points is the pasta is homemade although my boyfriend said he couldn't taste the difference between store bought and the one he ate.

Other highlights include my chair being continuously bumped by servers throughout my dinner and grand finale of a server dropping a utensil on my back...

Space is nice for a date night - the ambiance is right and Hayes Valley is a good neighborhood. Wouldn't recommend driving here.
author: Mimi T.

description:
This is our first visit and won't be the last because we plan to come back. In another word, we love the food there. 

First of all, Be prepared that you might need to wait 30 to 45 minutes for seats for party of two. More people, the wait time may be longer. Good thing that you can sit at the bar to have a drinks while you are waiting if the bar is not full. They are very busy. But they will text you when seats are available. 

Secondly, let's talk about the food: 

We ordered nightly special($25): red wine braised short ribs. MUST TRY! They are very good, surprisesily good. 

The pasta, tagliatelle ($15) tasted very very good. 
Another must try item too. 

Tuscan duck liver mousse ($11), we really like it the way how they mixed the strawberries. Perfect balanced! 

Cocktails Sirena ($12) was very good! 

Overall, They have excellent customer service and yummy food! I hope our next return will be having the same experience or better.
author: Meichelle L.

description: Enjoyed my visit at A Mano, and luckily didn't have to wait! Arrived not long after they opened for dinner on a Saturday night and sat outside, which was great. The cauliflower was actually one of the highlights- super delicious! We also had the summer squash pizza, margherita pizza, bucatini pasta, and pesto pasta. The summer squash and pesto pasta were good, but would highly recommend the margherita pizza and bucatini pasta!
author: Ali W.

description:
I'm not a fan of pasta but this place changed my opinion. 

I stumbled across this place one late night after work and finishing some errands downtown. Didn't feel like settling for crap mediocre fast food and said screw it let me try this pasta since its hand made fresh it might taste better than the usual. Sure enough it was great!

I went in wanting the spaghettini with clams after reading the street side menu. It was 45 minutes prior to closing so I went in quick and was seated. Unfortunately they were out of clams so I went for the tagliatelle. It came out and was cooked very well and had an excellent texture and light tasting pasta. Pasta has a tendency to make me feel very full and heavy after eating it but this had me feeling great. Definitely going to return earlier next time to get the spaghettini. 

Nice clean modern decor inside. Nothing too "try hard" or awkwardly over complicated stuff which is very relaxing to me an a place I can enjoy coming back again and again.
author: Yosof R.

description:
This is a cute place in Hayes Valley! I love how spacious the interior is, and that they have a glass counter so you can watch them handmake the pasta! I definitely got distracted during lunch a few times watching the chefs hand pull the pasta...

I tried a salad (wild arugula, chioggia beets, gorgonzola, hazelnut, pickled shallot ) and the chestnut pasta here. The salad was really good, we got the large portion (which was still quite small, haha) and finished it all. The nuts were toasted and added a great crunch to the salad.

The pasta tasted really fresh, and the seasoning/sauce was sooooo good. I actually don't really know why I thought it was so good, but it just was so satisfying to eat. And the texture was just right and chewy, not too soft or hard. 

One thing to note is that the portions are definitely smaller here. The large salad alone or the pasta alone would not fill a hungry person up, so if you're coming on a really empty stomach, order some sides in addition to a main.
author: Theresa L.

description:
*** In Short ***

Yet another carborrific win for the neighborhood!

*** In Depth ***

As if it wasn't enough that Chez Maman, with its carbonara, and Corridor, with its multitude of pasta, were already in the area, but now a Mano is throwing down on top of all of that?! My Hayes-y stomach will never be the same again.

Coming on a Monday night around 7pm, we were lucky enough to be seated within about 20min, since we'd been hearing about their 45-60min waits. If you really dislike waiting, and don't mind late dinners, seating was pretty much instantaneous after 9pm. And with how often you'll need to come to get through their extensive handmade pasta menu, all those minutes add up!

Notable dishes include, well, everything we tried: their Monterey squid and corn, roasted cauliflower, pesto tagliatelle, and clam spaghettini.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - While the venue itself is spacious, tables are packed together somewhat tightly. That said, there's definitely accessible seating, so fear not!

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Long lines and waits.  Do they always mean that a restaurant is amazing?  No.  Sometimes hubs and I wonder who lines up the most for food - SFers, NYers, or those in LA.  We do love our lines in SF.  I've been wanting to try a Mano ever since I heard about their anticipated opening.  I honestly was a little skeptical because I wasn't much of a fan of Beretta, but the menu sounded amazing, and my friends loved it too when they went for dinner.  So, to avoid a long wait, we lined up outside on their outdoor seating about 30 minutes before opening the other Saturday.  We were third in line and chatted with a friendly couple.  The line grew and people tried of course to get inside.  10 minutes til, we stood up and waited by the door.  Shortly after some 40 year old blonde Real Housewives wannabe with her mini crew cut behind the people behind me claiming she had a reservation when the others that waited with us told her "the line's back there."  a Mano doesn't take reservations at all and she tried to pull a lame fast one.  She walked into the restaurant (though not technically opened yet) and said something to the hostesses, they then pointed to the line and she stormed out and was angry.  

Doors finally opened, staffed clapped and we were all seated.  The restaurant is actually a fairly good size and had blonde waited about 10 minutes afterwards she would've gotten in.  Tables are very close together.  We witnessed the couple next to us fight and storm off before they ordered, and then a VC meeting happened afterwards.  Oh SF!  Service at first was a bit slow as we were third to get seated yet everyone else got water before us.  After that service was much more attentive and very friendly.  He had a red to start and I had a prickly pear soda which was so refreshing & light.  To start we went with the cauliflower, and for our mains we did the nightly special which was a porchetta and the famous pesto tagliatelle.

The cauliflower was lightly pan fried and seasoned with lemon, chili, and bagna cauda, which is a hot dish mixed of anchovies, garlic, butter and olive oil.  Healthyish dish of the night and done right!  I asked one of the waiters if the arancini was the fried rice balls just filled with cheese, and he said yes, and asked if I wanted them, I said I did but that I'm trying to be healthy, and he amused me saying that everything I got was healthy.  Shortly, he brought us an order of arancini saying it was on him.  Bless his heart!  They were served piping hot, and were super cheesy on the inside.  It was served with some orange sauce which was very faint.  They weren't my favorite arancinis but they were pleasing.  How can you not like fried balls?  Next up were the entrees I've been waiting for.  The porchetta was a huge hunk of meat served with a light arugula side salad, pickled peppers, red onion and salsa verde.  The porchetta was moist with some fat on it, and most importantly the skin was nice and crispy!  Up there with RoliRoti's porchetta for sure.  Lastly, you have to have pasta at a Mano or else, you're a fool!  a Mano means by hand, so all the pasta is super fresh!  The tagliatelle was cooked right before al dente.  People said that this gives you extreme garlic breath.  I semi agree.  Later in the evening my breath still smelled like it but it was light, not overwhelming like I was about to slay some vampires.  One of the best pesto pastas I've had.  And yes, the waiter was right, it is healthy!  LOL  I mean it had haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, pesto, fava pineuts in it and seemed lighter on the parm in the pesto.  None of a Mano's dishes were overkill though I feared some of them were going to be rich.  I was getting full but hoping to sample some of their dessert.  Unfortunately, none of the desserts really tickled us so I had to pass.  

a Mano serves up great Italian food with a twist at affordable prices - pasta topping $15, appetizers $16 and under, and the porchetta was under $30.  Service was friendly and attentive, the space is mod and in an area where there's a ton of good food this place is a stand out.  Worth the wait.  Next time I'm back, I think I'll try another pasta dish and a pizza, who wants to come with?  4.5 stars rounded up.
author: Cat C.

description: DELICIOUS food and great service! The pizzas, pastas, appetizers and focaccia bread... all yummy. Like the ambiance... fits so well in Hayes Valley. Grazie.
author: Zaza A.

description:
This place is very much like Delarosa, one of my favorite places. It has great non-fussy food, yummy cocktails and a relaxing vibe, all in a package that won't break the bank. 

I got the sirena and the hubby had the negroni. The sirena was well balanced and refreshing. Hubby liked his drink, too. 

We ordered the chicken liver mousse and the calamari for appetizers and the gemelli and bucatini for our entrees. The liver mousse was just ok but the calamari was outstanding. The calamari was tender and plump and the corn is a perfect accompaniment to accentuate the sweetness of the protein. 

We also enjoyed our pastas. I think all the pastas are made in house. It has the right amount of sauce and were al dente. My only complaint is that I wish they browned the pork bits a bit more to extract more flavor out of the bacon bits and render out a bit more of the fat, though. 

Wish there are more places like a Mano, where it's casual without being too casual, serves good food and cocktails and you can leave the place for around $50/person. I highly recommend the place.
author: Alice W.

description:
If I only knew this place had good food, I would have stayed for dinner!  Instead, I sipped my Negroni, chatted with the folks at the bar, and admired all of the food that was coming out of the kitchen.

Next time...next time.  At least I found my new aperitif, Becherovka.  Try to pronounce that and impress the bartender!
author: Ron L.

description: Food is always good here. Today, we enjoyed the cauliflower bagna cauda and a white pizza with cherry tomatoes, garlic and oregano topped with arugula.
author: S A.

description: Awesome Italian with great ambience and service. Even though it's clear it's a very popular restaurant, our wait time wasn't crazy and the food came quickly. I would love to go back and try some of the daily specials!
author: Hannah G.

description: Pasta made by hand.  The offerings were balanced well from zesty and light to creamy and savory.  The portions were enough to enjoy an evening conversation with friends.  Lovely service, knowledgeable staff, and friendly atmosphere.  I had the Bianca pizza that was great for sharing.
author: John D.

description:
Amazing in all ways. Fresh ingredients. Knowledgeable staff. Attentive staff. Quick service. 

We dined here with my family for our after wedding lunch. They offered a champagne toast for our celebration ( on the house ).  All the food was delicious! 5 stars all around.
author: Nicole A.

description: I fell in love last time I was in San Francisco...with a Mano. My friend and I waited close to 2 hours for dinner on a Saturday night, but it was totally worth it. There are plenty of bars around to grab a drink at while you wait.  My friends and I split the Arancini which was an amazing appetizer to start our meal. I had the Agnolotti which was perfectly al dente, packed with flavor and not grossly creamy or heavy. Prices are fair and the ambience is bustling. The drinks looked pretty tasty, too. I would absolutely come back next time I'm in the City and highly recommend this place.
author: Alana M.

description:
Pizza was a solid "less than MEH". 

I had the one with sausage & the pizza was salty, like TOO salty. I actually had a very hard time finishing it. There was oil surfacing on the pizza and it just didn't make me feel too good after a few bites. I had to stop eating and take it to go. There was no redeeming factor; maybe with the exception of the crust?? But yeah, this is not the place to go for a solid pie. But hey, it's all my opinion. A lot of people seem to dig it
author: Joshua C.

description: Came here last night 30 mins before they were closing and loved it! Not many other restaurants in the area were open so we were thankful these guys were open late. We got a burrata pizza with added sausage to share (so good!) and the pork rigatoni. Loved both dishes and the service was really good too. Our server was nice and the food came out in 10 minutes. I'll definitely be back. :)
author: Mira B.

description:
I'd like to preface this review by saying that the food here is good, and I am deliberately being a little picky with this review. I have been here twice and did give it a second chance. 

Pros:
Portions are perfect size
Amazing coffee
Good food

Cons:
Food doesn't live up to the hype. It's good, but not A-mazing. For having mostly pasta and pizza on the menu, I would expect both to be amazing, but it falls short

My 2nd time felt very rushed. I came in alone, but in general felt that my server was quite terse with me. Not in an aggressive or "bad" way, but definitely in a "you're alone so we expect a quick meal from you" kind of way. I eat pretty fast and don't generally linger, so for me this was a surprise.

Overall I'd recommend this for good pasta. But if you have an option go somewhere warmer and for A-mazing pasta, this is probably not the place.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I was very excited to try this Italian restaurant I've heard so much about, however it didn't live up to the hype or the long line in my book. 

Let's start with the positives:
1. Really good service and they were so thankful that everyone waited. 
2. Food came out pretty quickly
3. Drinks were nice and strong. We got the Negroni and Spritz.
4. Cauliflower was very good. Perfect amount of spice and lemoniness

Things that could've been improved:
1. I'm sure by now you've heard about the line at this place. We arrived at 5:30 and waited about 45 minutes and by the time we were seated at 6:15 the wait was 1:45! Mind you we came on a Saturday night, but I couldn't imagine waiting nearly 2 hours. Would love to see them take reservations in the future. 
2. Tagliatelle alla bolognese was sub par. I love savory, but this was just plain too salty. Also the homemade pasta fell apart pretty easily which was disappointing. 

Overall if you can come at a time that isn't busy (I'm honestly unsure when that is though) you should skip this place and go to one of the other amazing Italian restaurants in the city
author: Angela L.

description:
Luck was on my side when I told my family to meet me at a Mano. They had a table of four outside and it was a truly beautiful and warm evening. 

We ordered the fried squash (YUM), the fontina arancini (you'll want more than one!) and yummy cocktails. 

Each of us ordered a pasta dish and it was the perfect serving. I highly suggest trying just anything that sounds good to you on the menu - don't think about it too much - it'll be great. 

I chose the beautifully scalloped whole-wheat looking pasta with chestnut and Brussel sprouts. It was the perfect nutty, sweet, earthy combo I was looking for. Everyone else got the bucatini!

The food is wonderfully unique, tasty and affordable. However, our server seemed like he'd rather be anywhere else. He was exhausted to answer any questions (it wasn't that busy), and stared blankly any time we tried to relate to him with humor. We were nothing less than an easy table and I was actually turned off by the service, apologizing to my sweet family from out of town. 

Nonetheless, the food is amazing and I'll be going again when I'm craving pasta. I like what they have going there and the location is unbeatable.
author: Ainslee S.

description:
Absolutely obsessed with this little Hayes Valley gem! The ambiance is very cool, chic and welcoming. Our first interaction when my gf and I walked in was with the beautiful and oh so sweet, host (Gaelle), she let us know that there was a bit of waitlist for sitting outside and recommended we grab a drink while we wait for our table (they don't take reservations fyi so def get there a little early to hang while you wait as they're pretty busy most nights). 

We snagged some seats at the bar and our bartenders, Jamie and Chris were great, they made us great cocktail and wine recommendations and by the time we finished our second drink our table outside was ready, woo hoo! Gaelle walked us to our table (it was such a warm lovely night so they outdoor seating was ideal) and we were greeted by our server Kyle immediately with a ton of energy! 

We started off with the focaccia( (they make it in house and omg soo fresh and delish!) and the fried butternut squash (soo yummy with that aioli!) It was fried chicken special day so we split that (plenty for two girls if you split apps) and then of course finished our dinner with the nutella split which is to die for and totally worth the calories! 

Towards the end of our meal the manager Gio came over and checked how everything was, he was really sweet and is clearly doing a great job running the ship bc our experience was nothing short of spectacular!

I highly recommend A Mano and can't wait to come back for more yummy grub!
author: Nicole H.

description:
Met up with a small group of fellow Yelpers for dinner yesterday, Wednesday, July 12th. I was the first to arrive and got there a little before 6pm. There were some tables open and seats at the communal table. a Mano does not take reservations, so this would be the perfect time to arrive as you will probably avoid a wait. Unfortunately for me, the whole party needs to be here in order to be seated, so I had to wait for all the stragglers. When our entire party of four were all present, the wait was 45 minutes, so we just grabbed three seats at the end of the bar and ordered drinks. (The restaurant takes your phone number and will text you when your table is ready. You have 5 minutes to claim it once you get the text.)

*Americano: Campari, Sweet Vermouth, Soda ($10)
*Negroni: Gin, Campari, Alessio Chinato ($12)
*Cardinale: Gin, Luxardo Bianco, Dolin, Blanc, Grapefruit Bitters ($11)
*Godfather: Bourbon, Scotch, Almond Bitters ($12) x2
*Sirena: Aperol, Vodka, Grapefruit, Calabrian Chile ($12)
*Manhattanero: Rye, Cynar, Italian Vermouth ($13)
*Peroni ($5)

One of my friends ordered a Negroni, but I guess the bartender heard Peroni which is how we ended up with a beer. We just kept it as we have a beer drinker in the group. I started with the Manhattanero. I'm a fan of manhattans so I enjoyed this drink. For the second round, I got the Godfather. This was lighter than my first drink, so if you're going for the rye/scotch/bourbon drinks, I'd start with the Godfather and follow up with the Manhattanero.

*Tuscan duck liver mousse, kumquat mostarda ($9)
*Fontina arancini ($11)
*Monterey squid, summer corn, roman-esco, shishito peppers ($13)
*Margherita, tomato, fior di latte, basil ($12), add Arugula ($2)
*Tagliatelle, pesto, english peas, fava pinenuts ($15)
*Spaghettini, clams, chili, lemon, pangratatto ($15)
*Bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, pancetta, pecorino ($14)
*Cabernet Blend, Frescobaldi, Toscana 2014 ($13)

We moved to our table 46 mins after I put my name down. (I checked the texts for the amount of time we waited.) We had already talked about the food we wanted while drinking at the bar, so we knew what we wanted to order. We did everything family style, so I got to try all the dishes. My fav by far was the tagliatelle. That pesto was sooo good! I could have finished the plate all by myself. I also liked the duck liver mousse. Nice and creamy. I thought the rest of the dishes were good overall. The arancini was crispy and cheesy. The squid was tender with a nice chew. I adored the shishito peppers and corn. I'm actually not a huge pasta person, so I thought the other two pastas were okay. I liked the clams in the spaghettini, but I wished the bucatini had more sauce. The pizza was a little disappointing. The outside crust was soft with a great chew, but the middle was kinda soggy. Plus there wasn't much cheese on the pizza. I wanted more!

Fun new spot in Hayes Valley. If you want to avoid a wait, make sure to show up before 6pm. And order the pesto tagliatelle. It was sooo good! Thinking about it makes we want it again. Yum!
author: Elena N.

description: The food is good but the service is disappointed. Our server gave us the attitude when we asked about the recommendation and the question. The appetizers came before my drink because he totally forgot ..  Dont judge the book by the cover Mr. H..
author: Ann S.

description:
I love pasta! I can eat pasta all day everyday! That being said, I'm easily unimpressed by mediocre to bad pasta. a Mano is definitely not mediocre. I can safely say it is one of the best pastas I've had in the Bay Area. 
To start off, we had the focaccia olive tapenade which was good and worth a try if you love fresh homemade bread. Then we had the fontina arancini, two words, MIND BLOWING! I absolutely loved this dish and I think this fried rice ball is a must have for anyone coming here. We also had the bucatini al amatriciana which was flavorful and just as I expected it. Unfortunately, we did not get a chance to stuff our faces with more pasta or pizza or dessert! On that note, I will definitely be coming back to try out the other delicious options that they have. 
Some other good points about this place is that the wait is not too long. We were seated on a Sunday evening in about 20 minutes. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The ambience is cozy and good for date nights. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for some good Italian food with a casual vibe.
author: Shweta M.

description:
Serving sizes were tiny. My friends and I shared 3 pastas and a whole pizza, and afterwards, my guy friends said they could probably eat another full meal. 

The dishes themselves were very flavorful and delicious. I would go back to try the other pastas forsure! The ambiance was nice as well. It did get pretty crowded inside and the tables are pretty close to each other, but I think that didn't deter from the overall vibe of the restaurant. Also, there is usually a wait at normal dinner hours. So plan accordingly!

If you really want to enjoy the experience there I would recommend ordering maybe 2 dishes per person and sharing everything family style.
author: Hanna K.

description:
At best a 3 star meal.  Nothing that we ordered was bad but there was basically nothing with a lot of flavor. Tried the cauliflower. It's basically oil fried cauliflower with small pieces of chilli. The fava beans were fried with absolutely no seasoning. The pasta in the pesto sauce lacked seasoning and flavor. The squid with chickpea was nothing special either.  The Babette steak was the best thing we ate. 

Service was also not attentive. No one checked in on the table to ask how things were going. We had to ask for water and for our wines over and over. The servers seemed super busy. It's a stunning space and great location. Nothing there is making me say "wow" or even good. It was just ok at best. No reason to go back.
author: Rohan D.

description:
This has been my favorite neighborhood spot for italian food. The pasta is freshly made and the salad and cocktails are divine. The only problem is finding a table, so come early. 

Dishes are simple, but well executed with high quality ingredients at the perfect price point. 

I will be back again!
author: Rishika S.

description:
This place is the best! Not too expensive and very authentic. The Cauliflower appetizer is very bold flavor, spicy, crispy and sour!! You can not go wrong with it. 
Margarita pizza is very authentic, thin crust, and can taste the authentic mozzarella cheese. 
For entree, I got the mafladine with braised duck leg pasta, it is honestly the best. Flavor is so good and the duck meat is very tender. 
I will definitely come back here again!
author: Le Y.

description:
One of the best meals we had on our honeymoon! We stumbled upon this place while we were walking around in the Hayes neighborhood. We saw it was crowded so we thought it must be good! We were luckily able to get seated right away around 7:15 pm on a Monday since it was just the two of us. 

My husband and I split the following: 
-Summer squash, zucchini blossom pizza with fresh stracciatella
-Cauliflower Antipasti 
-Corn Agnolotti (special for the night and my favorite) 

Everything felt really fresh and We had great cocktails too. The only downside was that I think the cauliflower was fried which is not what I was hoping for - I would mark that it's fried on the menu. Still very tasty though. 

We sat outside and there were heat lamps which kept us warm. Would love to come back when I'm in SF!
author: Leslie H.

description: A good place to have dinner on Hayes st. Really cool atmosphere but tons of people waiting in line - be prepared to wait an hour if you want to stay inside. Dishes are good, we really enjoyed the Margherita and the cauliflower. Wish the pasta dish would have been a bit bigger. Service was nice but because the place was so packed we waited 45min to get our pizza. Hence 3.5 stars.
author: Clémentine C.

description: I got the nightly special it's fantastic, try the cauliflower you won't regret it. Sat outside and received great service. Place is a must if you are a bike ride. Classy bathroom real nice place. Kristina is very helpful!
author: Aaron V.

description: Came here for brunch on a Saturday.  For some reason we both ordered the specials instead of the standard pizza and pastas on the menu.  Unfortunately my fried chicken was really disappointing, as the batter had no flavor aside from burnt oil.  I had a bite of my girlfriend's frittata, which was actually pretty good.  Think I just made a mistake in ordering, so keeping this at 3 stars instead of 2.  Will definitely try the pasta or pizza next time.
author: Simon L.

description:
A Mano is the restaurant that I want to see open up in Hayes Valley. It has everything: a buzzy atmosphere, great cocktails, handmade pastas, outdoor seating right on Hayes Street perfect for these lovely Summer evenings which we know in SF, doesn't really start until September. Also, they close at a later hour which is rare is SF. 

We decided to swing by for dinner a couple Sunday evenings ago and arrived right before it opened. We were greeted by a line that was the length of the entire restaurant and then some. However they soon got everyone in and seated rather quickly. 

The dishes offered on their menu all sounded fantastic. I had the tagliatelle which I enjoyed but the pasta was slightly thinner than I personally would have liked as it didn't have much of a bite. However, the husband's paccheri had loads. Arancinis were decent and I would be ok skipping it next time and reserving the carb allowance for their pastas instead. 

Overall service was attentive, friendly, pleasant and prompt. 

A Mano hasn't been opened long however I see it is quickly establishing itself as one of the focal dining destination of this ever changing neighborhood.
author: Esther A.

description: I'm obsessed with this place!  A Mano has become my go-to Italian spot in the city and is a place I always bring friends who are visiting SF, or SF-friends who hadn't discovered it yet. Sitting outside or inside, eating dinner or brunch, I have never been disappointed.  The arancini, rigatoni, and pesto pasta are not to be missed.  I've also been lucky enough to eat in Harry's section a few times and now have come to request him if he happens to be working!  He is so personable and is a true professional. He has always come through with spot on food and cocktail recommendations.  I trust his taste completely!  I appreciate that he doesn't hover around too much which can be annoying, but also somehow magically knows when you need attention.  Put A Mano on your rotation for go-to restaurants in the city and ask for Harry.  It's the best!!
author: Jamie C.

description: My boyfriend and I loved this place!!!! So gooood. I can't remember what he had but it was a lemon pesto pasta. And I had the margherita pizza. SO FLAVORFUL. The restaurant was coY and our server was nice :)
author: Lindsey C.

description: It can be pretty hard to get a seat here for dinner on the weekends, so if you plan to eat here I recommend coming early. The nice thing is that their wait list system allows you to check what position you're in on the phone and receive text alerts when your table is ready, so you can stroll through Hayes Valley to kill time instead of just waiting outside the restaurant. For as popular and well received as a Mano is, I was surprised by how cheap it ended up being for an italian restaurant with homemade pasta! All the pasta dishes were below $20 and the portions are actually fairly substantial unlike some other spots (cough cough Barzotto). If only the lines were shorter, we'd probably go a lot more often. For now though it'll only be for times when we plan ahead enough in time.
author: Stephany L.

description: BEST thin-crust pizza ever!!! I haven't tried their pastas yet because the pizza is so good, I end up ordering the same again - salsiccia now, asparagus and marguerita were great too (plus the arugula & strawberry salad with pistachios). If you like thin, crispy crust with the perfect amount of toppings, you will not be disappointed. I also go at lunch time and although it's always busy I never had to wait for a table.
author: Debora G.

description:
I came with a party of 3 on a Wednesday night and the place was packed! We asked how long the wait was and they said it would be about an hour and will text/call us when our table is ready. We decided to go next door to grab a drink and the timing couldn't be more perfect - once we finished our first drink, the hostess called me and said it was ready!

We sat down and a very, VERY exuberant waiter came to greet us & tell us about the menu. He made a few suggestions and we loved all of them so we decided to go family style so we can try a bunch of things. 

- Cauliflower - I'm not a huge cauliflower gal, but I absolutely LOVED it... I wouldn't get enough of it 
- Seasonal Veggies Salad - Just ok, but really appreciated the large chunks of avocado
- Tagliatelle w/ pesto, english peas, fava, pine nuts - this was absolutely delicious.. the pasta tasted so fresh & with the peas/pine nuts - it was absolutely perfect
- Bucatini all amatriciana - this was my favorite pasta dish with tomato, pancetta, and pecorino... I could not get enough!!
- Salsiccia, chili sausage, tomato pizza - thin sliced pizza with the perfect crunch/cheese ratio

I'm already itching to come back and try the rest of their menu.... Their portions are decent... between the 3 of us we got 5 dishes & it was perfect.
author: Carrie L.

description: Came here on a Saturday afternoon. Almost got turn away by the crowd on the patio, but inside the restaurant were actually a lot of seats and didn't have to wait long. My friend had the fried chicken special and I ordered the pasta with meat sauce with olive oil fried egg added. The pasta was divine and it had a very nice chewy texture. Price was reasonable too.
author: Ava A.

description: Great place for drinks and food. Had the spritz which was good. Tried the figs with cheese and prosciutto, which how you can go wrong. Also tried their squid with corn and shishito peppers which was delicious. The heat lamps outside make all the difference. Cool spot. Would come back.
author: Linda H.

description: I don't understand the hype or maybe they don't care about the vegetarian folks. Got the beet salad, fungi pizza and the buckwheat pasta. All the food was very average. Nothing to talk about. The pizza was my favourite cause it was unique. These guys are apparently related to beretta in the mission but don't even come close as far as taste is concerned. On top of that ofcourse there's Hayes valley prices. Not impressed.
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Wait - Walk-in 18:00 on Saturday. One hour wait. *Text will be sent when your table is ready
 
Value - $15 / dish.
 
Dish Size: Medium size. One entrée was enough per person
 
Wallbanger - The mango flavor is strong with just a hint of alcohol. Well balanced drink.
 
Rossini - Extremely refreshing. The bubbles made it feel like you were actually biting into a straweberry.
 
Monterey squid (summer corn, roman-esco, shishito peppers) - Must order. The squid was cooked perfectly on the grille. Slightly charred outside but still completely melt in your mouth buttery.
 
Spaghettini (clams, chili, lemon, pangrattato) - A tasty dish with a prominent seafood forward flavor. Pasta and clams were cooked perfectly. There was just the right amount of spice from the chili which added an extra pop to the dish.
 
Tagliatelle (pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, pinenuts) - A bit disappointed that there wasn't a stronger pesto presence. Besides that, all the components were cooked well.
 
 
We attempted to test our luck and walk-in to a Mano at 18:00 on a Saturday night. However, when we arrived the entire place was packed and there was a line out the door. The hostess said the wait would be around an hour for a table of two. To the benefit of a Mano, the location is perfect as there's plenty of stuff around to make the hour wait fly by. A stone throws away, we ended up at Biergarten to have a couple drinks outside as we waited. A little less than a hour, we get a text saying our table is ready. I really do appreciate when you get a text instead of having to loiter around and wait to hear your name be called.
 
The space is large with both indoor and a row of outdoor seating. A major plus is the outdoor seating does have heat lamps which is perfect for a chilly day. The interior definitely follows the hip and trendy formula with the touch of industrial details accented by warm wood elements. The interior pairs well the crowd, which leans towards the younger bourgeois generation - a perfect fit for Hayes Valley.
 
a Mano has to be considered as a full package. There is definitely much better pasta joints elsewhere in the city. However judging the location, vibe, and value as a whole, a Mano is hard to beat. Would I wait an hour for a Mano if there wasn't all the other shops around- a resounding no. But there is, to the benefit of a Mano.
 
 
The best dish by far was the Monterey squid resting on top a bed of summer corn. The squid was cooked perfectly on the grille with a slight charred outside but still completely melt in your mouth buttery. I have a feeling the corn must have been cooked in the squid juices because the corn flavor was amazing. The corn was perfectly cooked with a slight bite to it when chewed.
author: Julian L.

description:
100% Worth the hype! 

My boyfriend has been begging me to go here since it opened as he is pretty much obsessed with anything Adriano Paganini touches (same dude who runs Beretta, Delarosa, Lolinda, Super Duper etc.) Finally, yesterday we decided to give a Mano a visit. 

WAIT (4/5) 
This place gets busy and they do NOT take reservations! We went at 5:45 on a Thursday and it was already pretty much full. Luckily, there was a table outside and they had heated lamps that made it comfortable enough to sit there. I would come early, and avoid peak times on the weekends. 

AMBIANCE (4.5/5) 
Sophisticated Italian Decor. A step up from Beretta and Delarosa - way less cramped seating and less noisy even though it's always popping. Ideal for date night! Located in Hayes Valley which is one of my favorite SF neighborhoods. 

FOOD (5+/5) 
YA'LL! This food is AMAZING! I am not even a pasta gal and this food had my life flashing before my eyes.  We ordered: 
****Monterrey Squid: amazing take on calamari. Not for the squeamish as you can literally see the squid on your plate. The consistency of the squid was to dieeee for and the sauce the accompanied it was so unique and delicious. If you have had the octopus at Lolinda it's the same vibe but BETTER. 
*****Spaghettini w/ Clams: BEST PASTA I'VE HAD IN MY 26 YEARS. I am not one to order pasta, but all pasta here is made by hand ("a Mano") so I figured we needed to try it. Such a crazy fusion of spices, sauces, seasoning, and yes - the pasta. Just do yourself a favor and get this dish. 
*****Margareta Pizza: Good, but very much overshadowed by the pasta. If you need to make a choice, skip the pizza. 
*****Nutella Sundae: Gelato was amazing! Nutella sauce very tasty. Great way to end an amazing meal. 

DRANKS (4/5) 
Cocktails were tasty, but please don't make the same mistake as me and skip the "Vino de la casa". It is NOT good, and had I known that I would've gladly paid the few bucks extra for another wine.

SERVICE (4/5) 
Friendly! Since it is a busy restaurant it was not as fast as it could be, but can't complain.  

OVERALL (4.5/5): Run, don't walk to a Mano. Try their pasta ASAP.
author: Natalie F.

description: If you want cold undercooked pasta and attitude this is the place to come. I am sorry that I like my food warm if not hot, and so sorry that I inconvenienced you to ask to heat it up.  Even when I did receive the food, it was blah had to add chili peppers to it to make it edible , go to an authentic  Italian where you will love your food and will get some decent service.
author: Diane G.

description:
I found a Mano on a list of must-try's so four of us lingered around Hayes Valley for the 90 minutes we were asked to wait. For great food, waiting is not a matter. 

Service was good but not spectacular, food was good but not particularly memorable (except for their agnolotti) although the drinks list did whisk me away to the boot-shaped country. We ordered the squid and summer salad to start, the margherita pizza to share, and individual pasta dishes. My rigatoni was a little bland as confirmed by the three others in my party, so I was eyeing every piece of agnolotti that was consumed by my neighbour. 

All in all, great atmosphere, decent food, but am I a fan of waiting 90 minutes for merely decent food? Probably not.
author: Anthony L.

description: Perfect portion size, really fresh food. Sat at the bar and had great service. Would definitely return
author: Sophia P.

description:
a Mano was wonderful this past Thursday night and boy are we glad we got there at about 5:15 PM because soon after, the place was packed.

Service was great right from the start as well as the drinks. Creative, Italian inspired drinks that were very well made. The Godfather, The Sirena, Aperol Spritz and a lovely glass of red wine were all fantastic.

The food was spectacular.
:: Gem lettuce, fennel, radish, anchovy, ricotta salata, capers - salty in all the right places.
:: Smelt with a light polenta coating and then fried to perfection with a caper aioli - so good and reminded me of my childhood.
:: Pizza margherita, tomato, fior di latte, basil - Neapolitan style to thin and light toppings (no oozing with cheese, thank goodness). Super and the right size for two people with a pasta dish.
:: Tagliatelle, pesto, green beans, thinly sliced potato and pine nuts - Hand. Cut. Pasta. Need I say more? Light and delicious, not smashed down by a machine. The sauce was superb, we cleaned the plate with our pizza crust - terrible manners I know, but it was so good.

Average bill for San Francisco - $120 including tip - nothing to complain about here.

Service was great except my knife was mistakenly taken away with some of the service plates but it was nearing the end of the meal, so it was fine. We even got a little Italian lesson along the way when trying to order a glass of Italian wine. Yay!
author: Katie S.

description:
This review is for the hostesses.

My aunt was visiting from out of town so I wanted to take her somewhere that had really tasty food. I found this place and the food looked yummy so we decided to meet here. We had a larger party of 7, but I didn't realize you probably needed to get there around 4 or 5 to be seated around 7:00 for dinner. We needed to sit outside because we had a puppy too, so that was our other mistake. My sister got there around 6:30 and called to tell me that the wait could be as long as 3 hours and we were number 32 on the list. I got there a minute later and decided we should wait it out for a bit and get drinks at the bar. After an hour we were number 15 on the waitlist and it looked like many more seats would be opening both inside and outside, which they did. We were at spot number one for way too long while we watched many people getting sat outside. This obviously irked us. They were not trying to be accommodating and push tables together, or wait for a table that was close to being done to put tables together. According to their online table system we were next for about an hour. My cousin ended up leaving because it was too much, so our table size when down a person. The straw that broke the camels back, was when a table that was actually big enough opened up for us OUTSIDE and one of the hostesses told us we were next, they sat another large party because they had 8 people and the table sat 8 people. I couldn't believe it. Horrible service. We ended up leaving because it was 10:00 and we were hangry. We went across the street to the little Mexican restaurant and they gladly seated us. My sister finally got a text around 10:30 that our table was ready, that would have meant it would have been a 4 hour wait. I don't think any restaurant is worth that. What a joke.

Maybe one day I'll try it again and get there earlier and not have a puppy with us, but probably not until they have some type of reservation system in order.
author: Margaret S.
