description: Great pasta, but really subpar and slow service. Also pasta could use a seasonal rotation too
author: Han L.

description:
OMG, I loved this place.  The food was great and the service was attentive.  I took off one star because it's very loud.  

Three of us shared an order of focaccia, a strawberry salad, a margherita pizza, the funghi campanelle pasta, and the pork sugo rigatoni.  I especially loved the strawberry salad and both of the pastas.  I also had a wheat beer, which was delicious.
author: Linda R.

description: My wife and I had a wonderful lunch here last Saturday.  This was our first visit here and it lived up to they hype.  We had a nice table on the sidewalk and were well treated by the wait staff.  We started with the cauliflower antipasti, which was delicious.  Just a hint of the banga cauda that was a nice touch to the cauliflower.  As the are house made, we both decided to try the pasta.  My wife had the mafaldine with summer squash and arugula pesto.  It was wonderful, a light pesto that was perfect with the pasta.  I had the bucatini all'amatriciana, which was more traditional and also delicious.  Highly recommended.
author: Ron E.

description: This place is great, the pasta is amazing and made fresh. My only small problem is that the portions are quite small for the price.
author: Rosanna S.

description: Came here and sat at the bar before going to the ballet. I got a salad and the penne with mushroom sauce. Both were solidly good. The food was a lot better the last time I came, so will have to try it again.
author: Kavita P.

description:
I love my carbs. Low carb / no carb diets are BS. Yea, I said it. 

I love pasta. I love fresh pasta. A bowl of fresh pasta is a bowl of comfort and love. 

a Mano delivers on that for sure. Easily got a table for 2 this past Sunday around 7:30pm. That will probably change as a Mano gains more popularity. Good attentive service. My friend and I split a salad and 2 pastas. a Mano encourages you to share, family style. Honestly I wanted every pasta dish on the menu but we were merely a party of 2. Looking back, I think I could've tackled it. It came down to the bucatini all' amatriciana or the tagliatelle for me. My friend said he felt the tagliatelle would just be any old pesto so he managed to sway me toward the bucatini. 

My friend and I split the mostaccioli w/ braised tripe, and the bucatini all' amatriciana. If you are not a lover of tripe, then do not get the mostaccioli. The tripe flavor definitely comes through in that dish. Disclaimer: I love tripe. The pasta was al dente so it was substantial, but I did wish it had something a bit more dense or crunch in the dish so that the overall texture would be better. Still found it to be good. 

LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVED the bucatini all' amatriciana. My favorite pasta of all pastas is bucatini and amatriciana is packed full of flavor. The tomato, the pancetta, the garlic.. Not too acidic, not overly salty, perfectly al dente with just the right amount of pecorino too. My favorite of the night. 

As much as I loved the amatriciana, I really think we should've split the tagliatelle as well. Nearly every table had ordered it. My friend said he had never really had a deep appreciation for freshly made pasta until a Mano. I told him he has been depriving himself. The way Aziz feels about pasta in Master of None is the way I feel about pasta. Season 2 reeeeaaaaaaaally pushed my pasta cravings. Before we even finished, my friend declared that he wanted to go on a pasta binge. I excitedly volunteered as tribute. Look at you, turned him into a fan! He is already binging hard because he went back to a Mano the very next night and ordered every pasta dish. No tagliatelle though, because you guys sold out. I KNEW IT! I knew I should've ordered it on Sunday!

a Mano, I really enjoyed you. Great value and price point, especially for Hayes Valley. When are you opening for lunch? because allora....I need to try everything!
author: Susy C.

description:
Lively bar and area and delicious food. 

Disappointed the wait ended up being TWO HOURS on an early Thursday night and the waiter hardly checked on us. 

Pasta was incredible and other dishes looked delicious. Would recommend getting a few dishes and splitting.
author: Shannon P.

description: We went here to celebrate an anniversary and we're so glad that we did! The food was really good. It was priced really well for the area too which was also a nice surprise. Overall: very tasty and there were amazing drinks plus don't skip on the appetizers.  one of our favorite places casual SF finds!
author: Ayanna A.

description: Same owners as Delarosa....similar vibe. I was so disappointed to find out that they don't offer vegan cheese for their pizzas!! It Surprised me- if the tagliatelle pasta wasn't so delicious (seriously) I'd be more bummed about the non-existent vegan cheese. Warning- the tagliatelle is very garlic!!! No kissing post dinner.
author: Rob M.

description: It is beyond words as to the intolerance of different religious practices within the San Francisco community. This the Jewish New Year, Rosh Hashana. We thought we would try something different this year but clearly this establishment doesn't support the rituals of other religions. I am completely shocked at the request by the manager to not break bread or say blessings in their place of business. I will never come back to this restaurant not because the food wasn't good but I was made to feel uncomfortable and not accepted. No one should be made to feel "less than" as a paying customer.
author: Michael C.

description:
My grandma and I arrived around 5:00pm and they didn't open until 5:02pm (lol). Upon entering the hostess was nice ish, and we were seated right away.

The restaurant is very spacious and modern (typical 'new' SF). After being seated for about 5 minutes our waitress approached us. She was nice and even went over the menu with us since it was our first time. 

We had the gem lettuce with fennel, radish, anchovy, ricotta salata, & capers which was delicious! The combination of the dressing with everything was a perfect mix of salty and somewhat sour.

I wish I could say the spaghettini with clams, chili, lemon & pangrattato was delicious because it wasn't! My noodles were undercooked! The taste was ok; the spiciness was overwhelming (it took away from the flavor), the clams were decent and the pangrattato was a nice added touch but couldn't save the dish. 

My grandma had the gnolotti dal plin with roast chicken, pork, chard, & Parmesan. Her dish was good, very flavorful and tasty (yum!)

Overall service was okay (felt like our waitress forgot about us after awhile), our meal was good-okay-good, and the prices were decent. I might try this place again in the near future, only because their pizza looked good.
author: M. H.

description: Stopped in to the new spot last night for some food and cocktails. We got the duck liver mousse app and the asparagus cheese pizza along with two cocktails. The place was packed but we snagged two seats at the bar. Food was really good and so we're the cocktails. Service was great as well. Would love to come back and try a pasta dish.
author: Katlyn H.

description:
The service here was amazing. Our server came back often and got out orders right. He was very attentive and really friendly.

We got their margherita and pizza like margherita with sausage. Their pizzas are thin crust. There were three of us and we were able to share two pizzas. It was about six slices per pizza.

They are really good. The flavors are just right. You do have to eat it fairly quickly though because the cheese does get hard rather fast. The crust was good and I rarely eat crust. 

I would come back here again. It was sort of pricey. The atmosphere is great. The lighting is great. Fairly dim so it makes anyone look good - perfect to take a first date. There were a lot of people so we had to wait about 30 min which I didn't mind. 

Definitely recommend this place.
author: Jerome N.

description:
Ate there on a Monday night. The space is fine. Initially seated at the communal bar top table with the weird explanation that we'd have more room even though we were elbow to elbow with the people next to us. The biggest problem with that table is the lighting though. Dim and horrible green tint. They've got to swap that out ASAP.

We were reseated at a proper table (and definitely had more space next to us than the bar table did) and the service was good.

Neither of the pasta dishes pasta was impressive - didn't have the taste or texture of truly high quality pasta. No comparison to flour + water. There has been a big deal made of this being affordable, good pasta. While we did find the prices reasonable the trade off was very small portions. If they had larger portions and adjusted prices up accordingly the food would still be mediocre.

What we ate:
Roasted asparagus, fonduta, prosciutto - really good. Fresh asparagus, cooked well, great taste. 

Agnolotti dal plin - ok but not amazing, small portion.

Bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, pancetta, pecorino - also ok but not amazing. Kind of bland, almost watered down taste.

The dessert options sounded boring and considering the unremarkable meal we didn't want to risk ordering any.

It wasn't so bad that I wouldn't go back. I will give it another try.
author: Ryan B.

description: So excited to have a reasonably priced, delicious hand cut pasta option in Hayes Valley! The lines are insane so put your name on the list and grab a cocktail at the bar while you wait or go next door to Anina and enjoy a drink on the patio. The bartenders make amazing craft cocktails so my preference is to loiter at the bar with a drink in hand and troll for an empty seat or two to get my dinner started early. The tagliatelle is hands down my favorite thing on the menu. The fritto misto is a great starter and their pizzas shouldn't be missed (have you seen the giant hunks of burrata on their summer pizza....drooling at the memory). Happier (and fatter) with this addition to the neighborhood!
author: Nerri Y.

description:
Really excited about this place opening, love the concept and price point. Was really hoping to love it more in reality.

There is going to be a wait. The pasta were fresh by both the tagliatelle and the bucatini were just a tad over cooked. The spring peas are fresh too, but both dishes lacked flavor and anything to remember.

Our waiter seemed intent on us getting wine and when we didn't, the rest of the service was very short in contrast. I'm sure they have many tables to serve.

The bar area looked nice but the rest of the place lacked soul and ambiance. Partly because of the location in a newly popped up Hayes valley building.

I think some of the reviews may be based on hype and mentally willing themselves to love it. I wanted to convince myself too, but if I'm being honest, it was completely forgettable with the exception of the awkward service.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Really quite good given the price point. It's really hard to find good, affordable, high quality pasta. You have your Cotogna, Flour + Water, Central Kitchens... but all those places are $20+ per bowl of pasta. I get that you have to pay for quality, but a Mano is a godsend in the Italian food scene in SF that serves really high quality pasta that doesn't break the bank. 

The SO and I came for dinner on Friday of opening week. We showed up at 6:15 pm (foolish) and were told that there would be a 45 min wait. Not actually a big deal since it's Hayes Valley and you can just grab a drink while you're waiting. They use a texting system to queue here which is great so you're not just stuck waiting in line. We actually got called back after 20 min which isn't too bad of a wait for a Friday night dinner at a new pretty popular restaurant.

Let's start with the space at a Mano -- I love it. They have floor to ceiling walls that look out onto the street, tons of seats, it's a really aesthetically pleasing place to eat at.

For drinks, I had the Rossini which was a super tasty opening cocktail. Would recommend if you're not a big fan of the taste of alcohol. 

Food wise, we did two apps and two pastas:
Monterey squid - wasn't a huge fan of this dish personally, but mostly because the base was beans. Resembled almost a bean/tomato soup texture as the base and squid on top. While the squid was tasty, the mixture of ingredients doesn't personally resonate

Cauliflower - delicious. Nicely roasted cauliflower seasoned with lemon and chili is one of my favorite preparations. No complaints here. Super tasty

Agnolotti del plin with roast chicken and pork - Agnolotti is always such a funny dish to be because basically it's like little pasta dumplings. I thought they were quite good. Tasty filling with a nice creamy sauce -- solid safe agnolotti option. 

Mostaccioli, braised tripe -- took a bit of a risk here as I usually don't see tripe outside of Chinese restaurants. I enjoyed this dish, though the SO thought that the sauce was almost too tripe flavored and would have preferred something that offered a more balanced flavor. I thought it was honestly fine. I enjoyed the mostaccioli though I thought they were a bit big, and the braised tripe was well cooked. Overall, a good dish as well. 

Despite the busy night, service was what you'd expect at a more casual eatery like a Mano. They were attentive when they needed to be which is all you can really expect. Fairly good for an opening week run -- usually service can be a lot worse in the beginning. 

Final price came out to be $80 -- you really can't get high quality pasta at the price elsewhere. a Mano is a great addition to Hayes -- can't wait to come back and try more dishes!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night. I'm not from San Francisco and what I loved most about this place was the location. Just like every SF restaurant, there is a long wait. That's just a part of life here.  I love that there is a ton of bars that you can go to while you wait to be seated. They text you when your table is ready. We went to smugglers (a subject of another review. Loved it)Drinks: Everyone had a round of The Godfather. It's a glorified old fashion. 
Appetizers:  We started with the olives and cauliflower. The cauliflower is perfectly roasted with chopped up peppers that add a little bit of a kick. The olives are delish. 
Entrees: Pancetta pizza with asparagus. It was okay. I was underwhelmed. Will go with the margherita  next time. The pork ragu was my absolute favorite. Pasta was perfectly al dente. Lastly, the fusilli... it was just okay. 
Dessert: only based on the panna cotta. FAIL. Just take it off your menu. It's a classic Italian dessert. And the texture was completely off. Usually, you will get a nice compote to sweeten it up. And their chopped strawberries seemed like an afterthought.
author: Mayra R.

description:
i want to love this place, but can't quite give it 5 stars. the food is fairly priced, which i love, especially in hayes valley, but the wait can be really long.  the vibe is definitely on point, and if you can snag a spot outside, even better (it reminds me of some of the italian spots in north beach).  the food is good, but great date-night spot, just be prepared for lots of people!

pro tip: put your name on the list, then walk around the corner to Fig & Thistle to grab a drink and snack while you wait!
author: Courteney S.

description:
I visited a Mano last night with my girlfriend and overall, I had a really great meal. I expected a long wait when we arrived because of how new the place was, but we were seated right away after speaking to the host. From start to end, service was excellent. 

I ordered the Sirena cocktail (Aperol, Vodka, Grapefruit, Calabrian Chile) and thought it was a very thoughtfully designed drink - just enough bitterness and kick. Between the two of us, we shared the fritto misto appetizer (deep fried shrimp, squid, fennel, and spring onion) and loved how crisp and light everything tasted. I love fried squid but there are far too many places I've been to that don't make it well, and you're left with a mouth coated with oil. No such thing here! For my entree, I ordered the spaghettini with clams. I was very impressed with this dish. Pasta was cooked perfectly (I wouldn't expect any less), portion size was perfect, clams were cleaned well (no sand), and the sauce wasn't too heavy. 

A Mano is the new kid on the block in Hayes Valley, and it looks like they're taking the crowd feedback very seriously. Another Yelper reported their pasta being under salted, and I experienced no such thing. If I had to be picky, one thing that could improve my experience is if some bread was available to munch on while waiting on the appetizers. The sheet pan of focaccia in the kitchen looked quite delicious.

In any case, I'm definitely coming back again! :)
author: Austin W.

description:
A Mano... It's not just good, but "close your eyes while you're chewing and try not to cry tears of happiness" good. My friend and I came for dinner on a Saturday night, after hearing much (well-deserved) hype. Since the restaurant doesn't take resos, we arrived right at 4:50pm -- 10min before it opened at 5pm. There was already a long line formed outside, so coming early was a great call.

It's a cute spot, right in the middle of downtown Hayes with big windows overlooking the street. Simple, trendy decor. Super nice waiting staff. From our table, we could watch the chefs prepare the pasta from scratch.

We started with cocktails and then split a bunch of dishes: 
- cauliflower appetizer (to die for, you must order this)
- rigatoni with pork sugo
- tagliatelle with pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, and pine-nuts (CRYING SO GOOD)
- summer squash pizza with zucchini blossom, stracciatella, vidalia onion, lemon

It was way too much food for just 2 people, and we had ZERO regrets. Took the extra food home and devoured it just the same.

A Mano is a must-visit, especially if you live in/near Hayes in which case you have zero excuse for not going! YUM. Can't wait to go back.
author: Katie K.

description: Fresh, hand-made pasta! To start, we got the anchovy caesar salad. A little salty, but a good combination. For entrees, we ordered the orecchiette with clams and broccoli, which was pretty good, and a margherita pizza. Personally, I like my pizza crust softer and this crust was a little on the crunchy side, but it was still good. Great, attentive service!
author: Lillian B.

description: Tasty Italian food, very affordable prices and delicious cocktails. We came to a Mano for our wedding anniversary after passing it a few times on the street when walking around Hayes. We stopped in at 6:15, and we're called for our table 30 minutes later. Our waitress was helpful and even brought us champagne for our celebration. Would definitely come again.
author: Jaclyn B.

description:
The pasta tastes quite right and fresh. They are doing a good job showing people how they work in the kitchen. The restaurant is quite neat. Pretty noisy but cozy and the staff are great. 
Had to take one star down for the waiting time. Be prepare to wait for at least 30 minutes. But your meals will be delicious.
author: Le T.

description: I love going to A Mano. They have great affordable foods. The only thing is not taking reservations and service can be a little slow sometimes, but I'm always coming back!
author: Fanny M.

description:
I went on St. Patrick's day so I didn't have to wait. Service was good, we had about 4 different servers throughout the meal (didn't bother me) all were friendly and accommodating. 

Pasta and cocktails? Super good! The pizza was alright. We got the one with mushrooms and onion - it didn't have any sauce so it tasted quite bland, the crust was crunchy which I did like. Our server was happy to accommodate us by giving us a side of marinara sauce (sorry chef) but it was very plain and didn't have any flavor.

I would definitely come back here again but avoid the pizza since I didn't like the sauce either.
author: Tanya C.

description:
Pretty good execution from day one! This newly opened Italian everyday restaurant is stylishly designed and bright yet still warm. The menu options are varied and offer a great range of antipasti, a few salads, two (very good) pizze, and an interesting assortment of pastas.  

We had the Margherita pizza and the Tagliatelle with favs and peas. The pizza was excellent with a very fresh tasting tomato sauce and the pasta was made here, nicely cooked al dente, and the sauce for but could maybe use a skosh more seasoning.

Overall an excellent effort and we're looking forward to coming back to explore more of the menu!
author: Josh M.

description: Modern Italian.  The restaurant is cozy and hip with many tables, most small. They have Italian beer and a great wine list. I had an amazing coconut mock-tail and my hubs had a moretti. You have to try the lemon chili cauliflour appetizer. It was delicious.  I had the pancetta bucatini dish and he had the braised duck pasta. Both were extremely well executed. I also loved pants cotta dessert. I wish I could come back and try the squid ink pasta, but we live in San Diego.
author: Diana S.

description: Totally love this new Italian place in Hayes Valley. Ordered the squid, agnolotti and the pistachio gelato. The chef gave me fried cauliflower on the house. The food here is great. The agnolotti, in particular, is outstanding. Service was good as well. The only "drawback" is that this place does not take reservations and it gets really packed quickly.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I've been hearing lots of great things about their homemade pastas and finally got to try it out post-Davies Symphony.  Solid pasta spot; definitely want to come back to try more apps and pastas.

Our waitress was very knowledgeable about drinks/food and gave great recs

Chicken Polpettine - spicy meatballs, excellent flavor
Rigatoni w/pork
Twisty pasta with lamb ragu

Aviazione - gin, violet, lemon, soda
author: Mon T.

description: This restaurant has it all--excellent food, drinks, and service. We arrived at about 7pm on a Saturday. Not surprisingly it was about an hour wait for dinner. However, they have a texting system where you can see how many reservations are ahead of you, so you can go for walk without losing your table. About a half hour later we found open seats at the bar. We started with cocktails--an old fashioned for my husband and a gin-based grapefruit one for me. Both were strong and well-balanced. We started with roasted cauliflower and I ordered a squash blossom pizza and my husband ordered pesto pasta. Our entrees were only slightly delayed (I honestly hadn't noticed) and we were brought complimentary olives for the inconvenience. My pizza was amazing--great crispy crust, fresh veggies and gooey cheese. The pizza was the highlight of the meal but everything we tried was delicious. Also, compared to other restaurants in the city, the quality of food for the price is better (and if you're a vegetarian like me there's still lots of menu options.) I'll definitely be back.
author: Kai S.

description: I rarely review, even when traveling, but I lucked in to this place for a weekday lunchtime bar seat and had a great experience. The first dish I ordered was not to my taste - my fault for not asking enough questions - and they sent me another dish without fuss.  I was massively impressed by their courtesy and how well-informed the staff were.  If you're a cocktail nerd, and enjoy wide selections of Amaro, Cynar, Chartruese, and other bitter liqueurs and their cocktails, you will be in heaven here. My bartender was John and he really knew his stuff.  I will be back.
author: Laural S.

description:
It's funny. I enjoyed this place so much that I've told a lot of friends to come and try again. 

I came with Stef C. a few months ago and had such a great time. There are no reservations so it makes it a little difficult to plan, but otherwise, great pasta and service!
author: Nina Y.

description:
A Mano is a GEM!  They don't accept ressies, so get there early if you don't want to wait.  This is a review of my visit a few months ago...  

A Mano is sparsely decorated which just lets the food shine!  Service is knowledgeable and friendly.  And the food....!  Oh the food!!!

I came here with a friend of mine after the opera.  We shared the beet salad, bucatini, agnolotti, and the nightly special (which I believe was the short ribs).  Their house-made pasta is divine!  Everything was perfectly seasoned and tasty.  The pastas were my favorite and the short ribs probably my least favorite.  It could have been cooked a bit more to make it more tender, and if I remember correctly, it was just a shade under seasoned.  

But yeah, I'd definitely go back...  for the pasta!
author: Christine T.

description:
Cool atmosphere. Good food. Reasonable prices. Great all around vibes.

When we first got seated it took a while for our waitress to greet our table and bring water (~10 mins). I just used the extra time to get familiar with the menu)

Had the clams and spaghettini which would have been perfect with a few pinches of salt.

Would definitely come back again.
author: Attiana P.

description: Amazing pesto tagliatelle. Love the vibe of the restaurant. Sadly, I won't be coming back. I was there today at about 2 with my young daughter and her friend. RUDEST server I've experienced in a long time. Male. May be Latino, May be White. Snarky and impatient, yet hiding behind the fakest smiles. I was patient and as I have my 10 year old and her 14 year old friend with us.  Will I come back even though I really enjoyed my food? No. Plenty of good restaurants in the city. I walked past the restaurant after shopping around and I noticed his rude behavior towards another customer sitting outside. Man. Guy needs to be let go by the restaurant.
author: X L.

description: What I love about a Mano is the food is consistently good, not overpriced, and its not terribly hard to get a table if you go earlier in the evening. I love the fontina arancini, the delicious focaccia with tapenade, and the amatriciana.  The seasonal specials are also usually delicious.  There have been a few misses, but nothing to steer us away completely.  Drinks are also stellar - highly recommend the Sirena! If I lived closer, I'd be a regular.
author: Archana P.

description: A family member wanted to try a new restaurant, a mano. We arrived early and were confused about which door to enter. A young lady working an outside table took care of us with a smile and we were soon seated. The woman who waited on us was friendly and very helpful answering a number of questions about the menu. Everyone we met made our restaurant experience one to be enjoyed. For antipasti we ordered cauliflower, lemon, chili, bagna cauda.  We ordered three pasta dishes to share: orecchiette, clams, broccoli, garlic, chili, pangrattato; bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, pancetta, percorino; and tagliatelle alla bolognese. The only thing I am going to write about these dishes is that you must try them. I would order everything again except there are several more items on the menu I want to try. Eat here. You will not be disappointed.
author: Gregory S.

description: Tagliatelle with pesto - so well seasoned, large shavings of cheese. Yum. The lighting inside and the interior space is so beautiful. I can't wait to come back.
author: Christine L.

description: Great food. Outstanding atmosphere. Phenomenal wait staff! We loved our waiter Tai!  You will not regret your choice to have your dining experience here!
author: Richard P.

description:
I went there on a friend date last night and we had an excellent time. The service was amazing (a little extra for the French speaking waiter who was absolutely amazing)! I would recommend anyone to get the pesto pastas and the pistachios salad were so tasty! 
The only thing you should do is to go there a little early so you don't have to wait too long!
author: Audrey T.

description:
The moderate prices are harbingers of the food quality and service: both mediocre. At a Mano, you get what you pay for, in my experience: soulless food and careless service. My ragu was over-sauced and under-salted shoveled on limp over-cooked pasta. The roasted cauliflower was the meal's high point. 
The space is large, and there is also sidewalk seating: with only two bathrooms, the wait to use one was more than ten minutes, which is just ridiculous and disruptive to a pleasant dining experience.
author: Stacey L.

description: The food was good but didn't live up to the hype. I enjoyed the tagliatelle pasta though the bolognese was oily and a bit bland. Also there's the fact that it had a HAIR! So sad. I couldn't eat it after that. The bucatini was al dente but a little too hard for me actually, but the sauce was great. The salad was not appropriately dressed, very sour or very salty at times and only good if you ate every element of the salad at once: greens, pickled onion, a piece of beet, piece of cheese and a hazelnut. The bang for buck was good, there was a sole diner sitting next to us and she had only a plate of pasta, which would be enough. I'm between a three and a four star but I thought I'd round up!
author: Terry K.

description:
Had a great time, food was good.
The blonde girl at the door was very accomodating!
Can you please let me have her phone number
author: Alex B.

description: The restaurant is nice, but the two hostesses are the worst. Unfriendly, arrogant and a lot of attitude. They seem to hate their job and clients.
author: Laurence V.

description:
a Mano is a solid Italian restaurant - we came with a party of 4 (one was running late) a few minutes before they opened on Saturday night and they seated us right away. The restaurant wasn't full until 5:30 and there was no visible line when we left around 6:45. Not sure if the hype is dying down, but would still suggest getting there early.

Our drinks were great (the rossini is light and bubbly, the wallbanger balances minty with mango, or order a carafe of the light and fruity rose), and our server was entertaining and attentive. The monterey squid and roasted caulifower were solid starters, though if you have more than 4 people, I'd order a third appetizer. The pizza was above-average, but nothing to write home about. Their pasta is, as the restaurant name suggests, made by hand each day and was definitely the highlight of our meal. I had the buccatini - not only was the texture of the pasta great, but the sauce was light and filling as well.

The prices are reasonable (most of the pasta dishes are around $15 and drinks are $10-12), and the ambiance and service are outstanding - but I can't say it's one of my favorites in SF and can't justify having to come early or wait in line.
author: Ada C.

description:
*3.5 stars* 

Solid Italian spot with good pasta selections.  The bucatini with pancetta and pecorino definitely stood out. 

That being said, I wouldn't expect a Mano to be better than some of the SF classics (Delfina is still my favorite!).  Be prepared to wait unless you get there before it opens.
author: Christine A.

description:
I love it when new restaurants open up in Hayes Valley, but I especially love it when it's decently priced and delicious!  Win-win. 

Their menu is relatively simple.  However, they do update it quite often.  (Yes, I go that often that I notice).  I do tend to gravitate towards their fresh pasta because I really like how silky and delicate they taste.  I've liked every tagliatelle dish they've offered (including the pesto one, which I'm hoping they'll bring back at some point).  Pizzas are also tasty and great to share.  

In terms of cocktails, they do those right too!  My absolute favorite is the Wallbanger (vodka/mango), and will probably never order anything else besides this moving forward. 

The wait can take awhile, so I would suggest trying to go on the earlier side.  Worse comes to worse, you can always put your name/number down and wait at the next door bars (Brass Tacks or Anina), or shop!
author: Judy C.

description: First time heard this place from my co worker, since he work here, he highly recommend me to come here try this food. Finally i got a chance to stop by here to try their food. I order the duck liver appetizer, one proscuitto Pizza, one squid pasta, one nite special. When our food come, the portion is good, the quality is very delicious! All of my friends like their food. Also their drink is good too. I highly recommend this place, if you guys looking for a high-end restaurant, good food and reasonable price this spot is good choice!
author: Yueming G.

description: Came on a Sat night around 8 pm. We were quoted 1h 15 min wait but ended up being about 45 min. They had plenty of tables open - it looks like they're still trying to figure out how to optimize for operational efficiency. We were able to sit outside under the warmth of a heat lamp to enjoy our food. House red wine was nice and dry and smooth! We then shared a flatbread (mushroom) as well as a freshly made pasta dish (taleggio-potato tortellini with nettle). The pasta was definitely very unique and fresh. Loved the use of nettle which is pretty rare. The pizza was good but just a bit above average. Service was friendly and quick. We also ended the night with a chocolate dessert which was delicious. The looooong wait usually turns me off but would definitely like to come back and try some more things from the menu. I do like that they text you when your table is ready so you can wander around Hayes and get some aperitifs.
author: Yin H.

description: The service was fine but the portions were not. My boyfriend and I both left still feeling hungry. He actually had to get another dinner at Double Decker around the corner and I had to eat left over salmon that I had in my refrigerator. I understand that this is a first world problem but I still expect to feel like I have eaten after spending quite a bit of money at a restaurant. I also didn't like that I wasn't allowed to add chicken or anything else to the pasta I ordered.
author: Loren F.

description: I was so pleased with my visit to A Mano!  The interior is well designed and the tables are spaced so you are not sitting on top of the table next to you.  There is outside seating with heaters that border the exterior.  We started with splitting the small (mind you it was bigger than small) romaine salad along with one small carafe of white and one small carafe of red house wine.  It was very fresh and perfectly dressed!  For my main course I ordered the fried chicken special.  It was so delicious and tender and it sat in a bed of creamy polenta, a side of arugula and TWO sunnyside fried eggs ($17).  My husband ate half of my dish as it was so much food.  He ordered the pappardelle with ragu and it was simply amazing - their pasta is handmade and you can watch them make it in the open kitchen.  The prices are very very reasonable and the waitstaff very friendly.  We went on a Saturday around 11:45 a.m. and to our surprise there was no wait and plenty of tables.  I saw many other dishes that we want to return and try next time - can't wait!!
author: Ginger O.

description:
Food was OK, small portions. Cauliflower was bland, buccatini so-so. Bad service. Asked waiter for a side of parmesan, and they acted like they've never heard of it. Then we asked for fresh black pepper and the waiter snorted and said very rudely 'anything else I can get for you?' with a snide tone. Clearly not sure what the role of a waiter does. 

SF has a very low idea of what good Italian food is. This place will appeal to the casual diner wjo wants to look chic, but its an empty experience.

Don't like the Super Duper family. If i had known they were related I definitely wouldn't go. How can a burger cook understand Italian food? The food is made with the same flavor profile and skills of a burger cook. Their burgers are bland too and also the same small portions. 

Also, very loud restaurant.
author: Johnny B.

description:
Honestly, a 3.5 but rounded up. 

A Mano is a surprisingly large Italian spot for Hayes valley. We came on a Thursday evening and were seated immediately. The place had very nice service. I thought all the pasta and pizza dishes were very good, but certainly on the smaller size relative to the price. The Godfather was a good drink, and they did a really great job with the chocolate dessert dish. 

A good place to come for a nice dinner, but expect to slightly overpay if you plan to get very full.
author: Nikita K.

description: Excellent Italian restaurant. It is usually crowded but it is worth the waiting. The price are acceptable considering the quality of the food. I tried the chocolate budino, the pasta with ham and tomato and calamari. All these were very good. Will definitely come back!
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description: First visit to what I'm certain is going to be a regular stop. Server recommended a lemony fusilli that was amazing and exactly what I was wanting.
author: Robert M.

description:
Wow, just wow. Hayes valley managed to open a trendy but non-pretentious, delicious but affordable restaurant with great service. I didn't get our waiters name but he was animated, enthusiastic, even when we arrived in the closing hour. He was attentive, gave honest recommendations and got us excited about the food.

We stumbled in after Warriors finals game looking for a meal. And I'm glad we did. We ordered the fontina antipasto: delicious. And the focaccia bread. Also the seasonal pizza which had asparagus and we added an egg-- to die for. I couldn't believe how good that was. The Margherita pizza melts in your mouth and tastes fresh as ever. We also got the bucatini which was amazing but not as good as the pizza.  

We are definitely coming back. Thanks for a great night a Mano!
author: Anthony G.

description: Always a delightful experience. Come ready for an adventure of flavor and hungry! You cannot go wrong and keep exploring, remember BYOB and cash only!
author: Kaitlyn H.

description:
Came here for Saturday night dinner, place was packed when we arrived at 7pm. Asked for a table of two and they told me 1hour wait. Went to grab a beer close by and never got a call, came back at around 1 hour and 15 mins and they said another 30 mins. We still waited. 

Once we were finally got a table everything was perfect and really good service. We started with a beet and a cocktail which arrived very fast. The sausage pizza was delicious, and we got the pesto pasta and the clam pasta which were also very good.

Pesto pasta needed maybe a little bit more flavor, but we still ate everything.

Really recommend this place, sadly their waiting list situation is not the best yet, but I understand since they just opened. I hope they either take reservations or get a better tool to estimate time.
author: Carlos P.

description: 4stars for food and service. Foods are good and service is great. One star missing because of the drink, cocktails are good but take forever. Cocktails should be served before meal not after meal.
author: Angkana P.

description: My date and I came into a Mano with an odd special request for our special occasion, and our lovely server Kristina was very helpful and accommodating. Highly recommended.
author: Skylar G.

description:
I gave a 3 star, only because it was so loud our party of six could not hear each other at all, and being seated closely next to others who were yelling to be heard didn't help.  The food is great,reasonable and service is competent, except for the ridiculous point of not letting 5 people sit when sixth is parking, especially delivered with a 'tude...

Disappointing when you are meeting friends & can't hear them.. with speakers blaring also. Whatever happened to ambience ? 

I have heard lunch is better, or perhaps outside, but the present ongoing construction prohibits that. 

But every dish was delicious...
author: Jean S.

description: I was expecting so much more of this place. The service and the restaurant itself was great, love the space and the decor. However the food was just okay, nothing special. With so many Italian options in SF I'm not sure I'll come back.
author: Daniela C.

description:
This place gets 3 stars from me because the service was not friendly at all and the food was nothing special. It wasn't absolutely terrible but I won't go back.

The wait was about 45 minutes for 2 at 10pm on a Friday so we decided to grab a drink and appetizer at the bar. The bartender was way too arrogant for the mediocre drinks he was making. Like come on you're pouring lemon juice concentrate out of a squeeze bottle into my drink.. you have no reason to be acting like you're the best bartender I'll ever have. 

A server dropped off our food just as we were getting up to be seated and instead of just taking it to our table he plopped it down on the counter. Not a big deal but it's really the little things that count when serving guests.

Once our food came (after a really long time) the server didn't even bother to come back and ask us how everything was or wanted to order anything else. 

All in all I wanted to like this place because the atmosphere looked great and the menu items sounded really good but I probably won't be recommending it to anyone.
author: Simrat D.

description:
Stumbled upon a Mano when other nearby restaurants where closed on New Year's Day. 
We found delightful,straight forward plates with great flavors that do not rely on salt or sugar to pop. Simple yet complex food. Great space, clean and just a nice place to have dinner. Wonderfully pleasant surprise!!
author: mica g.

description: Everything about a Mano is perfection. We ended up sitting at the bar and the bartender was so sweet and so knowledgeable about the food. We ordered the cauliflower and it was AMAZING. We also got the mushroom pizza which was really good but the show stealer was definitely the Bolognese pasta. It was UNREAL. I really enjoyed everything there if you are in Hayes Valley stop by for sure.
author: Jazlyn H.

description: Very fun spot. Delicious pasta! Great cocktails. The wait is long so be prepared to hang out.
author: Emily J.

description: Good spot to eat and drink, and food prices are not outrageous. Dining room gets lots of natural light.  I had pasta here and a salmon dish, both very good.  Good selection of beer and wine.  Service is very good.  Only complaint is the bar has too damn much Campari.  Why?
author: James H.

description: All of their pasta dishes were incredibly delicious, and if you can, I would recommend gathering a group of friends and doing it *family style*. It was a great way to sample all of the pastas (how can anyone honestly have an easy time making a decision here?), and I was impressed by the quality and flavor of all of them!
author: Justina E.

description: Cute spot for date night!  Came here around 8PM for dinner on a Saturday with my husband and waited about 30 min to be seated.  We ordered a bottle of red wine to pair with their Margherita Pizza and Bucatini Pasta.  The Bucatini was delicious and so full of flavor.  The Margherita Pizza was not impressive, it fell apart as soon as I broke off the first slice!  Definitely think this place would be great for groups as you can order more items to share.  Overall, great and lively environment.  Highly recommend!
author: Jann B.

description: If you like Pasta Pomodoro remixed, incredibly slow service, and a lively people-watching scene at both lunch and dinner, then have I got the Italian eatery for you...
author: Nish N.

description: Food was good, although I thought selection could have been broader.  The service was friendly and nice.  However, seating outside was very uncomfortable.  The benches and stools not conducive to sitting and enjoying a meal
author: Buddy Boy D.

description: I decided to take my sister to this restaurant for her birthday. We were both really hungry so we ordered our appetizer right away.  We got the beet and arugula salad with hazelnuts. The salad was perfect; the beets were fresh and the hazelnuts, gorgonzola and paired really well with them. The entrees arrived to the table right after we finished with the appetizers. Per our waiter recommendation we got the Duck Yolk Ravioli special and the Tagliatelle Pesto. The ravioli was perfection; it had a gamey/tangy flavor and the sauce was just perfect. The Tagliatelle was also delicious. The pasta was fresh and the sauce was the traditional pesto sauce, although it was a bit oily and had nuts. But that's how I like it. Overall a very good experience, It won't take much time till I come back.
author: Bradley C.

description:
I always wanted to come here but could not get here early enough so we don't have to wait in line. They don't take reservations but move really fast.
Got here at 5:10 and by 5:40, most all tables including the bar were taken. 
Loved the cauliflower dish. Kids loved it too. Also the fried  rice ball. What was it called? It had squash purée in it. Probably seasonal but delicious!
Special was pork wrapped with pork belly. Yummy!!
Tried the squash ravioli and bolognese pasta. Pizza crust is really thin. A bit too thin for my preference but sauce was delicious. Price is really reasonable. Highly recommended.
author: Akiko I.

description: We came on a thurs night around 7, grabbed a high top outside and waited about 30 mins to get a dinner table. Great wine list that was reasonably priced, and food was overall great as well. We had the walla cabbage pizza, which had this funky stinky cheese on it that was really delicious, along with the kale mushroom tagliatelle that was buttery and light and delicious. We also had the tomato, cucumber, avocado salad that I would skip next time, it was pretty average. Along with a $30 carafe of wine, we spent about $50 each for the two of us which was pretty reasonable for the portions and quality. Only complaint is the tables were very tiny, should maybe invest in those high pizza holders.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
EXCELLENT EXPERIENCE! 

I went here on Saturday with my two girl friends. We put in our name at 7:30pm and were told that the wait would be 2 hours, which is long, but we were totally fine with getting some cocktails next door to pass the time. Luckily for us, we were notified that a table was ready after waiting for just an hour! 

We were BLESSED to have Luis as our server. Honestly I'd eat dog food on the side of the road if Luis was serving it to me. He was SO attentive, fun, friendly, etc etc etc etc Luis for president basically. 

But of course this wasn't dog food, it was incredibly fresh and inventive Italian. We ate the arancini, bianca pizza, tagliatelle, and bucatini--I whole-heartedly recommend it all. Luis brought us out the cauliflower appetizer as well, which I think was my favorite part of the whole meal.

Long story short, food was amazing, service was amazing, Luis is amazing, GO HERE!
author: Leah G.

description: Love, Love, Loved this restaurant.  Can't say anything bad about the restaurants in the Beretta family.  I'm a total pasta (carb) lover. I have the pasta maker, and love pasta but often find that it's way over priced in the city.  Loved that a Mano has a variety of pasta types and they are so good. We go the agnolotti which I loved, although the bucattini was good too. The squid appetizer was another favorite of ours.  It was a rough week and I was in dire need of a drink.  The drinks were good, but I would say I like Beretta's better ..maybe we'll have to come back when they revise their cocktail menu.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Great housemade pasta.  The squid ink spaghetti and rigatoni clam pastas were very good.  The wild arugula salad was delicious.  The duck mousse bread apps was not very good.

Large place with outdoor seating.  Service was fast.  The best part was that the cost was very reasonable.  Would definitely go again even with the long wait.
author: Dan K.

description:
4/5 stars. A Mano is the new hot restaurant in town because anytime you come here it's always a 30+ minute wait for a table! The lesser rating is mainly for crowd control and the hostess who was managing seating. Pasta for this price point and quality cannot be beat. I went with a large group of six after work and arrived around 6pm. There was only bar seating available without a wait, but the hostess religiously follows the "whole party must be present to be seated". I understand that restaurants want to maximize diners, but I honestly felt it was a bit rude that the hostess forgot that we had been waiting outside for a good 30 minutes for the other half of our party who was stuck in traffic to arrive and asked if I had put my name down for a reservation. I almost had a heart attack because she had told me that I was "in line for the bar seating once my party arrived". This was the main detraction from my experience at a Mano given I had been so excited to eat here for several weeks. 

[Dinner]
A very reasonably priced restaurant with huge and fresh pasta portions. We got the focaccia with the olive spread for the table and the bread was great. I got the bucatini dish and for $15 dollars, the portion was huge. Most of my coworkers did not finish their entrees. The pasta was very fresh and cooked al dente how I prefer my pasta. The sauce was a little salty, but definitely complemented the pasta very well. 

[Drinks]
We split a bottle of the Montepulciano and at $32 was the cheapest bottle on the menu. However, I thought the wine tasted great and was really a value split in our group of six. There is also a great selection of wines and cocktails to choose from. If you can get here early enough, this would be a great date spot! 

[Service] 
Service was fast and attentive. We probably got our food less than ten minutes after we placed our order.

Definitely worth trying if you're able to secure a table without a two hour wait and an amazing addition to Hayes Valley!
author: Alice Z.

description: Given how long the lines here always are - I honestly thought this place would be overrated. Since my cousin was visiting one weekend though, I succumbed and put my name down for an hour wait. It wasn't so bad cause we went next door to Anina to sit on the outdoor deck and try their delicious passion fruit beer. In an hour, we beaded back to a Mano and it was absolutely worth the wait. The focaccia was crispy and fluffy at the same time and went beautifully with the olive oil and tapenade. The pizzas were subtle but super flavorful and the pasta was probably the best I've had in SF. For two of us (with drinks and dessert) the bill was finally $65 which I thought was really reasonable. Will definitely come back!
author: Sam M.

description:
What a disappointment! I live a few blocks away and was so excited for this place, but I can't get over how rude the staff is. The food overall is good, some dishes even great. But you have to put up with people who have an incredible level of arrogance. 

I've gone on two separate occasions, both times the hostesses were the worst. Wait staff was hit or miss, not very attentive, but maybe just overworked. And beware, if you don't finish your dish, they will give you a hard time about taking it to go. Heaven forbid you ask to have something boxed up!
author: Carlynn A.

description:
Service was terrible- minus one server (mustache).
Food was mediocre.
Drinks were mediocre.
Wait wasn't worth the while.
author: Dustin B.

description:
We went to a mano just before heading to the symphony hall. It is so hard to get good food in this neighborhood without it being overpriced. A Mano was a sweet surprise with great homemade pasta made every day on site! The restaurant encourages family style and we (2 people) shared 2 antipasti, one pasta and a dessert. Cocktails were probably the highlight of this place!

We walked in without a reservation and had a table immediately!
author: Muriel T.

description: Since moving to Hayes Valley I've been absolutely loving A Mano. Definitely the top 3 restaurants in the city for me personally. Every time I have been to A Mano, the pastas were delicious (they change their menu from time to time), cocktails were great, and ambiance pleasant. I love their buchwheat mushroom pasta and the kale pesto they at lunch. It's a fantastic spot for the price! I'm a happy customer and will definitely be back more than once.
author: Luba Y.

description:
Too bad they don't do reservation because the wait is ridiculous! However, the service and the food were outstanding. Came here for a girlfriend's birthday in a group of 7 and did family style. We ordered a lot to try and still the bill came out to be $44 per person including the birthday girl's share and a bottle of Pinot Grigio. For starts we had:

- cauliflower with lemon, chili, bagna cauda: deliciously healthy and crispy - lots of flavor on the surface but the inside of the cauliflower lacked, but I still enjoyed it.
- Monterey squid, corn, roman-esco, shishito peppers: loved the flavor in the corn and squid! Full squid pieces went well with the corn and it's small kick of spice. Would reorder!
- arugula, stone fruit, Gorgonzola, hazelnut and pickled shallots: delicious and refreshing! Loved the peaches and the mixture of texture in this dish. Love arugula and would recommend.
- Margherita pizza: delicious with the egg on top. Thin crust and perfectly enough for everyone to try a slice before moving onto entrees.

Main courses:
- tagliatelle pesto with pine nuts: this one lacked flavor compared to our other pasta dishes. My least favorite.
- spaghettini with clams: second to least favorite but had crispy bits on top that added texture to the dish. Also not that flavorful but still enjoyed it as it was lighter than the other pasta options and became a good balance.
- rigatoni with pork: one of my favored dishes and recommend ordering! Rich in flavor with delicious melted Parmesan on top.
- gemelli with lamb sausage: surprisingly my favorite dish when I don't eat lamb! It was not gamey in flavor at all and had the richest flavor out of all of them. I highly recommend this dish.
- bucatini with tomatoes and pancetta: also very delicious for a usual pasta dish. In my top three :)
- Bavette steak: very tender and perfectly sliced for everyone to grab a piece. I suggest pastas over this dish if you had to remove something.

Desserts:
- pistachio gelato: my favorite dessert of the night. Strong legit pistachio flavor with real pistachio pieces all around :)
- strawberry sorbetto: my second favorite with a sweet and tart strawberry flavor among strawberry bits
- Nutella sundae: one of my least favorite dessert of the 4, because it wasn't anything special or different.
- buttermilk panna cotta: perfectly sweet and had strawberry bits on top. Third favorite :)

We left satisfied and not overly full. Great spot to do family style :)
author: Amanda C.

description: Everything I ordered here from appetizers to the main dishes were too salty. Mind you, I don't like bland testing food but I also don't want to eat food bathed in salt. The service was meh too.
author: Amina A.

description: Loved it. Will definitely be back. Went for brunch and split the Arugula & Beet Salad, Chicken Meatballs & Salsiccia Pizza. I would definitely rate each dish as a 5/5. Service was great and the space was very pleasant.
author: Emily K.

description:
I was in town for a convention.  I been wanting to eat Porchetta.  I found this restaurant that makes them every Saturday.  Talk about lucky.  I ordered it without delay.

The waitress was really nice, I didn't get her name (sorry!) since it was loud inside.

The porchetta arrived and I dug into it.  It was very juicy and crispy.  Perfect dinner.
author: Bryan S.

description: I honestly was expecting more. The seating arrangement is pretty cafeteria like, it also pretty dark. The drinks are really good, but the service is below mediocre. The appetizers were better than the main courses. We had a party of 6, no one was impressed enough to consider coming back.
author: Jessica B.

description: Wow. Just wow. The cocktails alone should tell you that this place is not playing around. It's hard for a restaurant to have amazing cocktails and equally amazing food. A Mano just kills it. Think homemade pastas with interesting yet relatable ingredients and craft cocktails that will rival the best of them i.e. Bourbon and Branch, Trick Dog, Beretta (a sister restaurant), The Hideout at Dalva, ABV, etc etc. Just go.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Italian is one of my favorite cuisine. Their pasta is homemade and love the ambience. This is a good place to bring your date and enjoy some good food. Service was amazing as well. Definitely coming back to a Mano again!! 
Thank you guys
author: Bimarsh S.

description:
I've been searching for a reasonably priced pasta place (thinking of Il Corvo in Seattle), so I was super excited to hear about a Mano. 

The first time we tried to come a few weeks ago, it was a 2.5 hour wait on a Saturday.  Then we tried coming on Burning Man Sunday at 4:55pm, and there were only 15 people or so ahead of us in line. By around 5:40pm, the restaurant filled up for the first round.  When we left around 7pm, the line was pretty long.

I came on a mission for pasta, but they had pretty good drinks with an Italian flare.
- Sirena: grapefruit, vodka based, refreshing, very light
- Wallbanger: vodka based with mango, also good for summer 
- Godfather: spirit driven, strong, with a hint of almond (like an old fashioned)

Antipasti: 
- Monterey squid: baby squid sitting on top of summer corn with various colored shishitos and a romanesco sauce.  I thought the squid could have used a bit more salt, but the corn was amazingly fresh and sweet 

Pastas:
- Tagliatelle: fresh pasta, on the thinner side, with pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes (sliced thin), and pine nuts. I thought the haricot verts and potato were an interesting touch 
- Paccheri: I got this for the early early pomodoro, but the cherry tomatoes were also great, and the pasta texture was just right. It also came with flash fried eggplant, and capers all worked really well
- Torchetti: spiral pasta with house made lamb sausage, broccoli di ciccio, olives, garlic, chili. This one was a flavor bomb - I liked it a lot

We were tempted to get the agnolotti and rigatoni, but it was a super warm day, and those felt more like winter pastas. 

The pizzas looked pretty good, but the pasta seemed better.  They do thin crust pizza, but the crust wasn't as thin as at some other Neapolitan places.

The staff was really friendly, and despite the crowd outside, they don't make you feel rushed.

Also, every pasta was $14-16, which is very reasonable for SF.  The pizzas ranged from only $12 for the Margherita to $16.  Overall, it was really reasonably priced as far as SF pasta/pizza goes.  

Would I wait 2 hours?  No, but I would wait up to 30 min.  Coming right around opening time worked out well to sit in the first wave of diners.   I think you can actually put your name down and come back when your table is ready.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
They've opened a few months ago so two of my friends and I decided to go check it out. Oh man, the only thing I regret is that I haven't heard of this place before. 
We ordered fungi pizza and pasta tagliatelle alla bolognese. Words can't truly describe the taste so I recommend everyone to check out a Mano if you re going to Hayes Valley.
I want to thank Cristina for awesome service and beautiful smile.
author: Mark K.

description:
Great homemade pasta and wine selection! Looks like they have a really solid cocktail bar too. We got the squid and bean antipasti. Very good. Also ordered the pasta with clams and garlic sauce, and one with red sauce and pancheta. Some of the best pasta I've had. 

I recommend this place for cocktails, small plates or light dinner.
author: Evan S.

description:
No reservation, no problem. Came in on a Thursday night around 7/7:30 looking for a table for two and were seated almost instantly - at a communal table, next to a family with young children. Not ideal for date night. I talked to one of the hostesses and asked if there was literally anything else and she was able to help us out.

Finally at our own table we had he lost friendly server! Kind, funny and attentive. My boyfriend and I each got he rigatoni with pork sugo - one of our faves and it was delicious. You can tell how fresh this pasta is! For drinks he got a beer and I got a wall banger - definitely recommend. Not too sweet and refreshing for sure. We finished off with pistachio gelato for dessert. Definitely worth a try!
author: Cara S.

description:
I had dinner with my family of four and was disappointed with our experience. 
Although the atmosphere and new building offer a nice modern setting the food did not live up to our expectations. The orecchiette was watery and bland and although the other dishes ok nothing stood out. Oh and I understand having small portions but it's not chic or cool to put three pieces of lettuce on plate and charging 13$ for it. 
If you are going to compete in SF and charge that kind of money for dinner you simply can't serve mediocre food.
author: Philip H.

description:
It's more like 3.5 stars. 

It's exciting to finally see a place dedicated to handmade pasta. You can taste the freshness but I didn't feel like the food lived up to the hype. My hubby had the tagliatelle and I had the spaghetti with clams. The food is usually what drives up my rating and I can't bring myself to give it 4. The service and ambience is great and the prices are beyond reasonable. Reasonable enough for me to try again and hopefully change it to 4 or even 5 stars. Lots of potential.
author: Z C.

description: A mano- made by hand; and that's what this spot does! Their in high demand so expect a wait during peak hours but it is well worth it. I started with a wallbanger cocktail, moved right into an heirloom tomato, cucumber, and avocado salad that was fresh and seasoned well (Some amazing blend of citrus, salt, pepper and pine nuts). I finished off with the bucatini (that had a. Ice touch of pork and pecorino). The pasta was amazing and the sauce light enough to follow up the salad. Unfortunately, I didn't have room for dessert but perhaps next time...
author: Lyndsay M.

description: Amazing!! I could have had seconds of each last night! The pasta absolutely melted in my mouth. The pizza was perfection!! My drink was splendid! I can't wait to go back. Going to try ALL the pasta dishes on the menu #goals!! Thank you!!
author: Karen J.

description:
I tried this place because it had such good reviews and found it really underwhelming. The price was really reasonable but the food was bland and nothing special. I'm struggling to understand the hype and how people were waiting for more than an hour by 5:30p.

My friend and I shared the duck liver mousse, margherita pizza, and clam pasta. The duck liver was good and the other two weren't bad but not really good either.
author: Elle Y.

description: Uhhh, I came back from Italy a little less than a month ago, so maybe I'm being too judgey, but this place is highly overrated. Prices are hard to beat, for sure, but there are definitely better places. The focaccia had chili flakes on it, which I didn't love and a lot of the food was on the bland side. We got a lamb pasta and a summer squash pizza. The pizza crust is pretty on point, and maybe the margarita would have been better. Probably not worth going back, but i wonder if there was something I missed as well.
author: Annie S.

description: We went for lunch over the weekend. We both got pasta dishes. They were both exquisite! The food, the service, the experience - all pretty fantastic! I will be back!
author: Rita S.

description:
I was rooting for this place, especially after the hype I was seeing on Instagram. I hope they are just working out the kinks. I'm a huge pasta and wine lover, so I was really hoping for some magic.

After reading some reviews, I laughed because everyone from a couple months ago was complaining about the lack of salt. Maybe my experience was in direct response to that? Our pasta was so outrageously salty, we couldn't finish either dish.

Aside from the abundance of salt, the bucatini and tagliatelle pasta itself was fine If not a bit soft, but I was really disappointed in the sauces. So bland.

The gem salad with anchovies was solid, that adds a star on its own. The two itty bitty anchovy slices however, deduct it back. The ratio was two tiny bites on a salad big enough for two people. Aranchinis we're fine, as it's pretty hard to dislike a fried cheesy dish.

The wine choices were a little off. My first glass was definitely spoiled (maybe because the wine on the wall is in the sun during the day?) and when I politely apologized and asked the bartender about it, he just said "that's the way it tastes" without even bothering to check. It was a wine that I personally drink a lot and enjoy, so I was a little put off by his response as if I just didn't know better. He did pour me a new glass of something else, so water under the bridge.

There are a lot of solid Italian spots in the city, so I won't be returning but wish them luck improving.
author: Haley J.

description:
A great addition to Hayes Valley! 

- My fiancé and I came in on a Saturday night. We had to wait an hour for a table but there's so much to see/do in the area and we weren't on a time crunch so it was fine with us. 
- We were seated at the round green tables by the windows. The tables were spaced well where I didn't feel cramped and didn't have to squeeze out cautiously when I got up from my seat since I sat on the window side of table. 
- Great drinks! We had The Godfather and a manhattan. 
- Our waitress Alexa was wonderful. She was super polite and enthusiastic. 
- Food was yummy! We ordered the cauliflower, tagliatelle with pesto, fava beans, and pine nuts, and the spicy sausage pizza. 
- My favorite was the cauliflower - the spicy peppers gave the dish a great kick. I enjoyed the tagliatelle,  but adding some fresh basil would have brought out the flavors to the dish much more. Same goes for the pizza. 

Decent prices, good drinks & food, and ambiance. The restaurant was loud but not so much that I couldn't hear myself. Drinks took a while to come.
Overall, our bill for 2 drinks, appetizer, pizza, and pasta with tip came out to be $80.  I would definitely return if I was the area.
author: katrina c.

description: The pasta here reminds me the one I got from Naples!! So good!! And it has the crisp side!
author: Yuliana Z.

description:
I came to a Mano after reading about it in the SF Chronicle. This restaurant deserves to be lauded for its great service, its excellent food, and the aforesaid done with reasonable prices. Executive chef Freedom Rains creates quality pasta; pasta that is light, delicious, and fresh reflecting the undemanding summer weather of San Francisco. The drink choices reflect the pasta and combined with the atmosphere, produces a superb dining experience.

The spaghettini had a nice balance of acidity and spice. Though I thought the combination of clams and bread crumbs would be an odd choice, the dish came together to create a meal that excelled expectations.

The agnolotti dal plin were bites of flavor that deserved savoring. The parmesan, speckled like little snowflakes on top, started melting onto the pasta. However, before they even had the chance to melt, they were gone. 

Italian cuisine faces constant scrutiny on tradition versus reinvention, or heavy sauce versus a lighter Spaghetti Aglio e Olio. Many restaurants sway towards the former in both categories, but a Mano tries to break the norm.  While lighthearted and simple on the outside, the meal is complex on the subterranean level, reflecting the food norms and values changing in the Bay Area.
author: Shounak C.

description:
Our new favorite Italian restaurant. They don't take reservations and the restaurant seems to fill up pretty early. All of the dishes are reasonably priced which allows you to try several dishes.

Mixed Spring Vegetable Salad - 5 stars (I would definitely order this again)
Fritto Misto - 4 stars (generous portions of fried shrimp and squid)
Tagliatelle Pesto - 4 stars
Spaghettini w/ Clams - 5 stars
Bucatini - 5 stars

I will definitely be back again.
author: Lester W.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for the past month and finally made it there. They sure did not disappoint and food was awesome. My favorite was the spaghettini, rigatoni with pork, short ribs, and little gem salad. The short ribs just melted in your mouth. I can't wait to go back and try the other dishes!!
author: Mary L.

description:
The antipasti and cocktails were great! I would definitely come back for drinks and snacks. The prices were very reasonable too. 

The main pasta courses is where I have to deduct 2 stars. I ordered the agnolotti and it had no flavor. I initially thought it was sitting in broth, but I think it was supposed to be cheese sauce. Others ordered the bucatini which was nice. The pasta itself was great, the sauce had a good flavor, but too watery again. The tagliatelle was the most flavorful, but very pesto forward. 

Conclusion: they have lots of good things going, but the sauces are off. The prices were friendly. The ambience and service was great. The wait is insane (2.5 hours on a Saturday night).
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I need to clarify the 3 star rating.  If I were rating strictly presentation, texture, flavor:  totally 5 stars.  If I were rating portion sizes:  1 star!
I ordered the special on the lunch menu that day, which was a risotto served on a small round plate and layered so thin it was almost opaque.  I'm not a heavy eater either.  For example, I BBQ'd a slab of baby back ribs last night and my plate consisted of two ribs, half a sweet potato, and a few ounces of bacon-braised brussel sprouts.  

My friend ordered a pizza and that was generously sized.  Looking around the room, I noticed the pasta dishes were typically lightly portioned.  I can only assume these were meant as appetizers and not considered entrees.  Although the prices indicated entrée.  After lunch, I stopped at Fatted Calf for a snack to fill me up.
author: Art W.

description:
Took my wife tonight for a casual dinner as she'd just flown home from an overseas trip. a Amano is a short walk for us so pretty low effort and we figured if they were too busy we could go to one of the many other places in the neighborhood. Anyway, we got there at about 6:30 and it looked really busy so we didn't expect to get seated right away but were offered one of the communal tables which was just fine. 
Waiter showed up promptly and took our drink order. Despite them seeming really busy he took the time to thoroughly describe all the pasta dishes for me. Then he helped me decide between the two I'd narrowed it down to ( so, if it's going to be your last meal... which one?) My wife ordered the nightly special  which was braised short ribs with greens, carrots and onions.  I went with the tagliatelle al ragu. We also ordered the beet salad. The salad came out promptly and was delicious. I really love beets but these golden beets were exceptional. 
As for our entrees, the short ribs were amazing the knife provided was certainly there for show as a fork was all that was needed. Probably the best short ribs we've had amazing flavor and the vegetables were cooked nicely al dente.  My pasta dish was also really good, great flavor and the pasta was perfect. Fresh made pasta really makes a difference. Only thing that would have made it better would have been a little more meat in the sauce but I can say that about most any pasta dish. 
My second choice would have been the seafood pasta and a few of the folks around us ordered it, looked really good If we'd been there with another couple I'd have ordered one just to share it was that tempting. 
Will have to make it back before they change up the menu. Great food, great service and really decent prices. Love this place.
author: don l.

description:
I'm a fan!  Reasonably priced bottles and food. Love the atmosphere and service on point. Dinner for 2 - $100 (includes bottle of Syrah, 1 main plus 3 sides/appetizers).

- The Raspberry cocktail is so delicious!  Think it's the Rossini? I can drink this again and again.

- Do get the duck river mousse with extra crostini!
author: Judy K.

description:
App: 
arancini, cold sauce...but the arancini itself was great just wish they'd put in the "extra" effort of heating up the sauce.

Main: 
spaghetitini with clams - not spaghetitini just regular spaghetti, also super salty

Parpadelle with peas was great wish I'd gotten that instead...

Layout: very tight/"cozy" by that I mean I had the waiter's ass rubbing on my arm 3 times as he leaned over to pour the wine for the table next to us.  I had to lean away as he bent over to explain the menu for the table next to us.

Sound: loud like any other sf restaurant moreso due to the proximity of the tables.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
We were looking for a place open late night after a show we attended and a mano came up in our search. 

The place was still crowded  at 11 pm and we found a waiter to seat us. We asked for vegetarian options and were recommended the  fusilli verde ,  fontina arancini . Both of these were fantastic. Service was decently paced -- the appetizer came after the main dish - not a big deal , just a little surprising. 

They ran out of the chocolate dessert we wanted . Overall, great food, very friendly waiters. 

Just wish they would have more vegetarian options - or offer to make some of the pastas vegetarian .
author: aditi g.

description: We need to boycott places like this. Delarosa in the marina is another. "We have communal seating cause it's what makes us, us!" This is absolute crap. No one actually prefers to sit right next to a complete stranger. They seated us right smack in the middle of two parties when there were tons of other seating available. Way too close for comfort. Food was good tho. However, I'm convinced that they put laxatives in our food for asking to be moved. My girlfriend and I immediately got the runs before leaving the restaurant. Both had to shit. Bathroom was nice tho lol so not too mad about it. 3 stars on the whole experience.
author: Matt R.

description: Fantastic food, I was lucky to stumble upon this place while shopping on Hayes street and needing some food. I was able to grab a place at the bar with a friend and the cocktails were really good. I ordered the special of the day, short ribs on top of the best polenta I've ever had and my friend ordered the tagliatelle with pesto, so good. I grabbed a card when I left and looked up this place on line and was delighted to discover that the chef used to work at Flour + Water, now I know I can get great Italian food without a reservation if I come here at 5:00 when they open.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
I've been to a Mano a few times now and really love the pasta. It's reasonably priced for the exceptional quality, and all the dishes are super filling. The first two times I went, shortly after it opened, I didn't have to wait, and this time we were quoted for 1.5 hours for a table for 2 but were able to find seats at the bar.

I'm writing this review for the EXCEPTIONAL service at the bar. Midway through dinner with my friend, a man decided to wedge himself between me and the party to my right. We were two groups of two women, and this man was really invading my personal space--trying to sit on the stool with me. I asked him to move a few times, and the bartender took note and told the man that he could see the menu and be served at the end of the bar. 

When the guy moved, I asked the two girls to my right if he were part of their group, they said no. After getting his drink, the guy reappeared between us, and the bartender once again intervened by firmly telling the man he had to stand at the end of the bar and not between people because it infringes their personal space. 

Mr. No Personal Space moved, lurked around, and then reappeared on the other side of my friend. This time another staff member came over and checked in with us, asked the check for Mr. Stranger-Danger, dumped out his drink, and stood by us until he left. 

I'm writing this review because I greatly appreciate the level of attentiveness by the bartenders and staff. I often feel that I have to fend off these uncomfortable advances on my own, but at a Mano, the staff were very aware of the situation and took appropriate measures to address the issues as they continued and developed. I felt that the staff responded well to assure us that they were aware and made sure we knew they were willing to intervene and take care of the situation.

This place is one of my favorite new restaurants in San Francisco, but after this experience, I'll be sure to visit this place many many times in the future. Thank you, a Mano!
author: Sara F.

description: Great pasta and reasonable prices. We had the bucattini and agnolotti, and both were fantastic. The monterey squid appetizer was amazing as well -- full of flavor and cooked perfectly tender. The cauliflower was great as well. Cocktails were a bit hit-or-miss, but decent for the most part. This the same ownership as Beretta/Delarosa/Starbelly, so many of the menu items overlap with those locations, but the pasta here is what separates it from the rest of their restaurants. Overall, a solid meal!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Wait time - 45 min on a thurs night....bad 
Wine - not bad 
Squid appetizer - REALLY good (not amazing)
Pasta Bucatini Amatriciana - REALLY good (not amazing) 
Pizza Margherita - average-not impressed at all. Crust was hard, not soft. Dough was flavorless. Uninteresting 
Dessert Nutella sundae - looks better than it tastes, did not live up to the hype
Service - bad, took forever to get wait staff attention 
Ambiance - bad, Too loud, too many people, tables too close to each other, lots of obnoxious people 
Overall....4 stars, primarily because of the squid and pasta. Will come back for just the pasta next time.
author: George T.

description: There was nothing special about the food or ambiance here. There are too many good Italian restaurants and for thin crust pizzas, there are plenty other that are better. This pizza crust was just too thin- even eating it immediately, it was soggy and paper thing the half near the point. The pasta was good and fresh but nothing wowed me. I didn't like the ambiance- way too noisy,smashed and chaotic
author: Piper W.

description:
Where do I begin? I've been planning on dining at a Mano since I first heard of it's opening - and after much convincing that the wait wouldn't be as long as they said, my boyfriend was on board. 

Everything. Was. Amazing.

We split a carafe of the house wine (cheap and delicious Sangiovese) the bucatini, a sausage pizza and dessert for a total of $70 with tip. Could there BE a better deal in Hayes Valley? On top of that - the food was GOOD. I was craving a pasta with red sauce and the bucatini was perfectly cooked. We even debated ordering another pasta dish after the meal because we wanted to try more things!
