I want this to be a weekly stop - and will likely start recruiting others to join me!
author: Ellie J.

description: We got the bucatini, the arancini and the mafaldine and am very confused on the high reviews at this place. Not one of the 3 dishes had any flavor at all. It's like they don't allow salt in this restaurant. The pancetta in the bucatini was very undercooked and chewy, I had to pick it out. For 2 people who never leave food on the plate, we didn't even finish our meals because they simply weren't worth it.
author: Sarah W.

description: I held my birthday dinner here and it was magical from beginning to end. Kate, our server was so gracious and engaging. She guided us on our menu choices and paired our drinks so well it seemed as if it was a planned, coursed meal. a Mano gets it right in how creatively it brings Italian cuisine to new utterly surprising and delicious places. By the end of the dinner we left feeling like we found our new top Italian spot with amazing staff.
author: James D.

description:
It's early, but I'm a big fan.  It's a happy, bustling place - seems a little chaotic at first but it's well-managed in there and they have everything under control.  Nice cocktail menu - classics and a few variations - very manageable and nothing ridiculous on there.  

Food menu is simple and straightforward, and all the dishes we had (cauliflower app, squid, app, pizza, and pasta) were well executed.  (Although I do like my pizza with a little char/blistering.  Next time I will ask for my pizza well done.)

Price points are very welcoming as well - our tab for 2 cocktails, 2 apps, carafe of wine, one pizza, and one pasta was $100 plus tip.  Very few places in the city where you can get a full meal of such high quality for that price.

I do wish they would take reservations, at least for part of the floor, especially in a neighbourhood with so many performance venues where a lot of guests might have a schedule to keep.  

But all in all it was big win all the way around, and I look forward to going back.
author: Catherine F.

description:
The hostess was rude and looked miserable which you shouldn't have as the first person who greets you as you come to the restaurant. 

Besides from the hostess and the 2 hour wait, the food and service from the manager and our waitress was worth it which is also why this is a 5 star review. 
The manager stopped by to check in on us since they had ran out two of the dishes we wanted and didn't charge us for dessert. Extremely thoughtful and good service. Definitely coming back to try their porchetta!
author: Trang N.

description:
Contemporary look, quality ingredients, reasonable prices, great service!
We arrived when they opened and the place filled up quickly.  Our two appetizers were quite wonderful (arancini and cloud-like focaccia w/intense olive tapenade).  Our pasta entrees were fresh - the chestnut flour pasta is a rather unusual offering. Portion size seemed just right - not skimpy.  The gelato was not like one gets in Italy, but a refreshing conclusion to the meal.  The Thursday special of steak with a marrow bone at the neighboring table looked really good, as did the pizza. 
Great waiter!  Would definitely return.
author: Judi G.

description: The best part was the pizza which is ironic because they laud the home made pasta. The tagliatelle bolognese could have used more sauce. Ambiance was fun and festive.
author: Babz B.

description:
My new favorite Italian restaurant in the city! I went on Friday night with friends and waited for an hour and a half and were seated around 10pm, but it was well worth the wait. All of their pastas are made fresh and by hand (hence their name), and you can really tell they give a lot of care to the food they cook.

To start, we shared the squid with sweet corn and that was absolutely cooked to perfection. The savoriness of the squid was well balanced with the corn. I guess it's a popular item on their menu because we overheard a waiter tell people next to us that they were sold out of the squid soon after we had ordered ours.

We each ordered a different pasta, but we loved all of our choices. I personally had the bucatini all'amantriciana with pancetta and tomato sauce - the last time I had amantriciana that was that delicious was at Piccolo Buco in Rome. My sister opted for mostaccioli with braised tripe. Even if you're not a fan of tripe, I think anyone would like this pasta. One of my friends had agnolotti dal plin (which is like ravioli) with roast chicken and pork, which I personally thought was a little on the heavier side. He got hungry later on and had the tagliatelle with pesto. Not my favorite of the pastas we had, but it was quite refreshing to have, especially after eating so much food. Another friend had the spaghettini and clams - boy, do they give you A LOT of clams! It was good, but not the standout of the night, in my opinion.

We finally had dessert: my sister and I had the panna cotta and my friends shared the affogato. The panna cotta had the perfect jiggly texture and taste - highly recommend. I wasn't a fan of the espresso used for the affogato; it had a bit of an overextracted taste. If you  want dessert, I think the panna cotta would be a better choice than the affogato.

Overall, I'm a huge fan of a Mano and I will definitely be back to try other items on their menu! Shoutout to our waiter that night! I don't remember his name, but he gave us so many great recommendations and we enjoyed most of it.
author: Trisha V.

description:
In full disclosure, I went here the first week it opened +/- and was super underwhelmed, which is odd since I'm usually an Adriano Paganini fanboy.  We ordered four pastas, none of which wowed me, and the service was...ehh.  Water was dripping on us from an AC line, it wasn't a great experience.

However, I'm a huge believer that you shouldn't judge nor review a restaurant in its first few months, and this is why.  Our second trip to A Mano was seamless and just incredible.  They're up and running and in excellent form.

We ordered three pastas, the clam spaghettini, the pesto tagliatelle, and rigatoni with pork sugo.  We were also comped the focaccia for some reason.  For what it's worth, the three pastas were the perfect amount to split between two (hungry) people.  Each dish seems to have been tweaked slightly from the opening week, all for the better.

The clam spaghettini was perfect.  The clams were excellent, the dish had a nice kick to it while still remaining refreshing, I would get this again in a heartbeat.  The pesto tagliatelle was really fresh and flavorful, it needed a bit of salt though.  The rigatoni was ridiculous.  Just bursting with flavor.  The focaccia was probably the best I've ever had, amazing salt on top (I'm a salt fiend, admittedly).  We'd order all four dishes again, with the rigatoni and spaghettini being our favorites.  It was hot and we each ordered two glasses of the pinot noir sparkling rose.

I really wish we'd gotten our waiters name because he was excellent.  Funny, engaging, checked in the perfect amount of time.  

Three pastas and four glasses of rose set us back $80.  That's a total steal for SF.  If we had each had one pasta and one glass of wine, and weren't gluttonous alcoholics, the price point would have been unbeatable for this neighborhood.

We were seated right away but we arrived at 5:50 on a Thursday.  We had to wait the first time, but both Anina and Brass Tacks next door have great ambiance and are a fun place to wait, and they text/call you when your table is ready.

Already dreaming about going back -- this is the perfect fast casual spot that Hayes has needed.

The pizzas and the squid dish looked incredible...we'll be back to try those as well.
author: James S.

description: Oh my god, so good and fun!  I love the area - visiting from LA and for other LA natives, this area reminds me of silverlake.  Having been to Italy many times, I can say with complete confidence that the pasta here is delicious!  Arancini aren't completely authentic, but still tasty.  Cocktail was great - I had a grapefruit one, I think.  We had the lamb pasta and bucatini all'amatriciana and both really hit the spot.  Buttermilk panna cotta was the perfect way to end the meal.  In fact, I'm getting hungry again as I'm writing this.  Really hoping to go back and try some more on the menu during this trip!
author: Cindy L.

description:
We live close to Hayes and we were looking for some italian that night. We walked into Mano around 7pm and the wait was an hour. We put down our names and sat at the bar. 

I ordered the "Spritz" which reminded me of all the Spritz I had while in Venice last year. Its point on! 

We then got seated an hour later. We ordered: 
Margarita Pizza [5/5]: OMG this was amazing. Right amount of cheese, the ingredients tasted so fresh! 

Spagettini with Clams [4/5]: This was good but could have been better. The ingredients listed had chilli so I was hoping for more of a kick of spice in the flavors which it lacked. But the pasta is freshly made and the sauce was good too! Clams were cooked to perfection. 

Panna Cotta [4/5]: The panna cotta with strawberries and biscotti is heavenly. Its smooth and creamy and the strawberries add the right amount of flavor. The biscotti was a bit too crunchy. 

Overall the service is great and our waitress was really attentive. Its perfect for a date night. The vibe is classy. We'll be back! 

Priyanka.
author: Priyanka P.

description:
Came here with a friend after the movies and was craving some pasta for dinner. Found it on the map on the way home so we gave it a try. Apparently it had been open not more than a month when we went.

Overall, it was just very mediocre. Don't believe the hype and I'm not drinking the koolaid.

It wasn't overly busy but we were sat in the middle of the restaurant where staff and guests would brush by our chair every few minutes. The service was, ironically, a little overbearing and lacking at the same time with the waiter constantly reaching between us or moving stuff on our table but missing when we needed water or another drink. It was the service of a checked out career server where they ticked all the boxes but without actually paying attention and responding appropriately.

To start, we each got a serviceable, not necessarily enjoyable cocktails. It just didn't taste like the 'crafted' cocktails you would find at many other fine bars in SF, but rather a mix of alcoholic liquids like when experimenting at home, riffing off recipe and come up with a dud.

Apps started with the liver mousse and Monterey squid. 
Pate tasted like tinned stuff you get in holiday gift baskets, not much in the way of seasoning and served with 5 slices of oily grilled bread and a jam that didn't do much to complement. 
Squid lacked the briny pop that would've brought this dish together. It almost didn't make sense why it was served together as a result.

Mains were tagliatelle with pesto and mostaccioli with tripe.
Hard to mess up pesto and it ended up being the one dish we did like but it was like having pesto in a flavorless vessel. The pasta didn't speak for itself, its texture was slightly overcooked and the pesto just ever so slightly astringent. 
The mostaccioli was even more underwhelming, tasting similar to the romesco sauce with a healthy spoonful of salted pasta water. Anything offal piques my interest but barely any tripe was found to complement, used almost sparingly like garnish. Sauce didn't have much depth outside of a slight funk that could've just as well come from the cheese. The star ingredient could've shined but instead tasted very one note.

Your typical hyped restaurant in a popular neighborhood selling the idea of authenticity veiled in mediocrity. You come here mostly for a place to sit and fill your belly, not quite for a memorable meal or taste of home. My impression is that they were afraid of flavors and everything gets muddled as a result. Don't think we'll be coming back here.
author: Peel S.

description:
MUST TRY:
Rossilini - Prosecco with Elderflower and Strawberry ( I went to heaven for a minute with this drink)
Chicken Meatballs in Spicy Tomato Sauce
Any pasta dish on the menu.... their pastas are all made in house.

One of my new favorite Italian spots to hit in the Hayes Valley
author: Natalie W.

description:
A Mano was a delicious meal in a relaxed, modern environment. A few over-the-top positives:

- they offer half-bottles of wine
- they were happy to alter a dish to meet our needs!
author: Marissa K.

description:
The Focaccia was super yummy. The pizza was pretty good. The lamb pasta was very good. The squid was a bit bland. Serving sizes were legitimate, service was very annoyed with us because we didn't all arrive at the same time so they wouldn't seat us. Pricing was all reasonable which is terrific in the city.

Atmosphere was lovely.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Ate here a couple of weeks ago for a mamas night out. I live up the street so I was excited to try a new neighborhood restaurant. Me and my friends arrived at 7:45 pmish and the host told us it would be a two hour wait. But we got seated a little over an hour. The drinks were on point. My cocktail favorites (Vodka and Grapefruit) was excellent.
Salad was delicious. I liked my eggplant pasta dish more than the one with clams, but both were good. I am looking forward to trying a fish or chicken dish and pizza too when I come back. Panna cotta desert yummy. Comfortable, nicely designed space and service was great.
author: Camille S.

description:
Classy and vibrant, in a great area I really love this area in Hayes Valley, usually stop by for food or espresso on my way to the bridge game. Was able to be seated inside at the window walking in on a Thursday night by myself after work.

I would love to see a pizza/salad combo on the menu, perhaps a side salad or a half-pizza option? They didn't have it, so I just ordered a full salad and a full pizza. The vegetables were delectable, like farmer's market quality. Pizza was thin crust so I was able to finish it all. They gave me a full vase of water as well, which was just fantastic. Experienced prompt service and pretty yummy food overall.
author: Jakob Eats Alone ..

description:
My wife and I had dinner at A Mano yesterday.We were in the city to attend the SF Symphony. This was our first time at A Mano and our overall experience was excellent. Ryne was our server. He was helpful in explaining the menu and providing us with suggestions all of which turned out to be excellent. We shared the fried cauliflower appetizer. I had the Tagliatelle pasta dish and my wife had the Bucatini pasta dish. The pasta was fresh and cooked perfectly. Very tasty. We finished up with a cappuccino and split the apple crostata dessert. We plan to return when in Hayes Valley.

Richard F
Santa Rosa
author: Richard F.

description: I hate to say it, because the lines to get in annoy me, but this place was worth the wait and hype, from the fresh, simple, perfect pasta to the stylish wait staff.
author: Morris R.

description: What a menu! Everything we ordered was exceptional, and the ambiance was lovely as well. There's a long wait of course, however their location provides access to so many cool bars to grab a drink while you wait. And trust me, it's worth it!
author: Maureen L.

description:
The place does not take reservation and so my party of three arrived at 5pm. The restaurant has simple yet elegant clean design. 

We ordered pizza, pasta (I believe most are handmade) and the daily fish which was a sea bass. I love their pizza the most because it was the most crispy thin crust I've ever had, I could not stop eating one slice after another.

Service was quick and even dessert was quite delicious. I'm definitely going back to try more pastas. Price was perfect for the quality we got.
author: Maria C.

description: We came here twice already and we will come back again in the future. We love their cocktails and pasta. I think they have the best pasta in town. However, the pizza wasn't the best for us. We will skip that next time. Their nightly special was the best but only happens on every Tuesday.
author: Kent Q.

description:
Came here before the ballet one night and had a lovely dinner with my cousin. Shared a pizza, salad and pasta over a bottle of Falanghina. What else can a girl ask for!?! 
Service was quick and very efficient. Food was fresh and delicious.
I would totally come back.
author: Diana M.

description: Great Italian spot. Awesome rotating dishes. Great cocktails, but have to get here early go after work for snacks and drinks.
author: Joe B.

description:
Delicious, delicious, delicious! For 2 people, with tax, we got out for about $110.

+Drinks: glass of rose, arnold palmer
+Salads: gem lettuce, fennel, radish, anchovy, ricotta salata, capers = 5 stars
wild arugula, stone fruit, gorgonzola, hazelnut, pickled shallot= 1 million stars
+Mains: tagliatelle, pesto, haricot verts, fingerling potatoes, pinenuts = 4 stars (personally, I think it may have needed a little more "edge"- either salt or red pepper flakes)
gemelli, lamb sausage, tomato, eggplant, nepitella= 5 stars (husband was in HEAVEN)
+Desserts: panna cotta with fresh strawberries = 1 million stars
strawberry sorbet with salt flakes and fresh strawberries= 5 stars

+Service: 5 stars

We sat outside on a Thursday evening. Seated a little before 6 and beat the rush. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Kathryn F.

description:
Three of us came here for dinner on Monday night (4th of July weekend), about 7 weeks after their opening. a Mano doesn't take reservations, and we were told the wait would be an hour. We went a few doors down to Brass Tacks for a drink, and they called us just 30 minutes later. Of course we were thrilled to be seated early but had to force down the drinks we just got at BT - seems like they're still working out some kinks in wait times. 

The food: for apps, we ordered the duck liver mousse and the squid. Both were delicious! The mousse was the perfect amount of rich, and the kumquat jam was a really nice, acidic touch. The squid was also really nicely done, with a delicious romanesco sauce. There were a few too may shishito peppers for my taste, but overall it was yummy.

Entrees: my SO ordered the osso buco (the nightly special), my friend ordered the agnolotti, and I got the bucatini. His osso buco was so good! The meat was done perfectly, the polenta was creamy, and the portion size was great. My friend's agnolotti (mini ravioli) was decent, although the portion size was kind of small - just 14 or so small pieces, with each being about a quarter of a ravioli.

Now to my bucatini - I honestly can't understand why it's one of the most popular pastas here (per our server). The pasta was super thick and chewy, it was not seasoned (I struggled to find any pancetta in the dish), and the tomato sauce smelled so sour it reminded me of something quite the opposite of food (I'll spare you the details). I tried to take a few bites but really didn't like it. Our server was incredibly kind and accommodating, and I ordered the campanelle instead.

This was a ribbon pasta (much better texture than the bucatini) that would have been great with just some cheese, because this dish was too, too much. It was like they threw half the kitchen into this dish - it was so busy with so many conflicting flavors, I didn't quite understand it and didn't like it either. Though better than the bucatini, the lemon and olives were so overpowering, that was all I could taste. I had an unpleasant lingering olive taste in my mouth for the rest of the evening (until we got gelato!).

We didn't try the pizzas and maybe those are worth a try, but the pasta here is nothing special (we tried 3 and none were that good). A little overhyped, imo. Apps were great, but we probably won't be back.
author: Anna M.

description:
a Mano is one of my favorite Italian restaurants in the city. The fresh pasta alone is enough to bring anyone there. The mafladine is nothing short of epic. I am looking forward to trying some the other things the menu, but if it's you're first time and you don't have any issues with eating duck, you pretty much are obliged to order this as your entrée. The cauliflower anitpasti is also amazing, bringing the ordinarily mundane vegetable to breathtaking heights never seen before.

Their wait service is also very attentive and were able to come up with beverage choices that were non-alcoholic that were something other than water and diet coke. I appreciated her knowledge of the menu and genuine desire to make sure we were happy with our meal and overall experience.

What's more, the prices at a Mano are oddly reasonable, especially considering the location and quality of the meals. Hayes Valley is famed for its ability to sell tiny portions of food to astronomical prices. It's almost like the restaurant owners and chefs meet after work at a bar and dare each other to see how much they can gouge their customers, knowing there will always be some nouveaux riches millennial who will pay quadruple of what something is worth as long as it branded in a lower case helvetica font with minimal coloring. a Mano is not one of those locations- the prices are decidedly fair. What's more, there usally is nothing more than a short wait, even at 8 PM on a Saturday, though I don't expect this to be the case for much longer, so get a reservation if you can.

One thing I noted is that the hostess that was working there when I was there was downright hostile to the idea of having to do any sort of work. I attempted to reserve a table via yelp and she would immediately cancel it. When I showed up in person to put my name in I told her that we'd be just outside the door under the heat lamps since it was too crowded at the bar and she started to whine about how she wouldn't go outside to call me. Really. I mean, of all the jobs in a restaurant- especially when you consider how hard waiters, bussers, and cooks get slammed so hard they can't even take a 5 minute break during the rush- the job of hostess is literally to write down names on a list, smile and be pretty, call out the names of people on the list, and walk 10 feet with the diner and say "enjoy your meal", but she couldn't be pressed to have to step 4 feet away from her post to open the front door and call out my name. Anyway, when she started with the whining I just gave her a blank stare which could have said "the energy you are expending into complaining is literally more than it would take to just let me know my table is ready" with a mix of "your job could easily be replaced by a app." Now I know why waiters almost always hate the hostesses, but play nice with them because they usually want to sleep with them too, which stereotypically is not a difficult task either. But I digress...

Either way, good hostess or bad, don't miss a Mano before it becomes swamped and the waits become intolerable!
author: Matt L.

description: I love this place!  What a great addition to the neighborhood.  Nice design.  Friendly staff.  Delicious and inventive salads.  Absolutely sublime pizza.
author: Thomas M.

description:
A welcome addition to the neighborhood that needs more casual fine dining.

The prices are inline with the quality and quantity of food you get, you'll definitely want more than one dish if you are trying to have a meal.
author: Kurt N.

description:
A fun place, even if I did have to schlepp a cup of tea from the nearby Starbucks (always wonder why restaurants find it impossible to boil water?)

A really helpful & friendly waiter. I think that makes a big difference. It does not excuse bad food, but food that is good/not great, which pretty much describes A Mano, tastes much better when a person feels welcome.

He recommended a cocktail "like a mimosa", actually a little less sweet. I had it with olives. I had planned, reading menu on line, to order beets but two diners near me had the cauliflower and it looked so good I ordered that as appetizer. It was good as it looked. The waiter recommended a special, fried chicken with polenta and two fried eggs. The chicken was piping hot and generous portions, good flavor. Polenta too bland. Eggs were eggs. I'd say good, not great, but more than edible.

They don't list desserts on line so I thought I might have to walk to the nearby ice cream parlor, but helpful waiter brought me a dessert menu. Got chocolate something, he called it like a pots de creme, I think closer to mousse, dense dark chocolate with whipped cream on top. One of the desserts where you say what's not to like?

I will very likely return for lunch sometime. But could they please add tea?
author: Carol S.

description: Taglatielle and orechiette were delicious. Got the fried squash for appetizer which was great.  Drinks were good too.
author: Shalini C.

description: Super rude hostess and staff. Sub par food. Overpriced. "Buzzy" environment is it's only claim to fame.
author: Eve M.

description: Got a table here on a Friday at around 10pm. Hostess was friendly and the sever was too...until she brought our check and took our plates while we were still eating. Felt really pressured to leave which wasn't the chill Italian food and drink vibe we were going for. That said the margarita pizza was fresh and had a thin crispy crust. The best salad was good but nothing mind blowing. This is a nice spot to hang with friends and have food and drinks but wasn't a fan of being rushed to leave.
author: Lauren K.

description: The food was delicious. The atmosphere was casual and comfortable. The service needs improvement but I expect that for a newly opened establishment. I would bring out of town guests here for a great meal, the cuisine is very straightforward.
author: Chandler G.

description:
I love this place for the fresh, hand-made pasta. Me and my boyfriend both got the agnolotti dal plin with pork and chicken. It was well-seasoned and rich, but not too heavy, and had a delicious savory taste. I was pleasantly surprised by its depth of flavor. Highly recommend this dish. Small/moderate portion size. 

Also importantly: we were able to be seated immediately (at a side table, however) on a Friday night at 8:30!

We also got the fontina arancini, which is a few pieces of cheesy bread with an olive dip. The bread was quite moist and buttery, and the olive dip was good but salty; overall, nothing to write home about but still enjoyable.

While the food gets 5 stars from me, the cocktails were pretty good but not excellent. There are plenty of gin selections in their cocktails. I recommend the Wallbanger, which is fruity and minty but not overwhelmingly so - great for the summertime. The Spritz was refreshing and not too sweet. Our least favorite was probably the Godfather; but basically, you just have to be okay with the taste of almond bitters if you're going to order that.
author: Juliet Y.

description:
This was my second time dining experience. It's a mixed bag.  

Good: cauliflower appetizer is a must.  It's delicious.  My Ravioli was to die for.  Also the margherita pizza was so good I need to reorder next time.

Not-so-good: 1 hr 20 min wait for table of 4 was excessive and unpleasant. The reception lady was not helpful and inexperienced in estimating wait time.  Lastly, the final bill was miscalculated.  The wait staff was enthusiastic and attentive but slightly careless.

Food (4) + Service (2) = Average of 3.
author: Wing W.

description:
Soo the wait here is insane...but it's definitely worth it. I came here around 7:30pm on a weekday (my fault - should have known) and the wait was an hour and a half. I came back at 9:30pm on a weekend and was seated immediately. I ordered the rigatoni with pork ragu and it came out immediately. This pasta was so delicious! I recommend splitting an appetizer or two as the pasta was on the smaller side.

Definitely would recommend going if you don't mind waiting or are willing to eat on the later side.
author: Mia B.

description:
I'm always excited to see a new restaurant in the neighborhood, so I made a point to catch a Mano early on to see what they've put together on their menu. They have an excellent walking distance from the Civic Center venues, so it sounds like a romantic stroll off to dinner before or after a show, right? Keep in mind they don't currently offer reservations, so you'll likely have to wait a while to get seated. 

Atmosphere and service: 
a Mano has a surprisingly large footprint in the Hayes Valley corridor, the length of the restaurant receiving floor-to-ceiling window light. We arrived for an earlier dinner so we had a really nice evening glow for most of the meal. 

You're greeted by a very tidy bar upon entry, a somewhat absurd quantity of surplus apértifs fill the shelves above the regular drinking options. Grab a seat here if you can after your name is put down, my friends have gone more recently than I have and the wait has been ~1 hour each time.

The seating is very social and close-quarters, very welcome with the style and vibe of the menu. Our server was very kind and gave us some nice introductions to the pasta making and ingredients, not too pitchy though (much appreciated). 

The meal:
We each got the Agnolotti dal plin, the portion was a bit on the small side but I did enjoy the dish. Flavors were rather subtle but well done, I definitely could have added another appetizer beforehand.

I will say my review took a half-star hit or so because we ended up getting our focaccia after our main course and cocktails. I had assumed by that point that our bread + tapenade just didn't make the order and was ok with it, that sort of threw me off and decided not to get any dessert.

Fingers crossed that they open up reservations in the future, the bar is just too quaint to allow for parties waiting to be seated. One of those text-when-your-table-is-ready services could also allow you to grab a drink nearby without fear you're losing your spot...
 
I'll be back!
author: Taylor S.

description: Totally decent Italian spot in SF. They're walk-in only, and quite popular, so be prepared to wait. The food is pretty good and service is friendly, but unless you have to have pasta, not worth the wait. I've not had pizza here, just salads and pasta, both of which are relatively standard. They've also got good drinks, and a fun casual atmosphere. Good for a weeknight dinner, definitely aim to go a little early to avoid waiting over an hour.
author: Anna S.

description: Came here on New Years Eve. Food was good, but that was quickly overshadowed when we checked our bank account to find the waitress took our $20 cash tip PLUS $20 on our debit card which we used to pay our bill.
author: Bratty M.

description:
Best meal I've had all year! We ordered the mix salad, speghetanni with clams and the chicken/pork pasta which was like a ravioli. Make sure you get there before 5:30pm or you be waiting in line.

Lastly, the service was excellent and I really liked the decor and plethora of windows.
author: Al Y.

description: Showed up a little before 6pm on Friday night and got a table for two immediately. There was a wait when we left though. Food was outstanding. Shared the asparagus, spring onion, lemon, caciocavallo pizza, pesto tagliatelle and rigatoni with pork sauce. Wine comes by the glass, carafe or bottle. Also there were two house wines for $7 which is a steal in SF!
author: Kim O.

description: Full of young, vibrant, and somewhat hipster energy, this place served memorable pasta dishes.  We had bucatini all' amatriciana and (my bad for not jotting this down) chestnut pasta.  The first is my go-to choice, in an ode to my visits to Rome, and the second had to be a seasonal special.  Both presented pleasurable texture of the hand-made (a Mano) pasta, which btw Marcella Hazan calls "cashmere of pasta"with near perfectly balanced sauce.  We also had the duck liver mousse and beet salad, which were very tasty.  Good cocktails helped with the wait, as they do not take reservations.  Currently in my top three picks for pasta in San Francisco.
author: Alice A.

description: My friends and I thoroughly enjoyed our experience at a Mano. The food was absolutely delicious, the cocktails were great, and the restaurant itself was set up and decorated very beautifully. The moment my friend and I arrived at the restaurant, either the manager or owner greeted us immediately and was extremely welcoming. Our waitress was similarly very attentive and knowledgeable about the food and dining experience in general. Would definitely recommend this restaurant to SF locals or tourists alike.
author: Anoush Y.

description:
Rarely write reviews on yelp, but I'm a big fan of this place. Been there twice so far. First time on opening night. Second a week later. Food is fantastic, consistent, and moderately priced. Monterey squid and cauliflower apps were awesome. Pizza is really good- not amazing by New York standards, but at $12 a pop, a really great value and overall has really great thin, crisp, but chewy, crust. Pastas are fantastic! Had the rigatoni pork sugo on first visit. Rigatoni was perfectly aldente. Sauce had a ton of flavor and great texture. Had the agnolotti on the second visit- amazing pillows of goodness. 

One of the best things about a mano is the staff. Everyone whom I've met that works there is super warm, attentive, and visibly excited about being part of what will become a neighborhood, and likely, sf institution within the next year or two. I should mention that both times we've been, we've  taken our 2 year old. A combo of great food, staff and great and spacious design make this place super family friendly. 

Welcome to the neighborhood a mano! We will be back on a regular basis.
author: Dan Z.

description:
Hanging around Hayes Valley with my boyfriend when we walked by a very cute and airy restaurant that turned out to be the new Italian spot my boyfriend read about! We walked in around 7 and had no wait! It was almost a full house, but it was a soft opening so I'm sure it'll be even busier now!

We had a carafe of the house white wine, which we both really enjoyed. It paired well with the pastas we had.

I don't remember the exact names but he had the spaghetti with clams and I had the agnolotti with chicken and pork. I wished his was a little less al dente but it was fine for him, we both really liked mine!

Also had the calamari/shrimp appetizer which was super yummy! It was lightly breaded and fried so it stood out a lot :) would get again.

Overall, a great price point and a dinner spot if you're around the area for drinks!
author: Angela H.

description: Wow. A new favorite. My chesnut pasta was amazingly delicious. Also had a cauliflower appetizer and bay leaf pannacotta. Flavors were on point. Prices are very reasonable for the great food you get. Service is also very friendly and attentive. What a fantastic place! Thank you A Mano for a wonderful experience.
author: A H.

description: Pasta made from scratch, delicious! The seating arrangement wasn't very comfortable, the spacing between tables is basically non existent. I wish there were more pasta options on the menu.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Visited here on a Monday with colleagues for dinner and the place was packed. After dinning here I could see why! Its modern, clean and simply decorated with staff that truly aims to please. 

Had the Rossini bubbly cocktail- Very good, had to limit myself so I could eat! 

Appetizers: 
4/5 monterey squid
3.5/5 fontina arancini - usually love this dish, but felt it needed more flavor and salt
5/5 fritto misto, shrimp, squid, fennel, spring onion - light and tasty with a creamy dipping sauce
5/5 cauliflower, lemon, chili, bagna cauda- one of my fav dishes of the night, chilli isn't spicy and made the dish pop (color wise and flavor wise as well)


Entrees:
3/5 margherita pizza- my lease fav dish bc didn't taste the basil and soggy in middle
5/5 bucatini with pancetta- usually not a fan of pastas bc its so heavy, but after this dish I can't wait to have more! The pasta was perfectly cooked and seasoned. The sauce was simple, yet delicious and complimented the pasta well. 

Desserts:
5/5 Panna cotta - great way end to a fantastic dinner. Light and refreshing!
4/5 Blood orange sorbet - great flavors and palate cleanser. 

Overall, I can't wait to visit again and try everything else! Great Italian food that isn't heavy and a good value!
author: Suzie J.

description:
Let me start by staying that the only reason I am giving this place 2 stars is because of our very kind and knowledgeable waitress (thank you waitress whose name I do not know!)
Aside from that a Mano was not good from the start.. we walked in after seeing many pictures on yelp of home made pasta and undoubtably being very excited, and were told we could sit at the communal high top tables by the bar.. this was perfectly OK with us, especially when we saw that there were two seats next to each other and not just across from each other which, given the incredibly loud volume and packed capacity of the restaurant, would have hopefully given us a more intimate meal. 
However for some reason our hostess refused to let us sit next to each other and said they Only seated cross table couples. Both myself and my partner AND the girl sitting next to me already at the table pointed out that the remaining seat was a solo seat so it didn't matter anyways, but she flat out refused to seat us in a position she was completely capable of.
After that she moved us to a table because she NEEDED us across from each other and there we began the unfortunate beginning of our meal.
I have so little to say about the food except that we  ordered a few appetizers, a pizza and a pasta (all seemingly delicious despite the rude service and horrible ambiance) and yet somehow everything tasted exactly the same.. like nothing.. is this even possible?
I am not sure I have had a more flavorless meal ever. And needless to say we were very disappointed and finished nothing (which if you met my partner is saying a lot!)
Oh we did finish the wine. Which we brought ourselves. Corkage fee is only 20$ in case you were wondering.

There are so many amazing Italian places in SF. Don't waste your time.
author: Holden C.

description: After the pasta dish, did not feel heavy and groggy! As if I had a plate of veges. Balance of flavors was so amazing I wanted to savor every bite!
author: Hyun B.

description: One of my favorite places in SF. I've never had anything but amazing service and excellent food. Cocktails are refreshing and light.  The pastas taste fresh and delicate.  The pizza is probably my favorite.  It gets busy but has quite a bit of space for a city place.
author: Natasha M.

description: Amazing pizza, pastas, drinks, and staff. Great (for SF) prices, cute, vibrant ambiance. One of my favorite new restaurants!
author: Mirabella Y.

description:
The line to get into A Mano was long, long, long.  Maybe that was because of the positive San Francisco Chronicle review the day before or maybe it was because people know a good deal when it arrives.  By good deal I mean a place with an up-tempo vibe, good service, good food, and all at a good price.  

First off, my server (Alexa) knew the menu and steered me away from over ordering.  In fact all of the service staff, whether male or female, seems to be attractive and well-versed in the menu.  That's always a positive.  

I started with stone fruit salad which came with nicely ripe nectarines, arugula, soft cheese, and red onion.  Not overly dressed.  Very nice indeed.  

Next up was the nightly special of osso buco.  The meat was fall off the bone tender.  A small spoon was placed in the bone at the center of the meat to allow me to dig out the marrow.  Atop the meat was a slight grating of horseradish that livened the meat.  I would have liked even a bit more of the horseradish but never mind as that's a quibble.   Polenta and fresh spinach came with the meat.  In other words the nightly special was a fully realized plate of food. 

It's quite obvious that A Mano is well managed and well conceived and is going to be a fixture of the food scene for quite some time.
author: David D.

description:
I had the Monterrey grilled octopus on white beans app which was outstanding. I almost ordered it again for dessert. 

For dinner, I had the orichette pasta with clams. Excellent flavor with both dishes served at the appropriate temperature.

The place was hopping with a good vibe. I ate at Lolinda last time to SFO and this chef has done excellent work at both restaurants.

Keep it going!!
author: Lawrence F.

description:
We showed up to a Mano a little before it opens at 5. Thankfully, the line wasn't horribly long so we were able to get a seat for the first round of dining. The menu looks fantastic and we were excited to try several dishes. 

Our first dish was an arugula salad with peaches, hazelnuts, and gorgonzola. This was a delicious and refreshing salad that we all enjoyed. We had high hopes for the rest of the dishes.

The next dish was the chicken polpettine with spicy tomato sauce. It was a pretty dry and tasteless meatball. There wasn't enough juice from the chicken and the tomato sauce didn't balance out the dryness of the meatball. If you're looking for a fantastic meatball, I highly recommend the meatballs from Seven Hills. Those are the best meatballs I've had yet to date.

Next we had the monterey squid, summer corn, romanesco, and olives. This dish was nice with the sweet corns, but it wasn't terribly exciting. The squid was mediocre at best and slightly overcooked.

It took a very long time in between the antipasti and the main courses. Our waitress said they want to give us a break to digest our food between the antipasti and main but the wait was far too long and made the flow of the meal awkward.

For the mains, we got the margherita, tomato, for di latte, and basil pizza as well as the bucatini all' amatriciana, tomato, and pecorino (minus the pancetta). It was decent. If you go to check out the restaurant, I'd recommend it but I wouldn't go back just for the pizza. The dough is a little thicker and chewier than the thin crust. It has a good tomato sauce and the for di latte tastes fresh. The bucatini was underwhelming. It wasn't very exciting and the noodles had an odd hollowness in the middle. It doesn't taste fresh or handmade. It tastes store bought to me.

The restaurant itself is a bit noisy and the chairs are not the most comfortable. I would recommend bringing cushion if you are so tempted to go, but if you're looking for good Italian food, I would skip a Mano. There are several other Italian pizza and/or pasta restaurants I'd rather go to to satisfy my pizza and pasta cravings.
author: Emma L.

description:
This place is basically a fancier version of Olive Garden. 

I'm giving  this place two stars because our server was great otherwise the entire experience was sub par and deserves 1 star.

The atmosphere of this place is cold and cafeteria like.  It seriously lacks any charm and reminds me of the cafeteria at the Exploratorium (which btw is awesome but not for the food).

The food was less than mediocre.  So bad we decided to accidentally "forget" our left overs.  Everything sounded good on the menu but turned out to be incredibly bland and lacking distinct flavors.  

The pasta was cooked properly but again was tasteless.

Overall, I was very disappointed by our meal and experience.
author: Alan P.

description:
Sigh. The duck mafaldine. So freaking good. Love it!! 

Be prepared for a wait of 1-2 hours though!
author: J. A.

description:
Great vibe and service and dessert and drinks.
I'll come back again. And probably keep going.
They keep changing their menu and add new desserts which are Soo fresh and fullsome!
Great work guys! Keep it up.
author: Auroshikha R.

description: I am all in for all of the food here. I have been here twice now and everything has been on point. The short rib entree was perfect. The most recent porchetta was also exceptionally done well. The skin was crispy and very well seasoned. The bucatini is so delicious. The pizza is also what you would expect for everywhere else.
author: Lucio G.

description: 3 times is a charm, I finally got a table at this place. What a fantastic meal. I started off with Beet salad+arugula with pickled shallot, pistachios and honey yogurt...beautiful combo. You can taste the sweet, the sour and the salty. Then followed by amazing fungi pizza, crunchy and very tasty. Service is great and so are the cocktails m
author: Wawa O.

description: So worth the wait! Tasty fresh pasta served hot! Great wine list. Terrific helpful waiter & hostess. An awesome experience.
author: Robby B.

description: Really delicious food at an extremely affordable price. Great pizza options - we chose the margherita and one with salsiccia(sp?) -  both were delicious and had excellent crust. For their homemade pasta, we went with the bucatini and they did not disappoint. Will definitely make this place a go to on our list.
author: Ben M.

description: Sooooo good! I had the buccatini amatriciana and my partner had a white pizza. Everything tasted so fresh and was well executed. From where we sat you could into the open kitchen and watch the kitchen staff make the fresh pasta. The only downside is that they don't take reservations and the wait can be long (this time we waited ~ 1 hr for a 2-person table at 7 pm on a Saturday). However, the service is fast and the food is totally worth it.
author: Samantha S.

description: Mmmmmm so good. This restaurant group has got it going on in all the right ways. Great homemade food, tasty cocktails, targeted but delicious wine list all priced reasonably! That combined with consistent, friendly, knowledgeable, and caring staff makes for a great time. Beware this is a popular place for good reasons so either get there early or be ready for a wait. Good thing it's in a great neighborhood with plenty of things to see while you wait.
author: Matthew B.

description: Highly recommend a Mano. I know this place because of friend's recommendation. I have been here twice now. The wait is not too bad considering there are shops around here. Recommended dishes are appetizer for cauliflower and entree for hand-made pasta (Campanelle - the mushroom based one is so good). We also tried the Saturday special Porchetta - the combination of the side salad and Porchetta itself makes it a dish that you absolutely can not refuse. Overall, the dinning experience is excellent.
author: Jia S.

description: Amazing service, and even better food and drinks. The atmosphere is open and lively. We put our name on a long wait list but spent the time easily shopping our way through Hayes Valley on a beautiful Saturday evening. Once seated, I loved sitting at our table being able to watch happenings at the bar, fresh pasta being made and pizza being tossed, with a great view outside of one of the best spots in Hayes valley. Our waiter was prompt and had great suggestions for wine pairings and excellent suggestions for helping me decide what to order. For the price, this is one of the most reasonable nice restaurants in San Francisco, I will definitely be back!
author: Sydney C.

description: Great find! Beautiful restaurant full of light. Staff super nice and knowledgeable about menu and recommendations. Can't really go wrong with anything in the menu. Brought out a complimentary cocktail for the birthday girl!
author: cindy n.

description: In a way I'm glad this opened up, because my favorite place around the block has a much shorter wait.  So in that regard, give this 10 stars so all of you wait in line here.  But truthfully this was an average experience for food.  First off, the wait is humorous...it's not worth 1.5 hours or whatever it usually is.  This is a 30 min wait restaurant at best.  The reason being is that the food is basically a fancy version of something like Delrosa...now I have nothing to complain about for Delarosa, but there's no wait, and it's chill.  Yes the pasta is homemade, but nothing was amazing, esp to warrant the wait.  The apps were fine, the pasta was fine (and per our usual regiment, no desert if the nothing else popped).  The only thing I will say is that the value is solid. So I'd go here only if the wait was nil.  But there are way better places for Italian (see Bellotti).
author: A A.

description: I wanted to let u know, last night we came in for dinner, and I was craving pasta. We had  ordered a salad, a pizza, 3 different pasta dishes and a salmon special. The only thing we all agreed we liked was the salad. The ravioli, bucatini and I forget the 3rd dish was all over cooked. And the salmon was over cooked too. Just saying. Since we were told that the pastas were house made, my expectations were higher. For this price, I'd say I'm rather disappointed (all 4 of us)
author: S L.

description: You can tell that the pasta is fresh.  Good portions too.  Great place for lunch and looking forward to checking it out for dinner sometime.
author: a f.

description: Service was good, the place is nice, and their cauliflower appetizer was delicious. My pasta dish was good, but not great.
author: Sue V.

description: Young, vibrant, and bustling ambiance. Mediocre food. I got the tagliatelle dish with olives. This was much too salty and lacked complexity in flavor. It was very one dimensional, overpowered by the olives. My friend got the pesto dish. It was standard and nothing to rave about.
author: S W.

description:
Went there this past Wednesday night: 

In a nutshell, it is a slightly better version of Delarosa with less pizza and more pasta choices with pretty much similar wine list and drink offerings.

Pro: just like Delarosa, food items are well priced, but when you are selling flour and water as well as small plates, they would have a hard time to sustain higher prices in the long run.
Server was graceful and attentive, as well as the bartender and the hostess.
Space is beautiful but the bar area right by the host stand is too cramped and small, especially when you don't take reservations and guests are looking for a space to wait for their table. 

Con:
Pizza dough was too crunchy, almost like eating bread sticks; neither Delarosa or A Mano have figured out the right recipe, it should be much softer and lighter. It is surprising they could not perfect it since Ruggero and Adriano are both Italians.  
Chicken meatballs were too spicy, a little kick is ok but too much it throws off the flavors off the window.
Arancini were dry and one dimensional in flavor.
Cauliflowers and the Gem Lettuce salad were the two better items, but it is hard to messed up with those two.
They do not take reservations, which could be a hassle if you do not want to wait for a table; they do not have a place were you can enjoy your drinks while waiting for your reservation. Having some form of booking system it would improve their customer service.

Lolinda is by far still their most consistent and well done product they have in their company.
Open one more of those, 3 Delarosa are enough for now... and open it on Divisadero spot you are about to take over, I live a few blocks away :)
author: Gabe M.

description: Intimate, hometown, authentic Italian spot. Food was amazing, our waitress was friendly, and will definitely be back. No resevations, but plenty of nearby places to start with a quick drink.
author: Kyle M.

description: I would come here and have pasta for breakfast, lunch and dinner, if I could! One of the best pasta restaurants I've ever been to. All the pasta is made in house and so so delicious. We ordered 4 dishes and they were all amazing. The malfadine braised duck was our favourite - we actually ordered another one after tasting it. Arancini balls were like little bursts of heaven. Service was top notch, our server Kate was efficient, super helpful and very friendly. We're already planning our return trip. Highly recommended.
author: Chris N Kalista M.

description: This has to be one of the best Italian restaurants in SF. My boyfriend and I went on a date there, shared the squid spaghetti, the chestnut Brussels sprouts pasta and the fungi pizza. It was absolutely delicious - the pasta tasted great, the sauces had very delicate flavors and the pizza's crust is one of the best out there.
author: Lea O.

description:
We came here on a bracingly cold Thursday night around 6pm. When we put our names down, we were told the wait to be seated would be one hour-- no big deal, as Hayes Valley has a ton of little, albeit expensive, boutiques to wander through. Anyway, a Mano is a nice relief from the pricey offerings of the surrounding shops-- our entire meal for two clocked in at a cool $55 and we were rather happy. We ordered the chanterelle mushroom conserva with ricotta and grilled bread, funghi pizza (caramelized onions, escarole, rosemary, scarmoza), chestnut campanelle (brussells sprouts, chestnuts, celery root crema, and the bucatini all' amatriciana (sans pancetta, as we are vegetarian). 

We'd say that the portions sizes, at least for the pasta, skew slightly smaller than other plates in the city-- but they are also cheaper. We didn't love either pasta. The bucatini probably needed the pancetta for extra salt and flavor-- it tasted pretty unremarkable as we had it. One of our party loved the campanelle, but didn't have the oh-my-god-I-could-eat-this-all-day reaction that we've had elsewhere. Our server did mention that the stuffed pasta option is usually vegetarian-- it just so happened that they didn't have it on the menu. The pizza was delicious-- loved the crust, but again, nothing about it stood out. 

Would we come back? Sure, if we were in the area. But if we were craving pasta and had some lead time? We'd head to one of the many other places in the city that take reservations and serve up plates of holy-mother-of-god-now-I-can-die-happy pasta.
author: T K.

description: Beet salad with honey yogurt dressing is a must to begin the meal! And although you can't go wrong with any pasta choice since they are all homemade and cooked perfectly al dente - the bucatini is the best pasta on the menu. It has a traditional red tomato sauce that has a little kick and the added bonus of pancetta.
author: Laura B.

description:
Everything was fresh, and nice, but just good.  Nothing lovely, besides the drinks and company.  The space was nice and great service.  Was with people in the industry, so we got lots of comps, and they were all good.  Just good.

I would go back though so a 3+ for me.
author: Pul F.

description: I had a really good meal here last Saturday.  No wait which is unusual, but delightful on a Saturday night.  We started with a glass of the verdicchio while we were waiting for the first course.  We had the pate with strawberries.  It was a lovely dish, the pate was creamy and delicious and the strawberries added some sweetness.  It's perfect.  Second course was the tomato salad.  It's wonderful, fresh and the avocados add some lovely creamy texture.  I had the agnolotti as a main.  Stuffed with roasted chicken in a light cream sauce it's a lovely pasta dish without being too heavy.  All in all a really good night out.
author: Andrew S.

description: Wine, app, salad, and entree were amazing. My friend was a huge help with selection. Will return again.
author: Karson P.

description: Very artisan, but the portion sizes are very small. Not quite satisfactory for a hungry Americans.
author: Zeke S.

description:
This might be my new spot to take out of towners.  My fav is still Statebird hands down, but it does tend to be pricier.  Complete bill last night including a 25% tip was $130 (1 app, 2 pastas, 1 dessert, 4 drinks). When you go, ask for Kyle's section, he was phenomenal!  We got lucky and sat at the high communal table and got seated right away at 6pm, a table for two would have been a 30 min wait.

Antipasti - Monterey Squid - Tasty.  Corn was sweet, Squid was salty. Great balance and with a bit of sauce to round out everything.

Pasta - Tagliatelle - The pesto is a bit different from most, but it was light and hit all the right notes.  Texture of the handmade pasta made it great.  Huge difference between store bought and hand made for sure.

Pasta - Rigatoni, pork sugo - First bite in was definitely salty, but I think once everything mellowed a bit and you get a few more bites in, you appreciate that balanced with the meat sauce.  Again, the handmade pasta was definitely the star.  I'm a bit biased because I tend to eat saltier foods, but this was my friend's preference of the two pastas (I like her Tagliatelle more though, but to each their own)

Dessert - Got the Nutella ice cream to round out the night to share.  Great way to end a great meal.
author: Dave C.

description: Throughly enjoyed our evening at A Mano. The decor, lighting and the service (Kyle) were five star. Squid and bean appetizer, beet salad, fried chicken were delicious. We will be back!
author: Dan S.

description: Excellent restaurant on Hayes street. Homemade pasta. Recommend the pesto pasta, bucatini and chicken polpettine. Friendly and attentive staff, nice atmosphere, open kitchen. Make a reservation before you go.
author: Kathleen S.

description: Super tasty spot. Had the pork chop, pork belly special and a Bolognese pasta dish. Twas perfect. Outdoor seating was nice and warm even though it was late. 5 stars.
author: Timur Z.

description:
a mano= perfection!  literally the best italian food in san francisco right now.  barnone.  we got there late on a wednesday and the place was packed with so much positive energy it was contagious.  we got super lucky and scored a table outside.  it was pouring rain outside but it was perfect because they have heaters and awnings so we didn't get wet!  

The food was out of this world.  we started with the cauliflower and the chicken meatballs.  the cauliflower was so good i could have it for my main course.  it had peppers and capers and was roasted to perfection.  the chicken meatballs were delightful and came in a marinara sauce that is perfect.  we had the pasta bolognese and the rigatoni with clams.  the pasta bolognese was literally out of this world.  the pasta was cooked to perfection and the bolognese sauce was traditional yet elegant.  the rigatoni was extraordinary.  it was cooked al dente so it had a bit of a bite to it, the clams were fresh and the broccoli rabe "pesto" sauce was phenomenal.  we finished with the amazing nutella sundae.....pure decadence. 

while the food is extraordinary the service and staff are equally as wonderful.  we were greeted by the lovely gaelle  who was very professional, sweet and calm given the busy environment.  we were lucky enough to meet amanda who spoiled us and was so delightful.  And last, but not least....our server was alexa.  alexa was incredible.  she was working in the rain and she didn't complain at all.  we felt bad for her and she was so happy go lucky and sweet.  whats ironic is that the place was so busy but the service was still stellar!  we felt very well taken care of and that the service never skipped a beat despite the crowd.  this is a sign of a well run restaurant.  

we literally cannot wait to go back and try all the other fabulous dishes on the menu!  a mano has literally made hayes valley a destination not to be missed.
author: Samantha B.

description:
Second time didn't disappoint! Both pizzas were delicious and the asparagus and prosciutto appetizer was wonderful. We got the cauliflower again, consistently satisfying. Service and cocktails just as friendly and refreshing as the night before! 

Only suggestion would be to close the door if possible - it was a little chilly. But I understand if it's not an option.
author: Shimmy S.

description: Good food , good service , friendly bartender and the price is reasonable :-) enjoyed so much
author: Yumikase P.

description: Fabulous pasta, friendly service. No reservations, tight bar space, but worth the wait. Outdoor seating options.
author: Vicki L.

description: I've been here twice and both times the pasta was fantastic. The service, not so much which was why I reduced my rating by one star.  Our server My first visit seemed to have a bit of an attitude problem then screwed up our check at the end. The second time around one of the hostesses seemed snooty when we asked to be seated so we could get some food on the table while our guests were 10 minutes away. I still recommend it to people who are in the mood for Italian because in my experience the execution of their dishes was flawless. Give it a try!
author: Jason J.

description: Amazing little Italian place in Hayes. Good for a low key dinner with a friend or two and also good for a large group ready to feast. Plates are shareable and they have a good selection of pizza, pasta, salads, and other entrees. Dessert was fabulous as well. All around good vibes, good service, and great food!
author: Heidi C.

description: Great food, great cocktails. I've never actually sat in the restaurant because the bar seat Gods are on my side. I would actually prefer to sit at the bar here.
author: Adriana S.

description: I believe a 3 rating is rather generous but I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt. Needless to say, my first experience here was NOT a pleasurable one. My family and I were grabbing a bite to eat before a show and went to a Mano for dinner. The hostess that sat us seemed rather curt and didn't show any kind of warmth. The waiter who took our order was very rude and clearly annoyed with us. The fact that the food took nearly half an hour could have been justified had the waiter just shown some concern for us as customers. When the food did finally arrive, the portions were rather small considering the price and left me hungry. I hate to say that this experience has led me to avoid eating here again.
author: Sky G.

description: tried the porchetta special. outside was crispy but inside was so dry and hard it was inedible.  A pity, as i love porchetta.  pastas still great though. good service at the bar.
author: H S.

description: Mmm this is my favorite pasta place in the city so far. Unique dishes, reasonably priced, nice atmosphere. I got the pasta with celery purée and even though I don't like celery THAT much, I could still appreciate the uniqueness of the flavor. Noodles were cooked perfectly al dente, not too hard and not too soft!
author: Claire L.

description: Much more than just a pasta and salad place. High quality ingredients like chanterelles and daily homemade pasta make this a go-to spot. No reservations so grab a drink next door at Anina while you wait.
author: Mitchell N.

description: There are so many "Caltalian" restaurants in the city, but this is the one to keep coming back to. The antipasti, creative salads, and handmade pastas are all super delicious. The service is not only attentive, but thoughtful. The server we dined with was knowledgeable with her suggestions and descriptions, her company was one of my favorite attributes of the night.  The menu offers a balance between traditional Italian dishes with creative uses of local ingredients.  The cocktail program is articulate and gives nods to European drinking taste. All in all a great experience.
author: K M.

description: cute spot in hayes valley w reasonably priced food. recommend family style! great vegetarian options. small menu but suits many different styles.
author: Cathy Y.

description: Even when is a new restaurant, we were seated quickly. Very good service. Our server Diego was polite, professional and very passionate about the food and wine  We ordered the soft shell crab salad which it was good, flavors worked very well, then we went for the spaghettini with clams, not much to say about this dish, for our taste it was bland. Then we ordered the margherita pizza, delicious pizza, thin and crispy crust. We'll be back to try more dishes.
author: Harold F.

description:
I'll break this down into two parts:

Last night, I went in with a few friends to try this new spot. We walked in about 10:30, were seated promptly and the server was beyond chipper--genuinely hospitable. Was his name Kevin? Bearded fellow. Very patient as my Sommelier companion questioned him about the bottle list. (Wine was on point!)

Apps of olives, cauliflower and duck liver. The cauliflower was insane! Perfect brown on the outside, excellent level of crunch, not over seasoned. Iwould go back for this dish alone.

Pastas: bucatini, agnolotti, and pesto tagliatelle. SO DELISH!!!!! The bucatini seriously rivals Tosca's (which is my 2nd fave behind La Ciccia's bottarga). 

The wine was approachable priced, the service was on point but not intrusive, the space has an awesome vibe (way to go, Hannah!). Of course, this restaurant group KNOCKS IT OUT OF THE PARK!!

so why only 3 stars? 

Tonight, we scurried out of the opera bc we wanted to cap the night with round 2 of pasta! 

We walked in at 10:53 (I was watching the clock bc I know we are the jerks walking in right when staff wants to start shutting down). The host (cute man bun, by the way), told us that they were closed. In an effort to show we would be super quick, I said "even for 2 plates of bucatini and a bottle of Negro Amaro?!" (Insert smiling-please-I-want-pasta-face). Negative. He was not very empathetic. So we left. It was 10:55!

Am I going to go back? Sure. Will I tell everyone this story? Yes. Will it really negatively impact the business? Probs not. But if your hours are 11pm, why don't you seat until 11pm? Change your hours to 10:45 and I won't get annoyed the next time I'm turned away. 

I think your operation, or at least the MOD that night and your door, should take a cue from the server we had last night in terms of hospitality. That's what this business is all about right? 

5 stars for the first visit; 0 stars for the 2nd attempt = 3 stars overall
author: Meg D.

description: The service is poor. We waited 90 minutes only to have our table given to someone else. Eventually we were placed at a glorified high school cafeteria table. Additionally they don't have enough bathrooms so expect a line.  The food was decent at least.
author: David B.

description: Very nice waiters and really good appetizers (squid and duck liver pate) but pasta is beyond underwhelming. We had 3 and the 3 of us weren't crazy about any of them. They were all just kind of ok. Quite disappointed because I do like beretta and Delarosa a lot but honestly for the wait it is not worth it. So much good food in the city, this is just convenient because it's big, easy, and affordable.
author: Marianna L.

description: Wait time on a saturday night was 2 hours, luckily had prior reservations at a different location before hand! Server was very helpful and knowledgeable in the companies' history, etc! Was not too thrilled with the pasta I ordered, (Ravioli/horseradish) in comparison to the pasta dishes ordered with by my friends. However, the staff were friendly under the amount of pressure and people in the building. Nice inside, a little on the dim side & loud, but I still enjoyed the experience. Will be back for that rigatoni.
author: Rj L.

description: Great location and fun atmosphere but the food was good and not fabulous. I enjoyed the squid appetizer but salads and pizza were just okay. Nothing memorable.
author: amanda l.

description: Very disappointing. The food was bland. The cocktails were nothing special. The bread with olive tapenade was the best part of the meal (hence 2 stars). This place is too pretentious and lacking the real Italian flavor.
author: Mariya N.

description: We were here when it opened for dinner at 5. Every table was full 45 minutes later.  Everything was delicious and we recommend.   I especially liked the fried cauliflower appetizer.   We both had home made pastas.   Very vibrant and busy restaurant.   .
author: Jane M.

description: Wonderful, delicious dishes, with a short menu of hits.  Manages to get a broad range of light to filling dishes all with tons of amazing flavor.  The places is exceptionally designed (with wonderful lighting design, which is not common!), and feels quite casual while still exciting.  Our server Kyle was awesome, extremely attentive, nice, understanding, sharp..  probably the best service we have received in a restaurant in some time.  He is definitely deserving of praise for really rounding out a wonderful experience.
author: Dmitry K.

description: The pasta and pizzas are world class. The scene is hip and friendly. When weather permits, the outdoor seating is fun. Also, have nice salads for those of us trying to stay healthy and eat fresh. Perfect ingredients for primo dishes.
author: Kelly H.

description: Went here for dinner with my mom and everything was delicious! The tomatoes in the heirloom salad were fresh and the pistachios were a nice touch. The homemade pasta and ravioilis were fresh and delicious and the portions weren't too big. We had the boudino chocolate dessert and it was very rich with a touch of espresso. I definitely would recommend.
author: Tania L.

description:
Was excited to try this place with friends last night.  We waited about an hour for a table, which wasn't a big deal because they have a system where they text you when your table is ready, so we just hung around the area.

The food started out well - we had a spring salad and a pizza, and the house wine was affordable and decent.

However, when it came to pastas there were several major issues:
1. I asked before I ordered which pastas can be done without garlic because garlic causes severe digestive issues for me. They told me all but one would be fine, so I ordered the clam pasta without garlic.   Unfortunately I ate a bunch of the pasta before noticing there was garlic in it (I actually found a piece to show them).  I spent last night not sleeping as a result.
2. They brought 3 out of 5 pasta out way before the others, so our group couldn't eat at the same time
3. Two of my friends pastas came out cold and had to be redone
author: Yin L.

description: Great late night spot in Hayes Valley. Came here with some girls one night. There was a wait but we got a table outside under the heat lamp pretty quickly. We had the gem lettuce salad, the summer squash pizza (crust was to die for), and the bucatini pasta dish. We were all talkative until the food came and then no one spoke until all the plates were empty. It was delicious! Great addition to Hayes Valley.
author: Vivian L.

description: I was excited to try out this place because of all the amazing reviews and by the strong recommendation by my aunt. She wanted to order the agnolotti because of how good it was when she ordered it a few months ago. Upon trying it, my mouth wasn't satisfied by the taste at all. For a $16ish dish, you except to find yourself going in for another bit but instead I found myself regretting spending that much on a whatever less than okay dish. It turns out they changed the dish for the specific season or something along the lines but it wasn't good so they should change it back. Our server was also a bit passive aggressive imo. I could tell he was fed up serving our table because we asked more than a few questions. The 2 Stars is for the Nutella ice cream and the mushroom dish which was both pretty good. In conclusion...would I come back? No. Too many other places in San Fran that has good consistent food and better service so byeeee A Mano. Thanks but no thanks.
author: Nina T.

description: Make a reservation this place gets packed! We didn't have a reservation, but after talking to Amanda the hostess, she found a way to get us a table with only a 5 minute wait! Service was impeccable. Food was delicious. Loved the duck liver mousse and pasta was perfectly cooked. Amanda even came back over to our table to check-in and recommended a red wine I would have never ordered but now love. I thought this place was going to be overrated but the people who work there were amazing and the food was far beyond expectation. I'll be back with friends (and a reservation).
author: E N.

description: I had lunch at a Mano yesterday. The food was OK and reasonably priced but, as others have noted, the service left something to be desired. My waiter seemed annoyed when I asked for a recommendation between two dishes I was considering, like he didn't have time for my ridiculous question. The rest of the service (from him and others) was brusque and perfunctory. I live in the neighborhood, but I definitely won't go back. There are lots of other Hayes Valley restaurants where the food is as good or better, and staff are much friendlier to their customers.
author: SF D.

description: Everything you could ask for in a neighborhood gem. Truly excellent and friendly service, delicious and unique cocktails, and very VERY good food. Super fresh ingredients, perfectly prepared and reasonably priced. One of the best overall dining experiences I've had in quite a while - if they weren't so deserving of a great review I would be tempted to keep this place my little secret. Kudos to a Mano!
author: Excelsus S.

description: Great wine selection, great food, and the staff was so so kind to us! Reasonably priced, made for a really lovely date night. Also, I'm a vegetarian and had great choices here!
author: Megan N.

description: The service was absolutely incredible. Our waitress was very friendly and so knowledgeable. I couldn't decide between two dishes and she perfectly described them both to me. I ended up loving what I ordered, it was much better than your average pasta. The ambience was nice. The only reason I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is because we were still a little hungry after eating our pasta dishes. I guess I am accustomed to leaving an Italian meal stuffed and their dishes are a little smaller. We both are pretty big eaters, so that could be a factor, but I would make sure to get an appetizer if I went back. But this place really is great and I would recommend it. We sat outside and it was a chilly night but we were right under a heat lamp so it was perfect!
author: Mimi H.

description:
Good place to go for a small group. My wife and I and three of our helpers went here after running a charity booth at Folsom Steet Fair and all of us were exhausted and hungry. The menu was a welcome surprise. Gourmet Italian cooking at reasonable rates. Everybody found something and tucked in. Three of us shared a salad that instantly turned me into a pistachio fan. I don't remember what the others got, although I do remember my wife and one of our helpers finished their plates. The pizza margherita I got was wonderfully flavored and crispy. 

The service was five star, and the lady was both attentive and helpful.  The ONLY reason I'm doing four stars instead of five is that I have hearing problems and the place was so noisy with conversation that I could barely hear my wife, who was sitting next to me. But that's me. Besides, the food is so good it's a conversation stopper. :)
author: Edward B.

description: Update: Gio, the manager, reached to me personally and has done everything in his power to rectify the situation. This level of customer service is very much appreciated. Thank you, Gio.
author: Amanda C.

description: Last night I had a fabulous meal at a Mano. The wait was worth it! My server, Kai, broke down all the pastas for me and gave great recommendations. The vibe was buzzy and hip. I didn't see a chair without a butt for longer than five minutes. Somehow made room for dessert and left in a food coma. Thanks a Mano!
author: Erin W.

description:
Very good.i loved my waiter and and the food. The menu was simple and my waiter was very knowledgeable and picked great choices. The portions and price are excellent as well. Definitely gonna try this again. I like that the pasta was made in house.

Only problem was that it gets pretty loud in there. We were sat next to a bunch of screaming girls. They were loud I could hear my partner till they left. 
Must've been a gno.
author: Hong V.

description:
going to dinner during an nba finals game is the way to go.  we got here at 6 pm last night, and it was pretty empty.  by the time we left though, it was packed - probably b/c the warriors were killing the cavs (woot!).

3 of us tried the squid app, arancini, and the cauliflower to start.  i didn't try the arancini, but i liked the cauliflower and squid a lot.  we each picked a pasta we wanted and shared the tagliatelle, agnoletti and bucatini.  i loved the tagliatelle b/c it was fresh and green.  my friends all loved the pastas too.  there is one woman literally rolling out sheets of dough continuously and making fresh pasta, so you know it's good!
author: Helen T.

description: Really fresh hand-made pasta, and great pizza. Drinks were really good - they were so refreshing and don't taste too strong. Both my friend and I went through them pretty quickly. There was a small hiccup where the waitress mistook our order and served us a different pasta. She offered it for free later but we ended up choosing to pay for it (and cancel our original order) since the pasta was so good! Impressed by the food + service :)
author: Ella K.

description: I stopped in again with a friend for dinner the other day. The food was just as good as the first time, and our server Juliette was amazing! She was the sweetest and knowledgeable. We will be back again soon for another wonderful dinner.
author: Emily S.

description: Really good food. Price is affordable. I would go back for sure. I recommend. I tried pizza and salad. Next time I should try the pasta.
author: Rafael M.

description: Great service, friendly staff, and amazing food! Very quality and a great vibe overall. Can't wait to come again.
author: Bethany L.

description: I went with my girlfriend, we started with an antipasti of figs and two pastas, which we shared (the concept is to share plates).  I can say without risk that the pastas were the best I tried in my life. We liked them so much that we ordered another pasta dish that managed to exceed again our expectations.
author: Quinto P.

description:
I went on a Friday night and it was quite crowded. Initially walked up at 5:30 and they said it'd be a 30 mn wait for table of two. My boyfriend and I didn't want to eat that early, so decided to get a drink nearby. We returned at 6:45, and the same hostess told us 45 mn wait. a Mano uses a text message system to alert you of tables, which was great. 

We were seated at a high communal table- at the end, which was nice. I would not have enjoyed getting seated in the middle of the communal table. We had the carafe of red wine - basic table wine, but well priced.

We started with the squid and argula salad with beets and gorgonzola. The squid was well done - not over cooked, and came with gigante beans that were thick and creamy.

The argula salad with beet and gorgonzola was so-so-  nothing to write home about. The beets had a bit of vinegar flavor, but not bold enough to be decisive about the intent. 

We split the torchetti, lamb sausage,broccoli di ciccio pasta with the salsiccia pizza. The pasta came out first and was delicious. The lamb sausage was well seasoned, and the pasta noodles well cooked. It was hard to stop eating - but knew we had the pizza coming.

The saliccia pizza was good, but not astounding. It was what I expected - no surprises, positive or negative.
